analyzed: tatra etāḥ suṣupti viṣayāḥ śrutayaḥ bhavanti
translated: There are these scriptural statements about deep sleep.

original: kvacicchrūyate 'tadyatraitatsuptaḥ samastaḥ svapnaṃ na vijānātyāsu tadā nāḍīṣu sṛpo bhavati' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: kvacid śrūyate tat yatra etat suptaḥ samastaḥ svapnam na vijānāti āsu tadā nāḍīṣu sṛpaḥ bhavati chā iti
translated: In some places it is heard: When one is deeply asleep and at rest, not knowing any dreams, then one moves about in the channels.

original: anyatra tu nāḍīrevānukramya śrūyate 'tābhiḥ pratyavasṛpya purītati śete' bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: anyatra tu nāḍīḥ eva anukramya śrūyate tābhiḥ pratyavasṛpya purītati śete iti
translated: In another place, however, the nāḍīs are mentioned first, and then it is said, Having entered them, he lies in the purīta, Bṛ Up , , 0

original: tathānyatra nāḍīrevānukramya 'tāsu tadā bhavati yadā suptaḥ svapnaṃ na kañcana paśyatyathāsminprāṇa evaikadhā bhavati' kauṣī / / iti /
analyzed: tathā anyatra nāḍīḥ eva anukramya tāsu tadā bhavati yadā suptaḥ svapnam na kañcana paśyati atha asmin prāṇaḥ eva ekadhā bhavati kauṣī iti
translated: Similarly, in another place, the nāḍīs are mentioned first, and then it is said, Then he becomes one with them, when he being asleep sees no dreams; then he becomes one with prāṇa only, Kau Up ,

analyzed: tathā anyatra yaḥ eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ tasmin śete bṛ iti
translated: Similarly, in another place, it is said, He dwells in that ether which is within the heart, Bṛ Up , , 0

original: tathānyatra 'satā somya tadā saṃpanno bhavati svamapīto bhavati' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: tathā anyatra satā somya tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati svam api itas bhavati chā iti
translated: Similarly, in another place, it is said, Then, my dear, he becomes united with the True, he goes to his own Self, Ch Up , , 0

original: 'prājñenātmanā saṃpariśvakto na bāhyaṃ kiñcana veda nāntaram' bṛ / / / iti ca /🔽tatra saṃśayaḥ kimetāni nāḍyādīni parasparanirapekṣāṇi bhinnāni suṣuptisthānānyāhosvitparasparāpekṣayaikaṃ suṣuptisthānamasti /
analyzed: prājñena ātmanā saṃpariśvaktaḥ na bāhyam kiñcana veda na antaram iti ca  tatra saṃśayaḥ kim etāni nāḍī ādīni paraspara nirapekṣāṇi bhinnāni suṣupti sthānāni āhosvit paraspara apekṣayā ekam suṣupti sthānam asti
translated: And, wrapped in the intelligent Self, he knows nothing within nor without, Bṛ Up , , 0🔽Now there arises the question whether the nāḍīs, &c, are separate places of deep sleep, independent of one another, or whether there is only one place of deep sleep, the nāḍīs, &c, being dependent on one another

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam bhinnāni iti
translated: What is the prima facie view? That they are separate places of deep sleep

analyzed: kutas eka artha tvāt
translated: Why? Because they have each a separate purpose

analyzed: nahi eka arthānīm kvacid paraspara apekṣa tvam dṛśyate vrīhi yava ādīnām
translated: For we do not see that things which have each a separate purpose are dependent on one another, as for instance rice and barley

original: nāḍyādīnāṃ tvekārthatā suṣuptau dṛśyate 'nāḍīśu sṛpto bhavati' chā / / /
analyzed: nāḍī ādīnām tu eka artha tā suṣuptau dṛśyate sṛptaḥ bhavati
translated: In deep sleep, however, the equality of purpose of the nāḍīs, etc. is seen: ‘He becomes merged in the nāḍīs’ (Ch. Up. 8.7.2).🔽🔽

analyzed: purītati śete
translated: But in the case of the nāḍīs, etc., the same object is seen in deep sleep, as the text says, ‘He has entered the nāḍīs’ (Ch. U. 8. 6. 1), and ‘He sleeps in the heart’ (Ch. U. 8. 7. 1).

original: bṛ / / / iti ca tatra tatra saptamīnirdeśasya tulyatvāt /
analyzed: iti ca tatra tatra saptamī nirdeśasya tulya tvāt
translated: The locative ending in the above passages is the same.

original: nanu naivaṃ sati saptamīnirdeśo dṛśyate 'satā somya tadā saṃpanno bhavati' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: nanu na evam sati saptamī nirdeśaḥ dṛśyate satā somya tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati chā iti
translated: But in the passage, ‘Then, my dear, he becomes united with the True’ (Ch. U. 6. 8. 1), the locative ending is not found.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a defect.

analyzed: tatra api saptamī arthasya gamyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the sense of the locative is understood there also.

original: vākyaśeṣo hi tatrāyatanaiṣī jīvaḥ sadupasarpatītyāha 'anyatrāyatanamalabdhvā prāṇamevopaśrayate' chā / / /
analyzed: vākya śeṣaḥ hi tatra āyatana eṣī jīvaḥ sat upasarpati iti āha anyatra āyatanam a labdhvā prāṇam eva upaśrayate chā
translated: For the text goes on to say that the individual soul, seeking a resting place, approaches the True, ‘Not finding a resting place elsewhere, it rests in the prāṇa’ (Ch. U. 8. 7. 1).

original: iti prāṇaśabdena tatra prakṛtasya sata upādanāt /
analyzed: iti prāṇa śabdena tatra prakṛtasya sataḥ upādanāt
translated: Here the word prāṇa refers to the True which is the subject of the context.

analyzed: āyatanam ca saptamī arthaḥ
translated: And a resting place is the sense of the locative.

original: saptamīnirdeśo 'pi tatra vākyaśeṣe dṛśyate 'sati saṃpadya na viduḥ sati saṃpadyāmahe' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: saptamī nirdeśaḥ u pi tatra vākya śeṣe dṛśyate sati saṃpadya na viduḥ sati saṃpadyāmahe chā iti
translated: And the locative ending is found in the continuation of the passage, ‘When united with the True, they do not know that they are united with the True’ (Ch. U. 6. 8. 1).

original: sarvatra ca viśeṣavijñānoparamalakṣaṇaṃ suṣuptaṃ na viśiṣyate /
analyzed: sarvatra ca viśeṣa vijñāna uparama lakṣaṇam suṣuptam na viśiṣyate
translated: And in all these passages, deep sleep is not distinguished as having the characteristic of the cessation of the knowledge of particular things.

analyzed: tasmāt eka ārta tvāt nāḍī ādīnām vikalpena kadācid kiñcid sthānam svāpāya upasarpati iti
translated: Therefore, because of their being for one purpose, the nāḍīs, etc., are not to be resorted to as places of sleep by turns.

original: evaṃ prāpte pratipādyate tadabhāvo nāḍīṣvātni ceti /
analyzed: evam prāpte pratipādyate tad abhāvaḥ nāḍīṣu ātni ca iti
translated: When this is the case, it is taught that that absence is in the nāḍīs and in the Self.

original: tadabhāva iti tasya prakṛtasya svapnadarśanasyābhāvaḥ suṣuptamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ iti tasya prakṛtasya svapna darśanasya abhāvaḥ suṣuptam iti arthaḥ
translated: The absence of that means the absence of the seeing of dreams that was the topic, and the meaning is deep sleep.

original: nāḍīṣvātmani ceti samuccayenaitāni nāḍyādīni svāpāyopaiti na vikalpenetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: nāḍīṣu ātmani ca iti samuccayena etāni nāḍī ādīni svāpāya upaiti na vikalpena iti arthaḥ
translated: In the nāḍīs and in the Self means that these nāḍīs, etc., are to be resorted to for sleep by combination, not by turns. The meaning is that.

analyzed: kutas tad śruteḥ
translated: Why? Because of the Vedic text.

original: tathāhi sarveṣāmeva nāḍyādīnāṃ tatra tatra suṣuptisthānatvaṃ śrūyate tacca masuccaye saṃgṛhītaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tathā hi sarveṣām eva nāḍī ādīnām tatra tatra suṣupti sthāna tvam śrūyate tat ca masuccaye saṃgṛhītam bhavati
translated: For thus the fact that all these nāḍīs, etc. are the places of deep sleep is heard here and there, and that is included in combination.

analyzed: vikalpe hi eṣām pakṣe bādhaḥ syāt
translated: For if there were an option, there would be contradiction in some cases.

analyzed: nanu eka artha tvāt vikalpaḥ nāḍī ādīnām vrīhi yava ādi vat uktam
translated: But it has been said that there is an option among the nāḍīs, etc., because they have one purpose, like rice and barley.

analyzed: na iti ucyate  nahi eka vibhakti nirdeśa mātreṇa eka artha tvam vikalpaḥ ca āpatati
translated: It is said that this is not so.🔽For oneness of purpose and option do not follow merely from the indication of one case ending.

analyzed: nānā artha tva samuccayayoḥ api eka vibhakti nirdeśa darśanā prāsāde śete paryaṅ ke śete iti evamādiṣu
translated: For oneness of purpose and combination are seen to be indicated by one case ending, as in he sleeps in the palace and he sleeps on the couch and so on.

original: tathehāpi nāḍīṣu purītati brahmaṇi ca svapitītyetadupapadyate samuccayaḥ /
analyzed: tathā iha api nāḍīṣu purītati brahmaṇi ca svapiti iti etat upapadyate samuccayaḥ
translated: In the same way, here also, the combination of the soul sleeping in the nāḍīs, in the heart, and in Brahman is possible.

original: tathāca śrutiḥ 'tāsu tadā bhavati yadā suptaḥ svapnaṃ na kañcana paśyatyathāsminprāṇa evaikadhā bhavati' kauṣī / /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ tāsu tadā bhavati yadā suptaḥ svapnam na kañcana paśyati atha asmin prāṇaḥ eva ekadhā bhavati kauṣī
translated: And thus the Śruti declares the combination of the nāḍīs and the prāṇa in deep sleep: ‘Then he becomes one with the prāṇa alone’ (Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad 3.1).

original: iti samuccayaṃ nāḍīnāṃ prāṇasya ca suṣuptau śrāvayatyekavākyopādānāt /
analyzed: iti samuccayam nāḍīnām prāṇasya ca suṣuptau śrāvayati eka vākya upādānāt
translated: By being mentioned in the same sentence, it declares the combination of the nāḍīs and the prāṇa in deep sleep.

original: prāṇasya ca brahmatvaṃ samadhigatam 'prāṇastathānugamāt' bra /sū / / / ityatra /
analyzed: prāṇasya ca brahmatvam samadhigatam prāṇaḥ tathā anugamāt brasū iti atra
translated: And it has been established that the prāṇa is Brahman (in Sūtra 1.1.12).

original: yatrāpi nirapekṣā iva nāḍīḥ suptisthānatvena śrāvayati 'āsu tadā nāḍīṣu sṛpto bhavati' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: yatra api nirapekṣāḥ iva nāḍīḥ supti sthāna tvena śrāvayati āsu tadā nāḍīṣu sṛptaḥ bhavati chā iti
translated: Even where the nāḍīs are declared to be the place of deep sleep, as if independently of Brahman: ‘Then he has entered into those nāḍīs’ (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.6.3),

original: tatrāpi pradeśāntaraprasiddhasya brahmaṇo 'pratiṣedhānnāḍīdvāreṇaiva brahmaṇyevāvatiṣṭhata iti pratīyate /
analyzed: tatra api pradeśa antara prasiddhasya brahmaṇaḥ pratiṣedhāt nāḍī dvāreṇa eva brahmaṇi eva avatiṣṭhate iti pratīyate
translated: even there, because Brahman, well known from other texts, is not denied, it is understood that he abides in Brahman itself through the nāḍīs.

analyzed: na ca evam api nāḍīṣu saptamī virudhyate
translated: And even so, the locative case in the nāḍīs is not contradicted.

analyzed: nāḍī dvārā api brahma upasarpan sṛptaḥ eva nāḍīṣu bhavati
translated: For even though he approaches Brahman through the nāḍīs, he is still ‘entered into the nāḍīs’.

original: yo hi gaṅgayā sāgaraṃ gacchati gata eva sa gaṅgāyāṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yaḥ hi gaṅgayā sāgaram gacchati gataḥ eva sa gaṅgāyām bhavati
translated: For he who goes to the ocean by the Ganges is indeed gone in the Ganges.

analyzed: api ca atra raśmī nāḍī dvāra ātmakasya brahmaloka mārgasya vivakṣita tvāt nāḍī stuti artham sṛpti saṃkīrtanam
translated: Moreover, since here the path to the world of Brahman, consisting of rays, channels, and doors, is intended, the mention of entering is for the praise of the channels.

analyzed: nāḍīṣu sṛptaḥ bhavati chā
translated: He enters into the channels (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.6.6).

original: ityuktvā 'taṃ na kaścana pāpmā spṛśati' chā / / /
analyzed: iti uktvā tam na kaścana pāpmā spṛśati chā
translated: Having said this, by saying no impurity touches him (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.6.7),

analyzed: iti bruvan nāḍīḥ praśaṃsati
translated: he praises the channels.

original: bravīti ca pāpmasparśābhāve hetum tejasā nāḍīgatena pittākhyenābhivyāptakaraṇo na bāhyānviṣayānīkṣata ityarthaḥ /🔽athavā tejaseti brahmaṇa evāyaṃ nirdeśaḥ /
analyzed: bravīti ca pāpma sparśa abhāve hetum tejasā nāḍī gatena pitta ākhyena abhivyāpta karaṇaḥ na bāhyān viṣayān īkṣate iti arthaḥ  athavā tejasā iti brahmaṇaḥ eva ayam nirdeśaḥ
translated: And he states the reason for the absence of contact with impurity: the meaning is that one whose organs are pervaded by bile called 'heat' present in the channels does not look at external objects.🔽Or, 'by heat' is a reference to Brahman itself.

analyzed: śruti antare brahma eva tejaḥ eva bṛ
translated: In another scripture, 'Brahman itself is heat' (Brhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.22).

analyzed: iti tejaḥ śabdasya brahmaṇi pratyukta tvāt
translated: Since the word 'heat' is well-known to refer to Brahman.

original: brahmaṇā hi tadā saṃpanno bhavati nāḍīdvāreṇātastaṃ na kaścana pāpmāna spṛśatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: brahmaṇā hi tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati nāḍī dvāreṇa atas tam na kaścana pāpmā spṛśati iti arthaḥ
translated: For at that time one becomes endowed with Brahman through the channels. Therefore, no impurity touches him. The meaning is that.

original: brahmasamapattiśca pāpmasparśābhāve hetuḥ samadhigataḥ 'sarve pāpmāno 'ta nivartante 'pahatapāpmā hyeṣa brahmalokaḥ' chā /
analyzed: brahma samapattiḥ ca pāpma sparśa abhāve hetuḥ samadhigataḥ sarve nivartante pahata pāpmā hi eṣa brahma lokaḥ chā
translated: And the attainment of Brahman is understood to be the reason for the absence of contact with impurity, from statements such as all impurities turn away from him, for this world of Brahman is free from impurity (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.1.2).

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: From such statements in the scriptures.

original: evañca sati pradeśāntaraprasiddhena brahmaṇā suṣuptisthānenānugato nāḍīnāṃ samuccayaḥ samadhigato bhavati /🔽tathā purītato 'pi brahmaprakriyāyāṃ saṃkīrtanāttadanuguṇameva suptisthānatvaṃ vijñāyate 'ya eṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśastasmiñchete' bṛ / / /
analyzed: evañca sati pradeśa antara prasiddhena brahmaṇā suṣupti sthānena anugataḥ nāḍīnām samuccayaḥ samadhigataḥ bhavati  tathā brahma prakriyāyām saṃkīrtanāt tad anuguṇam eva supti sthāna tvam vijñāyate yaḥ eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ tasmin śete bṛ
translated: And if this is so, then the combination of the nāḍīs is understood to be connected with Brahman, which is well known in other sections, as the place of deep sleep.🔽Similarly, the fact that the purītat is mentioned in the description of Brahman shows that it is the place of deep sleep in accordance with that. It is said: He lies in the space within the heart.

original: iti hṛdayākāśe suptisthāne prakṛta idamucyate 'purītati śete' bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: iti hṛdaya ākāśe supti sthāne prakṛte idam ucyate purītati śete iti
translated: This is said about the space within the heart, which is the place of deep sleep: He lies in the purītat.

analyzed: purītat iti hṛdaya pariveṣṭanam ucyate
translated: The purītat is said to be the covering of the heart.

original: tadantarvartinyāpi hṛdayākāśe śayānaḥ śakyate purītati śeta iti vaktum /
analyzed: tad antarvartinyā api hṛdaya ākāśe śayānaḥ śakyate purītati śete iti vaktum
translated: One who lies in the space within the heart can be said to lie in the purītat.

original: prākāraparikṣipte 'pi pure vartamānaḥ prākāre vartata ityucyate /
analyzed: prākāra parikṣipte pi pure vartamānaḥ prākāre vartate iti ucyate
translated: One who is in a city surrounded by a wall is said to be in the wall.

original: hṛdayākāśasya ca brahmatvaṃ samadhigatam 'dahara uttarebhyaḥ' bra /sū / / / ityatra /🔽tathā nāḍīpurītatsamuccayo 'pi 'tābhiḥ pratyavasṛtya purītati śete' bṛ / / /
analyzed: hṛdaya ākāśasya ca brahmatvam samadhigatam dahara uttarebhyaḥ brasū iti atra  tathā nāḍī purītat samuccayaḥ pi tābhiḥ pratyavasṛtya purītati śete
translated: And it has been understood that the space within the heart is Brahman, in the section The small one is Brahman, because of the later passages.

analyzed: iti eka vākya upādānāt avagamyate
translated: Similarly, the combination of the nāḍīs and the purītat is understood from the inclusion in the same sentence: Having gone out by them, he lies in the purītat.

analyzed: sat prājñayoḥ ca prasiddham eva brahmatvam
translated: And the Sat and the Kshetrajna are well known to be Brahman.

original: evametāsu śrutiṣu trīṇyeva suṣuptisthānāni saṃkīrtitāni nāḍyaḥ purītadbrahma ceti /
analyzed: evam etāsu śrutiṣu trīṇi eva suṣupti sthānāni saṃkīrtitāni nāḍyaḥ purītat brahma ca iti
translated: Thus, in these scriptural passages, only three places of deep sleep are mentioned: the arteries, the heart, and Brahman.

analyzed: tatra api dvāra mātram nāḍyaḥ purītat ca
translated: And even there, the arteries and the heart are merely the door.

analyzed: brahma eva tu ekam suṣupti sthānam
translated: But Brahman alone is the place of deep sleep.

original: apica nāḍyaḥ purītadvā jīvasyopādhyādhāra eva bhavati tatrāsya karaṇāni vartanta iti /
analyzed: apica nāḍyaḥ purītat vā jīvasya upādhi ādhāraḥ eva bhavati tatra asya karaṇāni vartante iti
translated: Moreover, the arteries and the heart are merely the support of the limiting adjuncts of the individual soul, since the sense organs function there.

analyzed: nahi upādhi saṃbandham antareṇa svatas eva jīvasya ādhāraḥ kaścid saṃbhavati
translated: For, apart from the connection with the limiting adjuncts, no inherent support of the individual soul is possible.

analyzed: brahma a vyatirekeṇa sva mahima pratiṣṭhita tvāt
translated: Because it is established in its own glory without distinction from Brahman.

original: brahmādhāratvamapyasya suṣupte naivādhārādheyabhedābhiprāyeṇocyate kathaṃ tarhi tādātmyābhiprāyeṇa /
analyzed: brahma ādhāra tvam api asya suṣupte na eva ādhāra ādheya bheda abhiprāyeṇa ucyate katham tarhi tādātmya abhiprāyeṇa
translated: And even its being supported by Brahman is not stated with the intention of a difference between the supported and the supporter in deep sleep. Then how? With the intention of identity.

original: yata āha 'satā somya tadā saṃpanno bhavati svamapīto bhavati' chā / / / iti /🔽svaśabdenātmābhilapyate /
analyzed: yatas āha satā somya tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati svam api itas bhavati chā iti  sva śabdena ātmā abhilapyate
translated: Because it is said: Then, my dear, he becomes united with the existent. He becomes merged in his own self.🔽By the word his own, the self is referred to.

analyzed: sva rūpam āpannaḥ suptaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in deep sleep he attains his own nature.

original: apica na kadācijjīvasya brahmaṇā saṃpattirnāsti svarūpasyānapāyitvāt /
analyzed: apica na kadācid jīvasya brahmaṇā saṃpattiḥ na asti svarūpasya anapāyi tvāt
translated: Moreover, the soul is never without union with Brahman, because its own nature is not subject to destruction.

analyzed: svapna jāgaritayoḥ tu upādhi saṃparka vaśāt para rūpa āpattim iva apekṣya tad upaśamāt suṣupteḥ sva rūpa āpattiḥ vakṣyate
translated: In the states of waking and dreaming, however, it is as if the soul assumed the nature of something else, through its contact with limiting adjuncts; and it is said that in deep sleep, when that contact has ceased, the soul assumes its own nature.

original: ataśca suptāvasthāyāṃ kadācitsatāṃ saṃpadyate kadācinna saṃpadyata ityayuktam /
analyzed: atas ca supta avasthāyām kadācid satām saṃpadyate kadācid na saṃpadyate iti ayuktam
translated: And hence it is improper to say that in the state of deep sleep sometimes the soul is in union with Brahman and sometimes it is not.

original: apica sthānavikalpābhyupagame 'pi viśeṣavijñānopalakṣaṇaṃ tāvatsuṣuptaṃ na kvacidviśiṣyate /🔽tatra sati saṃpannastāvattadekatvānna vijānatīti yuktam /
analyzed: api ca sthāna vikalpa abhyupagame viśeṣa vijñāna upalakṣaṇam tāvat suṣuptam na kvacid viśiṣyate  tatra sati saṃpannaḥ tāvat tad eka tvāt na vijānati iti yuktam
translated: Moreover, even if we admit that there is a difference of place, still the definition of deep sleep as the non-perception of any difference is not fulfilled anywhere.🔽And it is proper to say that the soul, when in deep sleep, being in union with Brahman, does not perceive any difference,

original: 'ttakena kaṃ vijānīyāt' bṛ / / / iti śruteḥ /🔽nāḍīṣu puratīti ca śayānasya na kiñcidavijñāne kāraṇaṃ śakyaṃ vijñātuṃ /
analyzed: ttakena kam vijānīyāt iti śruteḥ  nāḍīṣu ca śayānasya na kiñcid avijñāne kāraṇam śakyam vijñātum
translated: because of the Vedic text, ‘By what, indeed, could one know the knower?’ (Br. 3.4.1).🔽And there is no reason to be found for the non-perception of the soul lying in the arteries, as stated in the text, ‘lying in the arteries, in the navel’ (Ch. 8.6.1).

original: bhedaviṣayatvāt 'yatra vā anyadiva syāttatrānyo 'nyatpaśyet' bṛ / / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: bheda viṣaya tvāt yatra vai anyat iva syāt tatra anyaḥ nyat paśyet iti śruteḥ
translated: For the soul, whose object is difference, the cause of non-perception is too remote, etc.

analyzed: nanu bheda viṣayasya api ati dūra ādi kāraṇam avijñāne syāt
translated: But is it not true that even when the object is difference, the cause of non-perception is too remote, etc.?

analyzed: bāḍham
translated: Yes, it is true.

analyzed: evam syāt yadi jīvaḥ svatas paricchinnaḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: This would be so if the individual soul were admitted to be limited by itself.

original: yathā viṣṇumitraḥ pravāsī svagṛhaṃ na paśyati /
analyzed: yathā viṣṇu mitraḥ pravāsī sva gṛham na paśyati
translated: Just as Viṣṇumitra, when abroad, does not see his own house.

analyzed: na tu jīvasya upādhi vyatirekeṇa paricchedaḥ vidyate
translated: But there is no limitation of the individual soul apart from the limiting adjuncts.

original: upādhigatamevātidūrādikāraṇamavijñāna iti yadyucyeta tathāpyupādherupaśāntatvātsatyeva saṃpanno na vijānatīti yuktam /
analyzed: upādhi gatam eva ati dūra ādi kāraṇam avijñānaḥ iti yadi ucyeta tathā api upādheḥ upaśānta tvāt sati eva saṃpannaḥ na vijānati iti yuktam
translated: If it be said that the cause of non-cognition lies in the limiting adjuncts themselves, such as remoteness, etc., even so, it is proper to say that he does not know when the limiting adjuncts are at rest, while he is really existent.

analyzed: na ca vayam iha tulya vat nāḍī ādi samuccayam pratipādayāmaḥ
translated: And here we do not teach the combination of the nāḍīs, etc., as equal [in importance].

original: nahi nāḍyaḥ suptisthānaṃ purītadvetyanena vijñānena kiñcitprayojanamasti /🔽nahyetadvijñānapratibaddhaṃ kiñcitphalaṃ śrūyate /
analyzed: nahi nāḍyaḥ supti sthānam purītat vā iti anena vijñānena kiñcid prayojanam asti  nahi etat vijñāna pratibaddham kiñcid phalam śrūyate
translated: For there is no purpose in the knowledge that the nāḍīs and the heart are the places of sleep.🔽For no result is heard to be connected with this knowledge.

analyzed: na api etat vijñānam phalavataḥ kasyacid aṅgam upadiśyate
translated: Nor is this knowledge taught as a part of anything fruitful.

analyzed: brahma tu anapāyi supti sthānam iti etat pratipādayāmaḥ
translated: But we teach that Brahman alone, which is free from destruction, is the place of sleep.

original: tena tu vijñānena prayojanamasti jīvasya brahmātmatvāvadhāraṇaṃ svapnajāgaritavyavahāravimuktatvāvadhāraṇaṃ ca /
analyzed: tena tu vijñānena prayojanam asti jīvasya brahma ātma tva avadhāraṇam svapna jāgarita vyavahāra vimukta tva avadhāraṇam ca
translated: But there is a purpose in the knowledge of that [Brahman], namely, the determination of the individual soul as having Brahman for its Self, and the determination of being free from the experiences of waking and dreaming.

analyzed: tasmāt ātmā eva supti sthānam
translated: Therefore, the Self alone is the place of sleep.

analyzed: evam bāhya karaṇa uparame sati manaḥ vāsanā uddīpita avidyā vilāsa ātmakam svapnam ātmanaḥ sākṣiṇaḥ
translated: Thus, when the external organs cease to function, the soul, which is the witness of dreams, experiences dreams that are the manifestation of ignorance kindled by mental impressions.

analyzed: svayañjyotiṣṭvā artham vicārya pratiyogi anuyogi bhāva saṅgatyā svapna avastha manaḥ laya ātmikām
translated: For the sake of establishing the soul's self-luminosity, the author analyzes the state of deep sleep, which is characterized by the dissolution of the mind in dreams, in terms of the relationship between the object and the subject.

analyzed: suṣuptim vicārayati tad abhāvaḥ nāḍīṣu tad śuteḥ ātmani ca
translated: The absence of that [dream state] is in the subtle channels and in the Self.

analyzed: tat etat svapanam yathā syāt tathā
translated: This sleeping state is as it is.

original: yatra kāle suptaḥ suṣuptaḥ samasto nirastabāhyakaraṇo manolayātsamyakprasaṅga ityarthaḥ /🔽svāpe nāḍīsthānamuktvā nāḍīpurītatornāḍīparamātmanośca samuccayaśrutī āhaanyatreti /🔽paramātmamātraśrutīrāhatathānyatretyādinā /
analyzed: yatra kāle suptaḥ suṣuptaḥ samastaḥ nirasta bāhya karaṇaḥ manaḥ layāt samyak prasaṅgaḥ iti arthaḥ  svāpe nāḍī sthānam uktvā nāḍī purītatoḥ nāḍī paramātmanoḥ ca samuccaya śrutī āha anyatra iti  paramātma mātra śrutīḥ āha tathā anyatra ityādinā
translated: At the time when one is deeply asleep, completely absorbed, with the external organs withdrawn due to the dissolution of the mind - this is the meaning of 'completely absorbed'.🔽Having mentioned the subtle channels as the location in sleep, the author states the scriptural passages that mention both the subtle channels and the city of Brahman, and the subtle channels and the supreme Self, in the phrase 'in another place'.🔽He states the scriptural passages that mention only the supreme Self in the phrase 'and in another place' and so on.

analyzed: nāḍī purīta brahmasu saptamī śruteḥ samuccaya śruteḥ ca saṃśayam āha tatra iti
translated: Due to the mention of the locative case in relation to the subtle channels, the city of Brahman, and Brahman, and due to the scriptural passages that mention the combination [of these locations], he raises a doubt in the phrase 'there' and so on.
In the prima facie view, due to the option of locations, there is no determination of the oneness of the individual soul with Brahman.

original: siddhānte nāḍībhiḥ purītataṃ gatvāntarhṛdi brahmaṇyeva śeta iti samuccyāt tannirṇaya iti vivekaḥ /
analyzed: siddhānte nāḍībhiḥ purītatam gatvā antar hṛdi brahmaṇi eva śete iti samuccyāt tad nirṇayaḥ iti vivekaḥ
translated: In the conclusion, by combining [the locations] in the statement 'going to the city of Brahman through the subtle channels, one lies down in Brahman within the heart', there is a determination of that [oneness], is the distinction.

original: ekapuroḍāśārthatvaṃ vrīhiyavayordṛṣṭaṃ nāḍyādīnāmekasmin svāparūpārthe nirapekṣasthānatvaṃ tu kuta ityata āhanāḍyādīnāṃ ceti /
analyzed: eka puroḍāśa arthatvam vrīhi yavayoḥ dṛṣṭam nāḍī ādīnām ekasmin svāpa rūpa arthe nirapekṣa sthānatvam tu kutas iti atas āha nāḍī ādīnām ca iti
translated: The purpose of the rice and barley is seen to be one cake. But how can the nāḍīs, etc. have the nature of being independent supports in the one form of sleep? To this he says: And of the nāḍīs, etc.

analyzed: sati brahmaṇi tṛtīya śruteḥ na saptamī iti śaṅkā arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the doubt is: When Brahman exists, the third case ending is not for the meaning of the locative.

original: āyatanaśabdātsaptamyartha ādhāratvaṃ gamyata ityāhanaiṣa doṣa iti /
analyzed: āyatana śabdāt saptamī arthe ādhāra tvam gamyate iti āha na eṣa doṣaḥ iti
translated: From the word āyatana, the meaning of the locative case, which is the nature of being a support, is understood. He says: This is not a fault.

original: anyatrāvasthādvaye śrānto jīvo viśrāntisthānaṃ prāṇākhyaṃ sadbrahmopasarpati suṣuptāvityarthaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra avasthā dvaye śrāntaḥ jīvaḥ viśrānti sthānam prāṇa ākhyam sat brahma upasarpati suṣuptau iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: The soul, tired in the other two states, approaches the true Brahman called prāṇa, which is the place of rest, in deep sleep.

original: saptamīśrutyā nirapekṣādhāratvabhānādvikalpa āstheyaḥ kadācitsamuccityāpi nāḍyādīnāṃ sthānatvamiti na samuccayaśrutivirodha iti pūrvapakṣārthaḥ
analyzed: saptamī śrutyā nirapekṣa ādhāra tva bhānāt vikalpaḥ āstheyaḥ kadācid samuccitya api nāḍī ādīnām sthāna tvam iti na samuccaya śruti virodhaḥ iti pūrvapakṣa arthaḥ
translated: The prima facie view is: Since the locative case ending indicates the nature of being an independent support, the option should be accepted. Sometimes the nāḍīs, etc. may be the place collectively, so there is no contradiction with the locative case ending in the Upaniṣads.

analyzed: siddhāntayati evam prāptaḥ iti
translated: The conclusion is stated: Thus it is obtained.

analyzed: sūtre cakāraḥ purītat samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: In the sūtra, the word ca is for the purpose of including the purītat.

original: yadā nāḍyaḥ suṣuptisthānaṃ tadā purītatsthānaṃ na bhavatīti śrutasthānatvasya pakṣe bādhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadā nāḍyaḥ suṣupti sthānam tadā purītat sthānam na bhavati iti śruta sthāna tvasya pakṣe bādhaḥ syāt
translated: When the nāḍīs are the place of deep sleep, then the purītat is not the place. There would be contradiction of the position stated in the Upaniṣads.

analyzed: sa na yuktaḥ iti āha vikalpe hi eṣām iti
translated: That is not proper. He says: For in the option of these,

analyzed: vrīhi yavayoḥ tu agatyā vikalpaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The sense is that in the case of rice and barley, there is an option due to the absence of any other means.

analyzed: yat tu saptamī śrutyā nāḍī ādīnām eka phalaka tvam iti
translated: As for the argument that the nāḍīs, etc. have the same result due to the genitive case ending,

analyzed: tat na iti āha na hi ekā iti
translated: that is not so, he says.

analyzed: prāsādasya paryaṅka dhāraṇam arthaḥ
translated: The purpose of the palace is to hold the couch.

analyzed: paryaṅkasya tu śayanam iti phala bhede pi eka vibhaktiḥ dṛśyate
translated: But the couch is for lying down. Even with a difference in results, a single case ending is seen.

analyzed: vyavadhāna avyavadhānābhyām śayana sādhana tvāt samuccayaḥ ca
translated: And there is combination due to being the means of lying down through the absence or presence of an obstruction.

original: tathehāpi nāḍīpurītatorjīvasya saṃcāradvārā brahmaṇyeva suptiriti samuccaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā iha api nāḍī purītatoḥ jīvasya saṃcāra dvārā brahmaṇi eva suptiḥ iti samuccayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Similarly here also, the combination is that the nāḍīs and the heart are the means of the soul's going to Brahman itself while sleeping. This is the meaning.

original: nāḍīnāṃ prāṇasya ca ekena vākyenopādānānmithaḥ samuccaya ityāhaekavākyeti /
analyzed: nāḍīnām prāṇasya ca ekena vākyena upādānāt mithas samuccayaḥ iti āha eka vākya iti
translated: Due to the nāḍīs and the prāṇa being mentioned by a single sentence, there is a mutual combination. He says this with in a single sentence.

original: ādhāratvamātraṃ saptamyartho na nirapekṣatvamato na samuccayasya saptamyā bādha ityāhana caivamapīti /
analyzed: ādhāra tva mātram saptamī arthaḥ na nirapekṣa tvam atas na samuccayasya saptamyāḥ bādhaḥ iti āha na ca evam api iti
translated: The genitive case ending means mere basis, not independence. Therefore, there is no contradiction of the combination by the genitive case ending. He says And even so.

analyzed: samuccaye pi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is even in the combination.

original: atra nāḍīśrutau nāḍīṣu bhoktuḥ suptirna vivakṣitā raśmisaṃbandhanāḍīrūpamārgastutyarthatvādityāhaapiceti /
analyzed: atra nāḍī śrutau nāḍīṣu bhoktuḥ suptiḥ na vivakṣitā raśmi saṃbandha nāḍī rūpa mārga stuti artha tvāt iti āha api ca iti
translated: Here, in the nāḍī passage, the sleep of the enjoyer in the nāḍīs is not intended, because it is for the purpose of praising the path in the form of the nāḍīs connected with the rays. He says Moreover.

analyzed: pittena viṣaya īkṣaṇa abhāve sukha duḥkhayoḥ abhāvāt tad hetu dharma ātmaka pāpma asparśaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when there is no seeing of objects due to bile, there is no happiness or sorrow, so there is no contact with the impurity which is the cause of those.

analyzed: apahata pāpma brahma saṃpattyā vā pāpma asparśaḥ iti āha athavā iti
translated: Or, the meaning is that there is no contact with impurity due to the attainment of Brahman which is devoid of impurity. He says or [in the text].

analyzed: asmin vyākhyāne lābham āha evam ca sati iti
translated: In this explanation, he states the benefit: Thus, in this case,

original: 'tāsu tadā bhavatyathāsmin prāṇa evaikadhā bhavati'iti śruteḥ samuccaya āśrito bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tāsu tadā bhavati atha asmin prāṇaḥ eva ekadhā bhavati iti śruteḥ samuccayaḥ āśritaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that the combination [of the vital breaths] is resorted to, according to the Vedic text At that time, he becomes one with those, then in this [world], he becomes one with the vital breath alone.

analyzed: nāḍī brahmaṇoḥ guṇa pradhāna bhāvena suptau samuccaya vat purītat brahmaṇoḥ api iti āha tathā ityādinā
translated: Just as there is a combination of the vital breaths and Brahman as subordinate and primary respectively in sleep, so also there is a combination of the heart and Brahman, he says thus and so on.

original: ākāśe brahmaṇi śeta ityupakramya tābhiḥ pratyavasṛpya purītamiti śeta ityuktaṃ /
analyzed: ākāśe brahmaṇi śete iti upakramya tābhiḥ pratyavasṛpya purītam iti śete iti uktam
translated: Beginning with he lies in the Brahman which is space, it is said having entered them through the vital breaths, he lies in the heart.

original: tathāca nāḍīdvārā purītataṃ gatvā brahmaṇi śeta iti samuccayaḥ siddha ityāhatathā nāḍīti /
analyzed: tathā ca nāḍī dvārā purītatam gatvā brahmaṇi śete iti samuccayaḥ siddhaḥ iti āha tathā nāḍī iti
translated: And thus, the combination is established that he lies in Brahman having gone to the heart through the vital breaths, he says thus, the vital breaths and so on.

original: satā saṃpanno bhavati prājñena saṃpariṣvakta iti satprājñayoḥ śruteḥ pañca suptisthānānītyata āhasatprājñayoriti /
analyzed: satā saṃpannaḥ bhavati prājñena saṃpariṣvaktaḥ iti sat prājñayoḥ śruteḥ pañca supti sthānāni iti atas āha sat prājñayoḥ iti
translated: There are five states of sleep, according to the Vedic text he becomes united with the existent, embraced by the wise one. Therefore he says the existent and the wise one and so on.

analyzed: kiñca prakṛta darśa ādi sādhana eka puroḍāśa niṣpattau mithas napekṣa tayā samartha tvāt yuktaḥ vrīhi yavayoḥ vikalpaḥ
translated: Moreover, in the production of the single cake as the result of the primary means such as the Darsha sacrifice, since they are capable of being independent of each other, the option between rice and barley is proper.

original: nāḍyādīnāṃ tu brahmanirapekṣatayā suṣuptajīvādhāratvāsāmarthyānna vikalpa ityāhaapica nāḍya iti /
analyzed: nāḍī ādīnām tu brahma nirapekṣa tayā suṣupta jīva ādhāra tva asāmarthyāt na vikalpaḥ iti āha api ca nāḍyaḥ iti
translated: But since the nāḍīs, etc. are incapable of being the support of the individual soul in deep sleep independently of Brahman, there is no option. Thus he says: Moreover, as regards the nāḍīs, etc.

analyzed: upādhi liṅga āśraya nāḍī purītatoḥ upahita jīva āśraya tvam paramparayā vācyam
translated: The support of the individual soul qualified by the limiting adjuncts should be stated to be the nāḍīs and the heart, which are the supports of the limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: tat api suṣuptau na saṃbhavati
translated: That also is not possible in deep sleep.

analyzed: upādhi layāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of the dissolution of the limiting adjuncts.

original: nanu brahmāpi jīvasya na mukhyaṃ sthānaṃ abhedādityata āhabrahmādhāratvamiti /🔽jīvasya brahmaṇyabhedenāvasthānaṃ nāḍīpurītatostu līnopādherjīvasya sthitireva na saṃbhavatītyekārthasāmarthyābhāvānna vikalpa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: nanu brahma api jīvasya na mukhyam sthānam abhedāt iti atas āha brahma ādhāra tvam iti  jīvasya brahmaṇi abhedena avasthānam nāḍī purītatoḥ tu līna upādheḥ jīvasya sthitiḥ eva na saṃbhavati iti ekārtha sāmarthya abhāvāt na vikalpaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But Brahman also is not the primary abode of the individual soul, because of non-difference. To this he says: The state of being the support of Brahman, etc.🔽The state of the individual soul in Brahman by non-difference, but the state of the individual soul whose limiting adjuncts are dissolved in the nāḍīs and the heart is not possible at all. Thus, due to the absence of the capacity for the same purpose, there is no option. This is the meaning.

original: suṣuptau jīvasya bhedakopādhilayāccautsargikabrahmābhedasya vikalpo na yukta ityāhaapiceti /
analyzed: suṣuptau jīvasya bhedaka upādhi layāt ca autsargika brahma abhedasya vikalpaḥ na yuktaḥ iti āha api ca iti
translated: And because of the dissolution of the limiting adjuncts that distinguish the individual soul in deep sleep, the option of the natural non-difference from Brahman is not proper. Thus he says: Moreover, etc.

original: kiñca nāḍyādīnāmanyatamasthāne kvacitsuptivādināpi suṣuptaṃ na viśiṣyata iti vaktavyaṃ /
analyzed: kiñca nāḍī ādīnām anyatama sthāne kvacid supti vādinā api suṣuptam na viśiṣyate iti vaktavyam
translated: Moreover, it should be said that even one who sleeps in some other place than the nāḍīs, etc. does not differ from one who is in deep sleep.

original: tacca vaktuṃ na śakyata ityāhaapica sthāneti /
analyzed: tat ca vaktum na śakyate iti āha api ca sthāna iti
translated: And that cannot be said, he says: Moreover, in a place, etc.

analyzed: bheda abhāvaḥ hi bheda jñāna abhāve hetuḥ
translated: For the absence of difference is the cause of the absence of the knowledge of difference.

original: nāḍīpūritadratasya tu jīvasya bhedāvasthatvādbhedāvijñāne karaṇaṃ nāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tu jīvasya bheda avastha tvāt bheda avijñāne karaṇam na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: But for the individual soul filled with nāḍīs, etc., being in a state of difference, there is no cause for the non-knowledge of difference, this is the meaning.

analyzed: dvaita avasthā asya api dvaita ajñāne hetum śaṅkate nanu bheda iti
translated: He doubts the cause of the non-knowledge of duality even for one in a state of duality: But, is not the difference, etc.

analyzed: draṣṭuḥ dṛśyāt dūra stha tvam svābhāvikam aupādhikam vā
translated: The natural remoteness of the seer from the seen is either natural or adventitious.

analyzed: tatra ādyam sa dṛṣṭāntam anūdya pratyāha bāḍham ityādinā
translated: There, having stated the first along with an example, he replies: Yes, etc.

analyzed: dvitīyam anūdya dūṣayati upādhi gatam eva iti
translated: Having stated the second, he refutes it: It belongs to the limiting adjunct, etc.

original: upādhisaṃbhinnasyaiva nāḍyādau svāpe katipayasaṃnikṛṣṭārthajñānaprasaṅgāt suṣuptivyāghātaḥ syāt /
analyzed: upādhi saṃbhinnasya eva nāḍī ādau svāpe katipaya saṃnikṛṣṭa artha jñāna prasaṅgāt suṣupti vyāghātaḥ syāt
translated: Because for one mixed with the limiting adjunct, there would be the undesirable consequence of the knowledge of some nearby objects while sleeping in the nāḍīs, etc., there would be a contradiction with deep sleep.

original: upādhilaye tvanyatra jīvasya sthityayogādbrahmaṇyeva svāpa āstheya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: upādhi laye tu anyatra jīvasya sthiti ayogāt brahmaṇi eva svāpaḥ āstheyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But when the limiting adjunct dissolves, because it is not possible for the individual soul to abide elsewhere, sleep must be accepted as being in Brahman itself, this is the meaning.

original: evaṃ vikalpaṃ nirasya nāḍīpurītatorbrahmaṇā saha tulyavatsamuccayamaphalatvena dūṣayan guṇapradhānatvena samuccayamupasaṃharatinaca vayamityādinā🔽END / / /
analyzed: evam vikalpam nirasya nāḍī purītatoḥ brahmaṇā saha tulya vat samuccayam aphalatvena dūṣayan guṇa pradhāna tvena samuccayam upasaṃharati na ca vayam ityādinā  e ns
translated: Having thus refuted the option, he concludes the combination by way of subordinate and principal, while refuting the combination on an equal footing with the nāḍīs and the heart, along with Brahman, as fruitless, with And we do not accept... etc.🔽🔽

analyzed: start
translated: Having thus refuted the option, he rejects the combination of the nāḍīs and the heart with Brahman as equal and fruitless, and concludes the combination as subordinate and principal, with And we do not and so on.

original: ataḥ prabodho 'smāt / / / /🔽yasmāccātmaiva suptisthānamata eva ca kāraṇānnityavadevāsmādātmanaḥ prabodhaḥ svāpādhikāre śiṣyate 'kuta etadāgāt' bṛ / / /
analyzed: atas prabodhaḥ u smāt  yasmāt ca ātmā eva supti sthānam atas eva ca kāraṇāt nitya vat eva asmāt ātmanaḥ prabodhaḥ svāpa adhikāre śiṣyate kutas etat āgāt bṛ
translated: Thus, the awakening is from this.

original: ityasya praśnasya prativacanāvasare 'yathāgneḥ kṣudrā visphuliṅgā vyuccārantyevamevaitasmādātmanaḥ sarve prāṇāḥ' bṛ / / / ityādinā /
analyzed: iti asya praśnasya prativacana avasare yathā agneḥ kṣudrāḥ visphuliṅgāḥ vyuccāranti evam eva etasmāt ātmanaḥ sarve prāṇāḥ ityādinā
translated: And because the Self alone is the place of sleep, for this very reason, the awakening is from this Self as if it were eternal, as taught in the section on sleep. At the time of answering the question From where did this come? in From where did this come?, it is said, Just as small sparks come forth from fire, in the same way all the vital breaths come forth from this Self, and so on.

original: 'sata āgamya na viduḥ sata āgacchāmahe' chā / / / iti ca /
analyzed: sataḥ āgamya na viduḥ sataḥ āgacchāmahe chā iti ca
translated: And Having come to the existent, they do not know. We have come to the existent.

original: vikalpyamāneṣu tu suṣuptisthāneṣu kadācinnāḍībhyaḥ pratibudhyate kadācitpurītataḥ kadācidātmana ityaśāsiṣyat /
analyzed: vikalpyamāneṣu tu suṣupti sthāneṣu kadācid nāḍībhyaḥ pratibudhyate kadācid purītataḥ kadācid ātmanaḥ iti aśāsiṣyat
translated: But if the places of deep sleep were optional, sometimes one would awaken from the nāḍīs, sometimes from the heart, sometimes from the Self.

analyzed: tasmāt api ātmā eva supti sthānam iti
translated: Therefore, the Self alone is the place of sleep.

original: kiñca brahmaṇaḥ sakāśājjīvasyotthānaśruterbrahmaiva suṣuptisthānamityāhasūtrakāraḥataḥ prabodha iti /
analyzed: kiñca brahmaṇaḥ sakāśāt jīvasya utthāna śruteḥ brahma eva suṣupti sthānam iti āha sūtrakāraḥ atas prabodhaḥ iti
translated: Moreover, because of the declaration of the soul's rising from Brahman, Brahman alone is the place of deep sleep, thus says the author of the aphorisms: Therefore, it is the waking state.

analyzed: nāḍī purītatoḥ kvāpi utthāna apādāna tva aśravaṇāt na suṣupti sthāna tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the channels and the heart are not the place of deep sleep, because nowhere is it heard that they are the place of rising and departing.

original: tasmādupādhilaye jīvasya brahmābhedādaupādhika eva bheda iti vivekadvākyārthābhedasiddhiriti sthitam ////
analyzed: tasmāt upādhi laye jīvasya brahma abhedāt aupādhikaḥ eva bhedaḥ iti viveka dvākya artha abheda siddhiḥ iti sthitam
translated: Therefore, it is established that the meaning of the statements on discrimination is the non-difference of the individual soul from Brahman, and the difference is only due to limiting adjuncts.🔽End.

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: Start.

analyzed: karma anusmṛti śabda vidhi adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the remembrance of past actions, words, and injunctions. Sutra.

analyzed: saḥ eva tu karma anusmṛti śabda vidhibhyaḥ
translated: But it is the same, because of the remembrance of past actions, words, and injunctions.

original: tasyāḥ punaḥ satsaṃpatteḥ pratibudhyamānaḥ kiṃ ya eva satasaṃpannaḥ sa eva pratibudhyata uta sa vānyo veti cintyate /
analyzed: tasyāḥ punar sat saṃpatteḥ pratibudhyamānaḥ kim yaḥ eva sata saṃpannaḥ saḥ eva pratibudhyate uta sa vā anyaḥ vā iti cintyate
translated: When he awakens from that attainment of Being, is it the same person who attained Being who awakens, or is it someone else? This is considered.

analyzed: tatra prāptam tāvat aniyamaḥ iti
translated: Here, it is first concluded that there is no restriction.

original: kutaḥ yadā hi jalarāśau kaścijjalabinduḥ prakṣipyate jalarāśireva sa tadā bhavati punaruddharaṇe ca sa eva jalabindurbhavatīti duḥsaṃpādam
analyzed: kutas yadā hi jala rāśau kaścid jala binduḥ prakṣipyate jala rāśiḥ eva sa tadā bhavati punar uddharaṇe ca saḥ eva jala binduḥ bhavati iti duḥsaṃpādam
translated: Why? When a drop of water is poured into a mass of water, it becomes just that mass of water. And when it is drawn out again, it becomes just that drop of water. This is difficult to accomplish.

original: tadvatsuptaḥ pareṇaikatmāpannaḥ saṃprasīdatatīti na sa eva punarutthātumarhati /
analyzed: tadvat suptaḥ pareṇa ekatmā āpannaḥ saṃprasīdatati iti na saḥ eva punar utthātum arhati
translated: In the same way, when the soul is asleep, it becomes one with the Supreme Self and is at rest. Therefore, it does not deserve to rise again.

original: tasmātsa eveśvaro vānyo vā jīvaḥ pratibudhyata ityevaṃ prāpta idamāha sa eva tu jīvaḥ luptaḥ svāsthyaṃ gataḥ punaruttiṣṭhati nānyaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt saḥ eva īśvaraḥ vā anyaḥ vā jīvaḥ pratibudhyate iti evam prāptaḥ idam āha saḥ eva tu jīvaḥ luptaḥ svāsthyam gataḥ punar uttiṣṭhati na anyaḥ
translated: Therefore, either that very God or some other soul awakens. This being the case, he says: But that very soul, having risen and attained normalcy, rises again, not another.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: karma anusmṛti śabda vidhibhyaḥ
translated: Because of the remaining karma, memory, sound, and injunctions.

analyzed: vibhajya hetum darśayiṣyāmi
translated: I will show the reason by dividing it.

analyzed: karma śeṣa anuṣṭhāna darśanāt tāvat saḥ eva utthātum arhati na anyaḥ
translated: First, because the remaining karma is seen to be performed, it is proper for that very one to rise, not another.

analyzed: tathā hi pūrvedyus anuṣṭhitasya karmaṇaḥ u paredyus śeṣam anutiṣṭhan dṛśyate
translated: For thus, on the next day, one is seen to perform the remainder of the karma performed on the previous day.

analyzed: na ca anyena sāmi kṛtasya karmaṇaḥ nyaḥ śeṣa kriyāyām pravarititum arhati  atiprasaṅgāt
translated: And another cannot be engaged in the performance of the remainder of the karma done by another, because that would lead to a great absurdity.

original: tasmādeka eva pūrvedyuraparedyuścaikasya karmaṇaḥ karteti gamyate /
analyzed: tasmāt ekaḥ eva pūrvedyus aparedyus ca ekasya karmaṇaḥ kartā iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that the same one is the doer of the same karma on the previous day and the next day.

original: itaśca sa evottiṣṭhati yatkāraṇamatīte 'hanyahamado 'drākṣamiti pūrvānubhūtasya paścātsmaraṇamanyasyotthāne nopapadyate /
analyzed: itas ca saḥ eva uttiṣṭhati yatkāraṇam atīte hani aham adaḥ drākṣam iti pūrva anubhūtasya paścāt smaraṇam anyasya utthāne na upapadyate
translated: And for this reason also, that very one rises, because the remembrance of what was experienced before, I saw this on the previous day, is not possible if another were to rise.

analyzed: na hi anya dṛṣṭam anyaḥ nusmartum arhati
translated: For one cannot remember what another has seen.

analyzed: saḥ ham asmi iti ca ātma anusmaraṇam ātma antara utthāne na avakalpate  śabdebhyaḥ ca tasya eva utthānam avagamyate
translated: And the remembrance of the self, ‘I am that’, is not possible if the self is produced anew.🔽And from the words also it is understood that it is the same self that rises again.

analyzed: tathā hi punar pratinyāyam pratiyoni ādravati buddha antāya eva
translated: For thus it is said, ‘He runs back again to the place from which he started, to the end of knowledge’ (Br. 3, 9, 26).

original: 'sarvāḥ prajā aharahargacchantya etaṃ brahmalokaṃ na vindanti' chā / / /
analyzed: sarvāḥ prajāḥ ahar ahar gacchantyaḥ etam brahma lokam na vindanti chā
translated: ‘All beings go to that world of Brahman day after day, but do not find it’ (Chā. 8, 3, 2).

original: 'ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yadyadbhavanti tadābhavanti'
analyzed: te iha vyāghraḥ vā siṃhaḥ vā vṛkaḥ vā varāhaḥ vā kīṭaḥ vā pataṅgaḥ vā daṃśaḥ vā maśakaḥ vā yat yat bhavanti tadā ābhavanti
translated: ‘They become here a tiger, a lion, a wolf, a boar, a worm, a moth, a gadfly, a mosquito, whatever they happen to be’ (Chā. 6, 1, 4).

original: chā / / / ityevamādayaḥ śabdāḥ svāpaprabodhādhikāre paṭhitā nātmāntarotthāne sāmañjasyamīyuḥ /
analyzed: chā iti evamādayaḥ śabdāḥ svāpa prabodha adhikāre paṭhitāḥ na ātma antara utthāne sāmañjasyam īyuḥ
translated: Such and other words are recited in the section on sleep and waking, and do not fit in with the production of another self.

analyzed: karma vidyā vidhibhyaḥ ca evam eva avagamyate
translated: And from the injunctions of action and knowledge it is understood in the same way.

analyzed: anyathā hi karma vidyā vidhayaḥ narthakāḥ syuḥ
translated: For otherwise the injunctions of action and knowledge would be meaningless.

analyzed: anya utthāna pakṣe hi supta mātraḥ mucyate iti āpadyeta
translated: For if it were the rising of another, it would follow that one is liberated merely by falling asleep.

original: evaṃ cetsyādvada kiṃ kālāntaraphalena karmaṇā vidyayā vā kṛtaṃ syāt /
analyzed: evam ced syāt vada kim kāla antara phalena karmaṇā vidyayā vā kṛtam syāt
translated: If it were so, then tell us what would be the use of action or knowledge whose fruit comes only after some time?

original: apicānyotthānapakṣe yadi tāvaccharīrāntare vyavaharaṇamāṇo jīva uttiṣṭhettatratyavyavahāralopaprasaṅgaḥ syāt /
analyzed: api ca anya utthāna pakṣe yadi tāvat śarīra antare vyavaharaṇa māṇaḥ jīvaḥ uttiṣṭhet tatratya vyavahāra lopa prasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, if the soul were to rise from another body, then the soul that is engaged in the activities of another body would have to be engaged in the activities of that body, which would lead to the absurdity of the cessation of the activities of that body.

analyzed: atha tatra suptaḥ uttiṣṭhet kalpanā ānarthakyam syāt
translated: If, on the other hand, the soul were to rise from sleep in that body, then the assumption would be useless.

original: yohi yasmiñśarīre suptaḥ sa tasminnotiṣṭhatyanyasmiñśarīre supto 'nyasminnuttiṣṭhatīti ko 'syāṃ kalpanāyāṃ lābhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yaḥ hi yasmin śarīre suptaḥ sa tasmin na uttiṣṭhati anyasmin śarīre suptaḥ nyasmin uttiṣṭhati iti kaḥ syām kalpanāyām lābhaḥ syāt
translated: For one who is asleep in one body would rise from that body, and one who is asleep in another body would rise from that body. What benefit would there be in this assumption?

analyzed: atha muktaḥ uttiṣṭhet antavān mokṣaḥ āpadyeta
translated: If, on the other hand, the liberated soul were to rise, then liberation would have an end.

analyzed: nivṛtta avidyasya ca punarutthānam upapannam
translated: And it is not possible for one whose ignorance has ceased to rise again.

analyzed: etena īśvarasya utthānam pratyuktam
translated: By this, the rising of God is refuted.

analyzed: nitya nivṛtta avidyā tvāt
translated: Because He is eternally free from ignorance.

analyzed: a kṛta abhyāgama kṛta vipraṇāśau ca durnivāra vanya utthāna pakṣe syātām
translated: And in the case of rising from another body, the absurdity of the acquisition of what was not done and the loss of what was done would be unavoidable.

analyzed: tasmāt saḥ eva uttiṣṭhati na anyaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is the same soul that rises, not another.

original: yatpunaruktaṃ yathā jalarāśau prakṣipto jalabindurnoddhartuṃ śakyata evaṃ sati saṃpanno jīvo notpatpatitumarhatīti /
analyzed: yat punar uktam yathā jala rāśau prakṣiptaḥ jala binduḥ na uddhartum śakyate evam sati saṃpannaḥ jīvaḥ na utpad patitum arhati iti
translated: As for what was said - just as a drop of water thrown into a mass of water cannot be taken out, so the soul that has attained union cannot rise again -

analyzed: tat parihriyate
translated: that is refuted.

analyzed: yuktam tatra viveka kāraṇa abhāvāt jala bindoḥ anuddharaṇam
translated: In the case of the water and the drop of oil, there is no reason for discrimination, and therefore the drop of oil cannot be separated from the water.

original: iha tu vidyate vivekakāraṇaṃ karma cāvidyā ceti vaiṣamyam /
analyzed: iha tu vidyate viveka kāraṇam karma ca avidyā ca iti vaiṣamyam
translated: But in the case of the soul and the body, there is a reason for discrimination, viz., action and Nescience.

original: dṛśyate ca durvivecayorapyasmajjātīyaiḥ kṣīrodakayoḥ saṃsṛṣṭayorhaṃsena vivecanam /
analyzed: dṛśyate ca durvivecayoḥ api asmad jātīyaiḥ kṣīra udakayoḥ saṃsṛṣṭayoḥ haṃsena vivecanam
translated: And we see that swans separate milk from water, though the latter are difficult to discriminate by people like us.

original: apica na jīvo nāma kaścitparasmādanyo vidyate yo jalabinduriva jalarāśeḥ sato vivicyeta /
analyzed: apica na jīvaḥ nāma kaścid parasmāt anyaḥ vidyate yaḥ jala binduḥ iva jalarāśeḥ sataḥ vivicyeta
translated: Moreover, there is no soul different from the highest Self, which could be separated from the highest Self as a drop of oil from a mass of water.

analyzed: sat eva tu upādhi saṃparkāt jīvaḥ iti asakṛt prapañcitam
translated: For it has been explained more than once that the soul is nothing but the highest Self, which appears as a soul by its connexion with limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: evam sati yāvat eka upādhi gatā bandha anuvṛttiḥ tāvat eka jīva vyavahāraḥ
translated: If this be so, as long as the soul is connected with one limiting adjunct, it is spoken of as one soul;

original: upādhyantaragatāyāṃ tu bandhānuvṛttau jīvāncataravyavahāraḥ /🔽sa evāyamupādhiḥ svāpaprabodhayorbījāṅ kuranyāyenetyataḥ sa eva jīvaḥ pratibudhyata iti yuktam // //
analyzed: upādhi antara gatāyām tu bandha anuvṛttau  saḥ eva ayam upādhiḥ svāpa prabodhayoḥ bīja aṅ kura nyāyena iti atas saḥ eva jīvaḥ pratibudhyate iti yuktam  /
translated: but when it is connected with another limiting adjunct, it is spoken of as another soul.🔽This limiting adjunct is to the soul what the seed is to the sprout, in the states of deep sleep and waking; hence it is right to say that the soul wakes up.

analyzed: saḥ eva tu karma anusmṛti śabda vidhibhyaḥ
translated: But on account of the remembrance of works, of the Śruti passage, and of injunctions, it is the same soul that wakes up.

original: suṣuptau upādhināśāt karmānusmṛtyāderdarśanācca saṃśaye satyasmādbrahmaṇo jīvasyotthānaśruterbrahmaiva suṣuptisthānamityuktamayuktam /
analyzed: suṣuptau upādhi nāśāt karma anusmṛti ādeḥ darśanāt ca saṃśaye sati asmāt brahmaṇaḥ jīvasya utthāna śruteḥ brahma eva suṣupti sthānam iti uktam ayuktam
translated: In deep sleep, due to the destruction of the limiting adjunct, and because of the perception of the remembrance of actions etc., there is doubt. Then, because of the statement of the arising of the individual soul from this Brahman, it is said that Brahman alone is the place of deep sleep. That is improper.

original: suptādanyasyāpyutthānasaṃbhavena suṣuptasya nāḍyādisthānatvasaṃbhavādityākṣepasaṃgatyā niyamakābhāvādaniyama iti pūrvapakṣamāhatasyāḥ punarityādinā
analyzed: suptāt anyasya api utthāna saṃbhavena suṣuptasya nāḍī ādi sthāna tva saṃbhavāt iti ākṣepa saṃgatyā niyamaka abhāvāt aniyamaḥ iti pūrvapakṣam āha tasyāḥ punar ityādinā
translated: Because of the possibility of arising from something other than sleep, and because of the possibility of deep sleep being the place of the channels etc., with the connection of the objection, the prima facie view that there is no restriction due to the absence of a determining factor is stated by But that etc.
In the prima facie view, knowledge is useless, because liberation in the form of non-return is accomplished by deep sleep itself.

original: siddhānte tu ajñātabrahmātmanā sthitasyājñānabalena punastasyaivotthānāvaśyaṃbhāvādajñānanāśāya jñānāpekṣeti phalam /
analyzed: siddhānte tu ajñāta brahma ātmanā sthitasya ajñāna balena punar tasya eva utthāna avaśyaṃbhāvāt ajñāna nāśāya jñāna apekṣā iti phalam
translated: But in the established conclusion, because of the necessity of the arising of that very soul abiding as the unknown Brahman-Self due to the power of ignorance, there is the need for knowledge to destroy ignorance. That is the result.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ vā iti aniyama dārḍhyāya uktam
translated: Is it God or not? is stated to strengthen the non-restriction.

analyzed: sa vā anyaḥ vā iti eva pūrvapakṣaḥ
translated: Is it He or someone else? is the prima facie view.

original: jñānaṃ vinā buddhyādyupādheratyantanāśābhāvādyayā buddhyopahito jīvaḥ suṣuptau kāraṇātmanā
analyzed: jñānam vinā buddhi ādi upādheḥ atyanta nāśa abhāvāt yayā buddhyā upahitaḥ jīvaḥ suṣuptau kāraṇa ātmanā
translated: Without knowledge, because of the impossibility of the complete destruction of the limiting adjuncts like intellect etc., by whatever intellect the individual soul is limited, in deep sleep it arises in the form of the cause,

original: sthitastasyaiva nānākarmānubhavasaṃskāravatyopahita uttiṣṭhatīti siddhāntayatisa eva tvityādinā /
analyzed: sthitaḥ tasya eva nānā karma anubhava saṃskāravatyā upahitaḥ uttiṣṭhati iti siddhāntayati saḥ eva tu ityādinā
translated: He who was engaged in the performance of the Jyotiṣṭoma, etc., rises again, having taken up the body that is qualified by the impressions of the experiences of various actions of that very person. This is the conclusion. He refutes the opponent's view with the words But it is he himself, etc.

analyzed: sāmi kṛtasya ardha kṛtasya ekasya eva jyotiṣṭoma ādeḥ aneka yajamānaka tva āpātaḥ utiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: The absurd consequence would be that the Jyotiṣṭoma, etc., performed by one person would be shared by many sacrificers.

analyzed: smṛtim uktvā anuśabda sūcitām pratyabhijñām āha so ham iti
translated: Having stated the Smṛti text, he states the recognition indicated by the word anu (afterwards) with the words So 'ham (I am he).

analyzed: ayanam gamanam āyaḥ
translated: Āya means going.

analyzed: yoniḥ tad tad indriya sthānam
translated: Yoni means the abode of each sense organ.

original: pratiniyataṃ gamanaṃ yathā bhavati tathā pratiyonyāgacchati jāgaraṇāyeti śrutyarthaḥ /
analyzed: pratiniyatam gamanam yathā bhavati tathā pratiyoni āgacchati jāgaraṇāya iti śruti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Vedic text is that he goes to each abode for the purpose of waking up, as it happens to be.

analyzed: na vindati iti ajñāna sattvāt suptasya utthāna niyamaḥ uktaḥ
translated: It is said that one who is asleep does not rise again because of the presence of ignorance.

original: iha pūrvaprabodhe ye bhavanti ta eva tadottaraprabodhe bhavantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: iha pūrva prabodhe ye bhavanti te eva tadā uttara prabodhe bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that those that exist at the previous awakening exist at the subsequent awakening.

analyzed: vidhim vyācaṣṭe karma iti
translated: He explains the injunction with the words Karma (action).

original: sa evottiṣṭhatīti niścīyate ityarthaḥ atraivotsūtraṃ yuktyantaramāhaapicetyādinā /
analyzed: saḥ eva uttiṣṭhati iti niścīyate iti arthaḥ atra eva utsūtram yukti antaram āha api ca ityādinā
translated: The meaning is that it is ascertained that he himself rises again. Here itself, he states another reason not mentioned in the sūtra with the words Moreover, etc.

analyzed: anya utthāne sukha ādeḥ na pūrva karma kārya tā iti akṛta sukha ādi āgamaḥ pūrva supta jīva kṛta karma nāśaḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the pleasure, etc., that arise from other causes are not the effects of the previous action, and there is no acquisition of pleasure, etc., that were not previously acquired, and the destruction of the action done by the living being who was previously asleep.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣi uktam dṛṣṭāntam vaiṣamyeṇa dūṣayati yat punar ityādinā
translated: He refutes the example stated by the opponent due to inequality, with What is said and so on.

original: asmadādyaśakyamapi vivecanaṃ prāṇyadṛṣṭāpekṣa īśvaraḥ karotīti matvā dṛṣṭāntamāhadṛśyate ceti /
analyzed: asmat ādi aśakyam api vivecanam prāṇya dṛṣṭa apekṣaḥ īśvaraḥ karoti iti matvā dṛṣṭāntam āha dṛśyate ca iti
translated: Thinking that God, depending on the unseen force of living beings, can discriminate what is impossible for us, he gives an example with And it is seen.

original: brahmābhedācca jīvasya jalabinduvaiṣamyamityāhaapiceti /🔽abhede sa vānyo vottiṣṭhati iti cintānavakāśa ityāśaṅkya buddhibhedena jīvabhedāccintetyāhaevaṃ satīti /
analyzed: brahma abhedāt ca jīvasya jala bindu vaiṣamyam iti āha api ca iti  abhede sa vā anyaḥ vā uttiṣṭhati iti cintā anavakāśaḥ iti āśaṅkya buddhi bhedena jīva bhedāt cintā iti āha evam sati iti
translated: And because the individual soul is non-different from Brahman, the difference from a drop of water is not possible, he says Moreover.🔽Fearing that in non-difference, the thought He or another rises is not possible, he says that the thought is due to the difference of individual souls by the difference of intellect, with Thus being the case.
