analyzed: evam paramārthataḥ vikṛtam eka rūpam api sat brahma deha ādi upādhi antarbhāvāt bhajate iva upa ādi dharmān vṛddhiḥ hrāsa ādīn
translated: Similarly, the existent Brahman, which is really unchanging and of one form, appears to have the properties of the limiting adjuncts such as increase and decrease due to being contained within the limiting adjuncts such as the body.

analyzed: evam ubhayoḥ dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭrāntikayoḥ sāmañjasyāt avirodhaḥ
translated: Thus, there is no contradiction because of the agreement between the example and the exemplified, both of which have increase and decrease.

original: upādhyantarbhāvena tatkalpitadharmavattvamatra vivakṣitāṃśastena sāmyena samādhānasūtramvṛddhihāseti /🔽dṛṣṭāntasāmye 'pi nīrūpātmanaḥ pratibimbaṃ svabuddhyā kathaṃ kalpyata ityata āhana cedamiti /
analyzed: upādhi antarbhāvena tad kalpita dharmavattvam atra vivakṣita aṃśaḥ tena sāmyena samādhāna sūtram vṛddhi hāsa iti  dṛṣṭānta sāmye pi nīrūpa ātmanaḥ pratibimbam sva buddhyā katham kalpyate iti atas āha na ca idam iti
translated: The intended part here is the quality of having the imagined properties due to being contained within the limiting adjuncts. The reconciliation sūtra is increase and decrease by that similarity.

analyzed: śrūyate na kalpyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Even if the example is the same, how is the reflection of the formless self imagined by one's own mind? Therefore, it is said: And this is heard. The meaning is: it is not imagined.

analyzed: śruta dṛṣṭāntasya sūryaka ādi vat iti upanyāsena kim phalam iti atas āha śāstra iti
translated: What is the purpose of citing the example of the sun and so on in the case of the heard and seen? To this he says 'by the scripture' etc.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ nirviśeṣa tvam phalam iti arthaḥ
translated: The purpose is the non-difference of the self.

analyzed: avirodhaḥ iti na vaiṣamyam iti arthaḥ
translated: 'Non-contradiction' means non-inequality.

analyzed: ātmā pratibimba śūnyaḥ
translated: The self is devoid of reflection.

analyzed: nīrūpa dravya tvāt
translated: Because it is a formless substance.

analyzed: vāyu vat iti anumāne ākāśe vyabhicāraḥ
translated: In the inference 'like air', there is fallacy in the case of space.

analyzed: alpa jale vidūra ākāśa pratibimba darśanāt upādhi dūra stha tvam api kvacid an apekṣatam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that remoteness due to the presence of an intervening medium is sometimes not at all necessary, as the reflection of distant space is seen in a little water.🔽end

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: start

analyzed: darśanāt ca
translated: And because it is seen.

original: darśayati ca śrutiḥ parasyaiva brahmaṇo dehādiṣūpādhiṣvantaranupraveśam 'puruścakre dvipadaḥ puruścakre catuśpadaḥ /
analyzed: darśayati ca śrutiḥ parasya eva brahmaṇaḥ deha ādiṣu upādhiṣu antar anupraveśam puruḥ cakre dvipadaḥ puruḥ cakre catuśpadaḥ
translated: And the scripture shows the internal entry of the supreme Brahman itself into the limiting adjuncts such as the body: 'He created the two-footed, he created the four-footed.

original: puraḥ sa pakṣī bhūtvā puraḥ puruṣa āviśat' bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: puras sa pakṣī bhūtvā puras puruṣa āviśat bṛ iti
translated: Having become the bird in front, the person entered into the front.' (Br. 3.2.13)

analyzed: anena jīvena ātmanā anupraviśya chā iti ca
translated: And 'having entered by this individual self' (Ch. 6.3.2).

original: tasmādyuktametat 'ata eva caipamā sūryakādivat' bra /sū / / / iti /
analyzed: tasmāt yuktam etat atas eva ca aipamā sūryaka ādi vat brasū iti
translated: Therefore this is proper: 'For this very reason, it is like the sun and so on' (Brahma. S. 2.1.15).

original: tasmānnirvikalpakaikaliṅgameva brahma nobhayaliṅgaṃ viparītaliṅgaṃ ceti siddham /
analyzed: tasmāt nirvikalpaka eka liṅgam eva brahma na ubhaya liṅgam viparīta liṅgam ca iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that Brahman has only one mark, which is free from conceptual differentiation, and not both marks or contradictory marks.

analyzed: atra kecid dve adhikaraṇe kalpayanti
translated: Here, some imagine two sections.

original: prathamaṃ tāvat kiṃ pratyastamitāśeṣaprapañcamekākāraṃ brahmota prapañcavadanekākāropetamiti /
analyzed: prathamam tāvat kim pratyastamita aśeṣa prapañcam eka ākāram brahma uta prapañca vat aneka ākāra upetam iti
translated: First, whether Brahman is of one form with all manifoldness dissolved, or whether it is endowed with manifoldness like the manifoldness itself.

original: dvitīyaṃ tu sthite pratyastamitaprapañcatve kiṃ sallakṣaṇaṃ brahmota bodhalakṣaṇamutobhayalakṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: dvitīyam tu sthite pratyastam ita prapañca tve kim sat lakṣaṇam brahma uta bodha lakṣaṇam uta ubhaya lakṣaṇam iti
translated: But the second is this: when manifoldness is dissolved, whether Brahman has the characteristic of existence, or the characteristic of consciousness, or the characteristic of both.

analyzed: atra vayam vadāmaḥ sarvathā api ānarthakyam adhikaraṇa antara ārambhasya iti
translated: Here we say that the beginning of another section is entirely useless.

analyzed: yadi tāvat aneka liṅga tvam parasya brahmaṇaḥ nirākartavyam iti ayam prayāsaḥ tad pūrveṇa eva
translated: If, then, this effort is to deny that the highest Brahman has manifold marks, then that should have been denied by the previous section itself.

original: na sthānato 'pi ityanenādhikaraṇena nirākartavyamityayamuttaramadhikaraṇaṃ prakāśavacca🔽etadvyarthameva bhavet /
analyzed: na iti anena adhikaraṇena nirākartavyam iti ayam uttaram adhikaraṇam prakāśavat ca  etat vyartham eva bhavet
translated: Not even from the standpoint of location - this subsequent section would be entirely useless.

original: naca sallakṣaṇameva bhma na bodhalakṣaṇamiti śakyaṃ vaktum /
analyzed: na ca sat lakṣaṇam eva bhma na bodha lakṣaṇam iti śakyam vaktum
translated: And it cannot be said that Brahman has only the characteristic of existence, not the characteristic of consciousness.

analyzed: vijñāna ghanaḥ eva ityādi śruti vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to the uselessness of such scriptural passages as It is pure consciousness alone (Br. 3.9.26).

original: kathaṃ vā nirastacaitanyaṃ brahma cetanasya jīvasyātmatvenopadiśyeta /
analyzed: katham vā nirasta caitanyam brahma cetanasya jīvasya ātma tvena upadiśyeta
translated: Or how can Brahman, which is devoid of consciousness, be taught as the Self of the conscious individual soul?

original: nāpi bodhalakṣaṇameva brahma na sallakṣaṇamiti śakyaṃ vaktum astītyevopalabdhavyaḥ pha / /
analyzed: nā api bodha lakṣaṇam eva brahma na sat lakṣaṇam iti śakyam vaktum asti iti eva upalabdhavyaḥ
translated: Nor can it be said that Brahman has the characteristic of consciousness only, not of existence,

analyzed: ityādi śruti vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt
translated: because that would lead to the futility of such Vedic statements as He is to be known as existing alone.

analyzed: katham vā nirasta sattākaḥ bodhaḥ bhyupagamyeta
translated: Or how can consciousness be accepted as devoid of existence?

analyzed: na api ubhaya lakṣaṇam eva brahma iti śakyam vaktum
translated: Nor can it be said that Brahman has both characteristics,

analyzed: pūrva abhyupagama virodha prasaṅgāt
translated: because that would lead to the contradiction of the previous acceptance.

original: sattāvyāvṛttena ca bodhena bodhavyāvṛttayā ca sattayopetaṃ brahma pratijānānasya tadeva pūrvādhikaraṇapratiṣiddhaṃ saprapañcatvaṃ brahmaṇaḥ
analyzed: sattā vyāvṛttena ca bodhena bodha vyāvṛttayā ca sattayā upetam brahma pratijānānasya tat eva pūrva adhikaraṇa pratiṣiddham sa prapañca tvam brahmaṇaḥ
translated: And for one who asserts Brahman to be endowed with consciousness devoid of existence and existence devoid of consciousness, the same elaborateness of Brahman that was refuted in the previous section

analyzed: prasajyeta
translated: would follow.

analyzed: śruta tvāt adoṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no fault because it is stated in the scriptures, that is not so.

analyzed: ekasya aneka svabhāva tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for one thing to have many natures.

original: atha sattaiva bodho bodha eva ca sattā nānayoḥ parasparavyāvṛttirastīti yadyucyeta
analyzed: atha sattā eva bodhaḥ bodhaḥ eva ca sattā na anayoḥ paraspara vyāvṛttiḥ asti iti yadi ucyeta
translated: If it is said that existence itself is consciousness and consciousness itself is existence, and there is no mutual exclusion between these two,

original: tathāpi kiṃ sallakṣaṇaṃ brahmota bodhalakṣaṇamutobhayalakṣaṇamityevaṃ vikalpo nirālambana eva syāt /
analyzed: tathā api kim sat lakṣaṇam brahma uta bodha lakṣaṇam uta ubhaya lakṣaṇam iti evam vikalpaḥ nirālambanaḥ eva syāt
translated: Still, what is Brahman, the definition of which is existence, or the definition of which is knowledge, or the definition of which is both? Thus, the option would be baseless.

analyzed: sūtrāṇi tu eka adhikaraṇa tvena eva asmābhiḥ nītāni
translated: But the aphorisms have been interpreted by us as having one topic.

original: apica brahmaviṣayāsu śrutiṣvākāravadanākārapratipādanena vipratipannasvānākāre brahmaṇi parigṛhīte 'vaśyaṃ vaktavyetarāsāṃ śrutīnāṃ gatiḥ /
analyzed: apica brahma viṣayāsu śrutiṣu ākāra vadana ākāra pratipādanena vipratipanna sva an ākāre brahmaṇi parigṛhīte vaśyam vaktavyā itarāsām śrutīnām gatiḥ
translated: Moreover, in the scriptures dealing with Brahman, when the formless Brahman is accepted as the subject of dispute by teaching it as having form and as formless, the course of the other scriptures must be stated.

analyzed: tādarthyena prakāśavat ca ityādīni sūtrāṇi arthavattarāṇi saṃpadyante
translated: The aphorisms beginning with like light become more meaningful in that sense.

original: yadyapyāhurākāravādinyo 'pi śrutayaḥ prapañcapravilayamukhenānākārapratipattyarthā eva na pṛthagarthā iti tadapi na samīcīnamiva lakṣyate /
analyzed: yadi api āhuḥ ākāra vādinyaḥ pi śrutayaḥ prapañca pravilaya mukhena anākāra pratipatti arthāḥ eva na pṛthak arthāḥ iti tat api na samīcīnam iva lakṣyate
translated: Although they say that even the scriptures teaching form are only for the purpose of teaching the formless through the dissolution of the world, and are not separate in meaning, that also does not seem to be correct.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: ye hi paravidyādhikāre kecitprapañcā ucyante yathā 'yuktā hyasya harayaḥ śatā deśetyaya vai harayo 'yaṃ vai sahasrāṇi bahūni cānantāni ca'
analyzed: ye hi para vidyā adhikāre kecid prapañcāḥ ucyante yathā vai harayaḥ yam vai sahasrāṇi bahūni ca anantāni ca
translated: Those who say that some worlds are mentioned in the section on supreme knowledge, such as His horses are yoked, in the country, These are the horses, these are the many thousands and the endless ones,

analyzed: bṛ
iti evamādayaḥ te bhavanti pravilaya arthāḥ tat etat brahma apūrvam anaparam anantaram abāhyam
translated: Thus, these are for the purpose of dissolution.

analyzed: iti upasaṃhārāt
translated: Because of the conclusion in the Brhadaranyaka Upanishad: This Brahman is without beginning or end, without inside or outside.

original: ye punarupāsanādhikāre prapañcā ucyante yathā 'manomayaḥ prāṇasīro bhārūpaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: ye punar upāsana adhikāre prapañcāḥ ucyante yathā manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa sīraḥ bhā rūpaḥ chā
translated: But those which are described in the section on meditation, such as consisting of mind, having breath for its body, having light for its form,

analyzed: iti evamādayaḥ na teṣām pravilaya artha tvam nyāyyam
translated: it is not proper for them to be for the purpose of dissolution.

analyzed: sa kratum kurvīta chā
translated: He should form the resolve.

analyzed: iti evañjātīyakena prakṛtena eva upāsana vidhinā teṣām saṃbandhāt
translated: Because of their connection with the meditation injunctions of that type.

original: śrutyā caivañjātīyakānāṃ guṇānāmupāsanārthatve 'vakalpyamāne na lakṣaṇayā pravilayārtatvamavakalpate /🔽sarveṣāṃ ca sādhāraṇe pravilayārthatve sati 'arūpavadeva hi tatpradhānatvāt' bra / sū / / /
analyzed: śrutyā ca evañjātīyakānām guṇānām upāsana artha tve na lakṣaṇayā pravilaya ārta tvam avakalpate  sarveṣām ca sādhāraṇe pravilaya artha tve sati arūpavat eva hi tad pradhāna tvāt
translated: And when the purpose of qualities of that type is determined to be meditation, it cannot be determined to be for the purpose of dissolution by implication.🔽And if dissolution were the common purpose of all, then the statement of the reason for the conclusion in the Brahmasutra: It is indeed like that, because it is primary,

analyzed: iti vinigamana kāraṇa vacanam anavakāśam syāt
translated: would be without scope.

analyzed: phalam api eṣām yathopadeśam kvacid durita kṣayaḥ kvacid aiśvarya prāptiḥ kvacid krama muktiḥ iti avagamyata
translated: And the result of these is understood to be, according to the teaching, the destruction of sin in some cases, the attainment of lordship in some cases, and gradual liberation in some cases.

original: evetyataḥ pārthagartyamevopāsanāvākyānāṃ brahmavākyānāṃ ca nyāyyaṃ naikavākyatvam /
analyzed: eva iti atas pārthagartyam eva upāsanā vākyānām brahma vākyānām ca nyāyyam na eka vākya tvam
translated: Therefore it is right to consider the passages about meditation and the passages about Brahman as having a separate purport, and not as forming one sentence.

analyzed: katham ca eṣām eka vākya tā utprekṣyate iti vaktavyam
translated: And it must be stated how it is supposed that they form one sentence.

analyzed: eka niyoga pratīteḥ prayāja darśa pūrṇamāsa vākya vat iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is because one injunction is understood, as in the case of the sentences about the Prayāja and the Darśapūrṇamāsa, we say no.

analyzed: brahma vākyeṣu niyoga abhāvāt
translated: Because in the passages about Brahman there is no injunction.

original: vastumātraparyavasāyīni hi brakahmavākyāni na niyogopadeśīnītyetadvistare pratiṣṭhāpitaṃ 'tattu samanvayāt bra / sū / / / ityatra /
analyzed: vastu mātra paryavasāyīni hi bra kahma vākyāni na niyoga upadeśīni iti etat vistare pratiṣṭhāpitam tat tu samanvayāt iti atra
translated: For it has been fully established under the Sūtra, ‘But that is Brahman on account of the agreement of the attributes,’ that the passages about Brahman have for purport only the matter of Brahman, and do not teach an injunction.

analyzed: kiṃviṣayaḥ ca atra niyogaḥ bhipreyate iti vaktavyam
translated: And it must be stated what the matter of the injunction is supposed to be here.

original: puruṣo hi niyujyamānaḥ kurviti svavyāpāre kasmiṃścinniyujyate /🔽nanu dvaitaprapañcavilayo na yogaviṣayo bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ hi niyujyamānaḥ kuru iti sva vyāpāre kasmiṃścid niyujyate  nanu dvaita prapañca vilayaḥ na yoga viṣayaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: For a man who is enjoined is enjoined to some activity of his own in some matter, in the words ‘Do thus.’🔽But will not the dissolution of the world of duality not be the matter of the injunction?

original: apravilāpite hi dvaitaprapañce brahmatattvāvabodho na bhavatyato brahmatattvāvabodhapratyanīkabhūto dvaitaprapañcaḥ pravilāpyaḥ /
analyzed: apravilāpite hi dvaita prapañce brahma tattva avabodhaḥ na bhavati atas brahma tattva avabodha pratyanīka bhūtaḥ dvaita prapañcaḥ pravilāpyaḥ
translated: For as long as the world of duality is not dissolved, there is no knowledge of the truth of Brahman. Therefore the world of duality, which is opposed to the knowledge of the truth of Brahman, must be dissolved.

original: yathā svargāmasya yāgo 'nuṣṭhātavya upadiśyata evamapavargakāmasya prapañcapravilayaḥ /
analyzed: yathā svarga āmasya yāgaḥ nuṣṭhātavyaḥ upadiśyate evam apavarga kāmasya prapañca pravilayaḥ
translated: Just as the performance of a sacrifice is taught to one who desires heaven, so the dissolution of the world is taught to one who desires liberation.

original: yathāca tamasi vyavasthitaṃ ghaṭāditattvamavabubhutsamānena tatpratyanīkabhūtaṃ tamaḥ
analyzed: yathā ca tamasi vyavasthitam ghaṭa ādi tattvam avabubhutsamānena tat pratyanīka bhūtam tamaḥ
translated: And just as one who desires to know the truth of a pot hidden in darkness must first dispel the darkness which is opposed to it,

original: pravilāpyata evaṃ brahmatattavamavabubhutsamānena tatpratyanīkabhūtaḥ prapañcaḥ pravilāpayitavyaḥ /
analyzed: pravilāpyate evam brahma tattavam avabubhutsamānena tad pratyanīka bhūtaḥ prapañcaḥ pravilāpayitavyaḥ
translated: so one who desires to know the truth of Brahman must first dispel the world which is opposed to it.

original: brahmasvabhāvo hi prapañco na prapañcasvabhāvaṃ brahma /
analyzed: brahma svabhāvaḥ hi prapañcaḥ na prapañca svabhāvam brahma
translated: For the world has Brahman for its nature, not Brahman for the world.

analyzed: tena nāma rūpa prapañca pravilāpanena brahma tattva avabodhaḥ bhavati iti
translated: Therefore, by the dissolution of the world of names and forms, there is the realization of the truth of Brahman.

original: atra vayaṃ pṛcchāmaḥ ko 'yaṃ prapañcapravilayo nāma /🔽kimagnipratāpasaṃparkādghṛtakāṭhinyapravilaya iva ppapañcapravilayaḥ kartavya āhosvidekasmiṃścandre
analyzed: atra vayam pṛcchāmaḥ kaḥ yam prapañca pravilayaḥ nāma  kim agni pratāpa saṃparkāt ghṛta kāṭhinya pravilayaḥ iva ppapañca pravilayaḥ kartavyaḥ āhosvit ekasmin candre
translated: Here we ask: What is this dissolution of the world?

original: timirakṛtānekacandraprapañcavadavidyākṛto brahmaṇi nāmarūpaprapañco vidyayā pravilāpitavya iti /
analyzed: timira kṛta aneka candra prapañca vat avidyā kṛtaḥ brahmaṇi nāma rūpa prapañcaḥ vidyayā pravilāpitavyaḥ iti
translated: Is the dissolution of the world to be done like the dissolution of the hardness of ghee by contact with the heat of fire, or is the world of names and forms superimposed on Brahman by ignorance, like the many moons seen in the moon due to timira, to be dissolved by knowledge?

original: tatra tāvadvidyāmano 'yaṃ prapañco dehādilakṣaṇa ādhyatmiko bāhyaśca pṛthivyādilakṣaṇaḥ
analyzed: tatra tāvat vidyā manaḥ yam prapañcaḥ deha ādi lakṣaṇaḥ ādhyatmikaḥ bāhyaḥ ca pṛthivī ādi lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: There, the world characterized by the body etc. is internal, and that characterized by earth etc. is external.

original: pravilāpayitavya ityucyeta sa puruṣamātreṇāśakyaḥ pravilāpayitumiti tatpravilayopadeśo
analyzed: pravilāpayitavyaḥ iti ucyeta sa puruṣa mātreṇa aśakyaḥ pravilāpayitum iti tad pravilaya upadeśaḥ
translated: Now, it might be said that this world, characterized by the body etc. internally and by earth etc. externally, should be dissolved by the knowledge of the Self. But that is impossible to be dissolved by the mere individual soul, so the teaching of its dissolution

analyzed: śakya viṣayaḥ eva syāt
translated: would be about an impossible object.

original: ekena cādimuktena pṛthivyādipravilayaḥ kṛta itīdānīṃ pṛthivyādiśūnyaṃ jagadabhaviṣyat /
analyzed: ekena ca ādi muktena pṛthivī ādi pravilayaḥ kṛtaḥ iti idānīm pṛthivī ādi śūnyam jagat abhaviṣyat
translated: And if the dissolution of earth etc. were done by a single one liberated from the beginning, then the world would now be empty of earth etc.

original: athāvidyādhyasto brahmaṇyekasminnayaṃ prapañco vidyayā pravilāpyata iti brūyāt /🔽tato brahmaivāvidyādhyastaprapañcapratyākhyānenāvedayitavyam ekamevādvitīyaṃ brahma /
analyzed: atha avidyā adhyastaḥ brahmaṇi ekasmin ayam prapañcaḥ vidyayā pravilāpyate iti brūyāt  tatas brahma eva avidyā adhyasta prapañca pratyākhyānena āvedayitavyam ekam eva advitīyam brahma
translated: If one were to say that this world, superimposed on Brahman by ignorance, is dissolved by knowledge,

analyzed: tat satyam saḥ ātmā tatvam asi chā
translated: then Brahman itself should be revealed by rejecting the world superimposed by ignorance as one without a second, that Brahman is Truth, that is the Self, that thou art.

original: iti tasminnāvedite vidyā svayamevotpadyate tayā cāvidyā bādhyate /
analyzed: iti tasmin āvedite vidyā svayam evā utpadyate tayā ca avidyā bādhyate
translated: When that is revealed, knowledge arises by itself and by that ignorance is countered.

analyzed: tatas ca avidyā dhyastaḥ sakalaḥ yam nāma rūpa prapañcaḥ svapna prapañca vat pravilīyate
translated: Then this entire world of name and form, superimposed by ignorance, dissolves like a dream.

original: anāvedite tu brahmaṇi brahmavijñānaṃ kuru prapañcapravilayaṃ ceti śatakṛtvo 'pyukte /
analyzed: an āvedite tu brahmaṇi brahma vijñānam kuru prapañca pravilayam ca iti śata kṛtvas u pi ukte
translated: But when Brahman is not known, even if the injunction to know Brahman and to destroy the world of effects is repeated a hundred times,

analyzed: na brahma vijñānam prapañpa pravilayaḥ vā jāyate
translated: neither the knowledge of Brahman nor the destruction of the world of effects takes place.

original: nanvāvedite brahmaṇi tadvijñānaviṣayaḥ prapañcavilayaviṣayo vā niyogaḥ syāt / na /🔽niṣprapañcabrahmātmatvāvedanenaivobhayasiddheḥ /
analyzed: nanu āvedite brahmaṇi tad vijñāna viṣayaḥ prapañca vilaya viṣayaḥ vā niyogaḥ syāt na  niṣprapañca brahma ātma tva āvedanena eva ubhaya siddheḥ
translated: But if Brahman is known, the injunction would be to know Brahman or to destroy the world of effects. Not so.🔽Because both are accomplished by the mere knowledge of Brahman as free from the world of effects.

analyzed: rajju sva rūpa prakāśanena eva hi tad sva rūpa vijñānam avidyā adhyasta sarpa ādi prapañca pravilayaḥ ca bhavati
translated: For by the mere knowledge of the true nature of the rope, the knowledge of its nature and the destruction of the world of effects superimposed by ignorance, such as the snake, take place.

analyzed: na ca kṛtam eva punar kriyate
translated: And what is done is not to be done again.

original: niyojyoñapi ca prapañcāvasthāyāṃ yo 'vagamyate jīvo nāma sa prapañcasyaiva vā syādbrahmapakṣasyaiva vā /🔽prathame vikalpe niṣprapañcabrahmatattvapratipādanena pṛthivyādivajjīvasyāpi pravilāpitatvātkasya prapañcavilaye niyoga ucyeta kasya vā niyoganiṣṭhatayā
analyzed: ca prapañca avasthāyām yaḥ avagamyate jīvaḥ nāma sa prapañcasya eva vā syāt brahma pakṣasya eva vā  prathame vikalpe niṣprapañca brahma tattva pratipādanena pṛthivī ādi vat jīvasya api pravilāpita tvāt kasya prapañca vilaye niyogaḥ ucyeta kasya vā niyoga niṣṭha tayā
translated: And the individual soul, who is known to exist in the state of the world of effects, would belong either to the world of effects or to the side of Brahman.

analyzed: mokṣaḥ vā āptavyaḥ ucyeta
translated: In the first case, since the individual soul, like earth etc., is dissolved by the teaching of the truth of Brahman free from the world of effects, to whom would the injunction to destroy the world of effects be stated, or to whom would liberation be said to be attained by the completion of the injunction?

original: dvitīye 'pi brahmaivāniyojyasvabhāvaṃ jīvasya svarūpaṃ jīvatvaṃ tvavidyākṛtameveti pratipādite brahmaṇi niyojyābhāvānniyogābhāva eva /🔽draṣṭavyādiśabdā api paravidyādhikārapaṭhitāstattvābhimukhīkaraṇapradhānā na tatvāvabodhavidhipradhānā bhavanti /
analyzed: dvitīye pi brahma eva a niyojya svabhāvam jīvasya svarūpam jīva tvam tu avidyā kṛtam eva iti pratipādite brahmaṇi niyojya abhāvāt niyoga abhāvaḥ eva  draṣṭavya ādi śabdāḥ api paravidyā adhikāra paṭhitāḥ tattva abhimukhīkaraṇa pradhānāḥ na tatva avabodha vidhi pradhānāḥ bhavanti
translated: In the second case also, Brahman alone, which is of the nature of the non-agent, is the true nature of the individual soul; but the state of being an individual soul is due to Nescience only. When Brahman has been thus taught, there is absence of injunction, because there is absence of an agent to be enjoined.🔽The words 'to be seen' etc. also, which are recited in the section on the higher knowledge, are primarily meant to turn the mind towards the truth, not to enjoin the knowledge of the truth.

original: loke 'pīdaṃ paśyedamākārṇayeti caivañjātīyakeṣu nirdeśeṣu praṇidhānamātraṃ kurvityucyate na sākṣājjñānameva kurviti /
analyzed: loke pi idam paśya idam ākārṇaya iti ca evañjātīyakeṣu nirdeśeṣu praṇidhāna mātram kuru iti ucyate na sākṣāt jñānam eva kuru iti
translated: Even in the world, in such instructions as 'one should see this, one should hear this', it is said that one should merely make an effort, not that one should directly produce knowledge itself.

original: jñeyābhimukhasyāpi jñānaṃ kadācijjāyate kadācinna jāyate tasmāttaṃ prati jñānaviṣaya eva darśayitavyo jñāpayitukāmena /
analyzed: jñeya abhimukhasya api jñānam kadācid jāyate kadācid na jāyate tasmāt tam prati jñāna viṣayaḥ eva darśayitavyaḥ jñāpayitu kāmena
translated: Even for one who is facing the object of knowledge, knowledge sometimes arises and sometimes does not arise. Therefore, one who desires to make him know should only show the object of knowledge to him.

original: tasmindarśite svayameva yathāviṣayaṃ yathāpramāṇaṃ ca jñānamutpadyate /
analyzed: tasmin darśite svayam eva yathāviṣayam yathāpramāṇam ca jñānam utpadyate
translated: When it is shown to him, knowledge arises by itself, according to the object and according to the means of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca pramāṇa antareṇa anyathā prasiddhi ṛthe nyathā jñānam niyuktasya api upapadyate
translated: And for one who is engaged, it is not possible to have knowledge of an object known by another means of knowledge in a way different from its being known by that other means of knowledge.

original: yadi punarniyukto 'hamityanyathā jñānaṃ kuryānna tu tajjñānaṃ kiṃ tarhi mānasī sā kriyā /
analyzed: yadi punar niyuktaḥ ham iti anyathā jñānam kuryāt na tu tat jñānam kim tarhi mānasī sā kriyā
translated: If, on the other hand, I were to act in a way contrary to the injunction, ‘I am appointed,’ then that would not be knowledge; it would be a mental action.

analyzed: svayam eva ced anyathā utpadyeta bhrāntiḥ eva syāt
translated: And if it were to arise in a different way by itself, it would be mere error.

original: jñānaṃ tu pramāṇajanyaṃ yathābhūtaviṣayaṃ ca na tanniyogaśatenāpi kārayituṃ śakyate /
analyzed: jñānam tu pramāṇa janyam yathā bhūta viṣayam ca na tat niyoga śatena api kārayitum śakyate
translated: But knowledge is produced by a means of valid knowledge and has an object as it really is; it cannot be made by even a hundred injunctions.

analyzed: na ca pratiṣedhena api vārayitum śakyate
translated: And it cannot be prevented even by a prohibition.

analyzed: nahi tat puru śata tantram
translated: For it is not dependent on the person.

analyzed: vastu tantram eva hi tat
translated: It is dependent on the real thing.

original: ato 'pi niyogābhāvaḥ /🔽kiñcānyanniyoganiṣṭhatayaiva paryavasyāmnāye yadabhyupagatamaniyojyabrahmātmatvaṃ jīvasya tadapramāṇakameva syāt /🔽atha śāstramevāniyojyabrahmātmatvamapyācakṣīta tadavabodhe ca puruṣaṃ niyuñjīta tato brahmaśāstrasyaikasya dvyarthaparatā viruddhārthaparatā
analyzed: atas pi niyoga abhāvaḥ  kiñca anyat niyoga niṣṭhatayā eva paryavasya āmnāye yat abhyupagatam aniyojya brahma ātmatvam jīvasya tat apramāṇakam eva syāt  atha śāstram eva aniyojya brahma ātmatvam api ācakṣīta tad avabodhe ca puruṣam niyuñjīta tatas brahma śāstrasya ekasya dvi artha para tā viruddha artha para tā
translated: Therefore, there is no injunction.🔽Moreover, if the Veda were to end only with injunctions, the doctrine of the individual soul being Brahman, which is not to be enjoined, which is accepted, would be without a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: ca prasajyetām
translated: Or if the sacred teaching itself were to declare that the individual soul is Brahman, which is not to be enjoined, and were to engage a person in understanding that, then the one sacred teaching of Brahman would be subject to two contradictory meanings.

original: niyogaparatāyāṃ ca śrutahāniraśrutakalpanā karmaphalavanmokṣasyādṛṣṭaphalatvamanityatvaṃ cetyevamādayo doṣā na kenacitparihartuṃ śakyāḥ /
analyzed: niyoga para tāyām ca śruta hāniḥ aśruta kalpanā karma phala vat mokṣasya adṛṣṭa phala tvam anitya tvam ca iti evamādayaḥ doṣāḥ na kenacid parihartum śakyāḥ
translated: And if the passages about Brahman were to enjoin something, then the following and similar faults would ensue: the abandoning of what is heard, the assumption of what is not heard, the fruit of the knowledge of Brahman would be invisible, and Brahman would be noneternal, just as the fruit of an action is.

analyzed: tasmāt avagata niṣṭhāni eva brahma vākyāni na niyoga niṣṭhāni
translated: Therefore the passages about Brahman have for purport what is already known, not something to be enjoined.

analyzed: atas ca eka niyoga pratīteḥ ekavākya tā iti ayuktam
translated: And hence it is wrong to say that they form one sentence because they convey one injunction.

original: abhyupagamyamāne 'pi ca brahmavākyechu niyogasadbhāve tadekatvaṃ niṣprapañcopadeśeṣu saprapañcopajadeśeṣu cāsiddham /
analyzed: abhyupagamyamāne ca niyoga sadbhāve tad eka tvam niṣprapañca upadeśeṣu ca asiddham
translated: And even if we admit that the passages about Brahman have for purport something to be enjoined, still the oneness of the injunction is not established in the case of those passages which teach a world of multiplicity as well as those which teach a world of nonmultiplicity.

original: nahi śabdāntarādibhiḥ pramāṇairniyogabhede 'vagamyamāne sarvatraikā niyoga iti śakyamāśrayitum /
analyzed: nahi śabda antara ādibhiḥ pramāṇaiḥ niyoga bhede vagamyamāne sarvatra ekā niyogaḥ iti śakyam āśrayitum
translated: For it is not possible to maintain that there is one injunction in all cases, when the difference of injunctions is apprehended by other means of knowledge such as the difference of words.

original: prayājadarśapūrṇamāsavākyechu tvadhikārāṃśenābhedādyuktamekatvam /🔽natviha saguṇanirguṇacodanāsu kaścidekatvādhikīrāṃso 'sti /🔽nahi bhārūpatāvādayo guṇāḥ prapañcapravilayopakāriṇaḥ /
analyzed: prayāja darśa pūrṇamāsa vākya ichu tu adhikāra aṃśena abhedāt yuktam ekatvam  na tu iha saguṇa nirguṇa codanāsu sti  nahi bhā rūpa tāva ādayaḥ guṇāḥ prapañca pravilaya upakāriṇaḥ
translated: But in the case of the passages about the prayājas and the new and full moon sacrifices, oneness is proper, because there is nondifference in the part about the qualification.🔽But in the case of the passages about Brahman with and without qualities there is no such nondifference of purport.🔽For the qualities such as having the form of light do not help the dissolution of the world;

analyzed: nā api prapañca pravilayaḥ bhā rūpa tva ādi guṇa upakārī
translated: nor does the dissolution of the world help the qualities such as having the form of light.

analyzed: paraspara virodhi tvāt
translated: Because of mutual contradiction.

original: nahi kṛtsnaprapañcapravilāpanaṃ prapañcaikadeśāpekṣaṇaṃ caikasmindharmiṇi yuktaṃ samāveśayitum /
analyzed: nahi kṛtsna prapañca pravilāpanam prapañca eka deśa apekṣaṇam ca ekasmin dharmiṇi yuktam samāveśayitum
translated: For it is not proper to combine the complete dissolution of the entire phenomenal world with the dependence on a part of the phenomenal world in a single substrate.

original: tasmādasmādukta eva vibhāga ākāravadanākāropadeśānāṃ yuktatara iti // //
analyzed: tasmāt asmāt uktaḥ eva vibhāgaḥ ākāra vat anākāra upadeśānām yuktataraḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the division stated by us alone is more reasonable for the teachings of form, formlessness, and so on.

original: FN / asya jīvabhāvaṃ prāptasyeśvarasya daśa harayo viṣayā indriyāṇi vā /
analyzed: asya jīva bhāvam prāptasya īśvarasya daśa harayaḥ viṣayāḥ indriyāṇi vā
translated: For him who has attained the state of an individual soul, the ten horses are the objects or the senses.

analyzed: tam jñāna arthinam
translated: Him who seeks knowledge.
The word śabda (word) refers to another word whose meaning is different.

analyzed: praveśa śruteḥ ca ukta anumāna bādhaḥ iti āha sūtrakāraḥ
translated: And because of the mention of entry, there is contradiction with the previously stated inference, the author of the aphorisms says:

analyzed: darśanāt ca iti
translated: And because of seeing.

original: dvipadaḥ puro manuṣyādidehāṃścakre catuṣpadaḥ puraḥ paśūnkṛtvā puraścakṣurādyabhivyakteḥ purastāt sa īśvaraḥ pakṣī liṅgaśarīrī bhūtvā pura
analyzed: dvipadaḥ puraḥ manuṣya ādi dehān cakre catuṣpadaḥ puraḥ paśūn kṛtvā puras cakṣuḥ ādi abhivyakteḥ purastāt saḥ īśvaraḥ pakṣī liṅga śarīrī bhūtvā puras
translated: Having made the two-footed in front, such as human beings, and having made the four-footed in front, such as animals, in front, because of the manifestation of the eye etc., in front, that Lord, having become a bird with a subtle body, in front,

original: sa ca praviṣṭo 'pi puruṣaḥ pūrṇa evetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca praviṣṭaḥ puruṣaḥ pūrṇaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: And even though he has entered, that Purusha is complete, is the meaning.

analyzed: taittirīyake liṅgasya pakṣa ādi ukteḥ pakṣi tvam mantavyam
translated: In the Taittiriya Upanishad, because of the mention of the subtle body as having wings etc., it should be understood to have wings.

original: evaṃ pratibimbabhāvena bhedādeḥ kalpitatvāt nirviśeṣaṃ brahmeti svamatamupasaṃharatitasmāditi /
analyzed: evam pratibimba bhāvena bheda ādeḥ kalpita tvāt nirviśeṣam brahma iti sva matam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: Thus, because difference, etc., are imagined in the manner of a reflection, he concludes his own view that Brahman is without distinctions.

analyzed: eka deśi vyākhyām utthāpayati atra iti
translated: He raises the explanation of a sectarian with Here.

analyzed: na pi ityādi ekam adhikaraṇam
translated: Not even from location is one section.

original: tatra brahmaṇo niṣprapañcatve sthite kiṃlakṣaṇaṃ brahmeti saṃdehe prakāśavaccetyādidvitīyamadhikaraṇaṃ pravṛttaṃ /
analyzed: tatra brahmaṇaḥ niṣprapañca tve sthite kiṃlakṣaṇam brahma iti saṃdehe prakāśavat ca ityādi dvitīyam adhikaraṇam pravṛttam
translated: There, when the non-elaboration of Brahman is established, when there is doubt about what the characteristic of Brahman is, the second section beginning with Like light is begun.

original: na sadrūpameva brahma kintu prakāśavacca cidrūpaṃ ca /
analyzed: na sat rūpam eva brahma kintu prakāśavat ca cit rūpam ca
translated: Brahman is not just of the nature of existence, but also of the nature of consciousness, like light.

analyzed: kutas a vaiyarthyāt
translated: Why? Because it is not meaningless.

original: satyaṃ jñānaṃ sadeva somyetyubhayaśruterdvirūpe brahmaṇyarthavattvāditi pūrvapakṣe siddhāntaḥāha ca tanmātram /
analyzed: satyam jñānam sat eva somya iti ubhaya śruteḥ dvi rūpe brahmaṇi arthavat tvāt iti pūrvapakṣe siddhāntaḥ āha ca tanmātram
translated: When there is the prima facie view that Brahman has two forms, because the statement It is real, knowledge, existence is meaningful when Brahman has two forms, the conclusion is stated: It is that alone.

analyzed: sat mātram brahma śrutiḥ āha
translated: The scripture says that Brahman is existence alone.

analyzed: jñānasya sattā anatirekāt iti
translated: Because knowledge is not different from existence.

analyzed: idam dvitīya adhikaraṇam dūṣayati atra vayam iti
translated: He criticizes this second section with Here we say...
Is the result of the second section the denial of Brahman having many forms?

original: uta bodharūpatvanirāsa āhosvitsattānirāsa iti vikalpya sarvathāpyānarthakyaṃ prapañcayannādye gatārthatāmāhayadi tāvaditi /
analyzed: uta bodha rūpatva nirāsaḥ āhosvit sattā nirāsaḥ iti vikalpya sarvathā api ānarthakyam prapañcayan ādye gatārtha tām āha yadi tāvat iti
translated: Or is the denial of the form of consciousness? Or is the denial of existence? Having considered this, he elaborates on the futility in every way, and in the first case, he says it is already established if it is so.

analyzed: na hi dvitīyaḥ iti āha na ca iti
translated: And it is not the second, he says, and not.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ bodha rūpa tva nirāse jaḍa tvāt jīva abheda śruti bādhaḥ ca syāt iti āha katham vā iti
translated: If the form of consciousness of Brahman is denied, there would be the fault of the inertness and the contradiction of the scriptural statement of non-difference with the individual soul, he says, how then?

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ iti āha na api iti
translated: And it is not the third, he says, and not.

original: sattānirāse bodhasya tucchatvaṃ ca syādityāhakathamiti /🔽naca bodhasya sattānatirekānna tucchateti vācyam /
analyzed: sattā nirāse bodhasya tuccha tvam ca syāt iti āha katham iti  na ca bodhasya sattā anatirekāt na tuccha tā iti vācyam
translated: If existence is denied, there would be the fault of the emptiness of consciousness, he says, how?🔽And it cannot be said that consciousness is not empty because it is not different from existence.

original: sadbodhapadayorvācyānatireke paryāyatvaprasaṅgāt /🔽evaṃ siddhāntaṃ phalābhāvena dūṣayitvā pūrvapakṣaṃ dūṣayatināpīti /
analyzed: sat bodha padayoḥ vācya anatireke paryāya tva prasaṅgāt  evam siddhāntam phala abhāvena dūṣayitvā pūrvapakṣam dūṣayati na api iti
translated: Because if there is no difference in the denotation of the words existence and consciousness, they would be synonyms.🔽Thus, having refuted the established view by the absence of result, he refutes the prima facie view, and not.

analyzed: prasaṅgam eva ahasatta iti
translated: He states the undesirable consequence, and existence.

analyzed: vyāvṛtta tvam bhinna tvam  niṣprapañca eka rūpatva siddhānta virodhāt bhinna ubhaya rūpatva pūrvapakṣa anutthānam iti arthaḥ
translated: Difference means being distinct.🔽The prima facie view of the two being different does not arise due to the contradiction with the established view of the oneness of the non-dual.

analyzed: ubhaya śruti balāt utthānam iti śaṅkate śruta tvāt iti
translated: He doubts that the prima facie view arises due to the force of the two scriptural statements, and because of being stated.

analyzed: meru vindhya vat parasparam bhinna sattā bodhayoḥ eka brahma abheda śaṅkā śruti śatena api na yuktā iti āhana iti
translated: It is not proper to suspect the non-difference of the one Brahman from the two, Sat and Chit, which are mutually different in nature, even with a hundred Vedic texts. He says, No.

analyzed: sat bodhayoḥ bhedaḥ sti na vā
translated: Is there a difference between Sat and Chit or not?

analyzed: ādye śruteḥ api viruddha artha tva anupapatteḥ na pūrvapakṣa utthānam iti uktam
translated: If the first, then it is said that even the Veda cannot be accepted as having contradictory meanings, so the prima facie view does not arise.

analyzed: saṃprati dvitīyam śaṅkate atha sattā eva iti
translated: Now he raises the second doubt, But if they are the same...

analyzed: sat bodha padayoḥ vācya bhede pi lakṣya aikya upapattiḥ akhaṇḍa artha svīkārāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even though there is a difference in the denotations of the words Sat and Chit, their reference to the same thing is possible because of the acceptance of the indivisible meaning.

analyzed: akhaṇḍa arthasya pūrvapakṣa tvam na syāt siddhānta tvāt
translated: The indivisible meaning cannot be the prima facie view because it is the established conclusion.

analyzed: kiñca atra saṃśaye pi ayuktaḥ iti āha tathā api iti
translated: Moreover, he says that even in this doubt it is improper, Thus...

analyzed: eka adhikaraṇa pakṣe sūtrāṇi katham neyāni iti atas āha sūtrāṇi iti
translated: How are the sutras to be interpreted in the case of a single topic? To this he says, The sutras...

analyzed: sva pakṣe sūtra sāmañcasyam ca iti āha api ca iti
translated: And there is agreement of the sutras in our view. He says, Moreover...

analyzed: avaśya apekṣita gati artha tvena uttara sūtrāṇām pūrva eka vākya tvāt na adhikaraṇa bhedaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because the later sutras are necessarily required to convey the meaning, they form a single sentence with the earlier ones, so there is no difference in the topics.

analyzed: ākāra śrutīnām kalpita ākāraḥ gatiḥ iti sva matam uktam
translated: The view of his own school is stated that the references to forms are the means of understanding the imagined forms.

analyzed: prapañca vilaya vādinaḥ tu manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ satya kāmaḥ ityādi ākāra śrutīnām tad itara ākāra pravilayaḥ gatiḥ iti āhuḥ
translated: But those who maintain the doctrine of the dissolution of the world say that the meaning of such passages as, 'He who consists of mind, whose body is breath, whose form is truth' (Ch. Up. III. 18. 1), is the dissolution of all other forms into Brahman.

analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ iti ko rthaḥ
translated: What is the meaning of the term 'consisting of mind'?
It means devoid of all limiting adjuncts other than mind.

analyzed: evam prāṇa śarīra padena prāṇa atirikta upādhi niṣedhāt manasaḥ api abhāva siddhiḥ
translated: Similarly, by the term 'whose body is breath', all limiting adjuncts other than breath being denied, the absence of mind also is established.

original: evaṃ sarve śabdā anākārabrahmaparā eveti tanmatamanūdya dūṣayatiyadapītyādinā /
analyzed: evam sarve śabdāḥ an ākāra brahma parāḥ eva iti tad matam anūdya dūṣayati yat api ityādinā
translated: Thus all these terms refer to Brahman, which is devoid of all forms. This doctrine is stated and refuted by the words 'What is more', etc.

analyzed: kim jñeya brahma prakaraṇa sthānām ākāra śabdānām niṣedha para tvam uta upāsanā prakaraṇa sthānām api
translated: Do the terms denoting forms, occurring in the context of the knowable Brahman, refer to denial, or those occurring in the context of meditation also?

analyzed: tatra ādyam aṅgīkaroti ye hi iti
translated: Of these, he accepts the first by the words 'For, etc.'.

original: asya jīvabhāvaṃ prāptasyeśvarasya daśa harayo viṣayā haraṇāddaśendriyāṇi prāṇibhedāpekṣayā śatāni sahasrāṇi ca teṣāmīśvarādbhedamāśaṅkyāhaayamiti
analyzed: asya jīva bhāvam prāptasya īśvarasya daśa harayaḥ viṣayāḥ haraṇāt daśa indriyāṇi prāṇi bheda apekṣayā śatāni sahasrāṇi ca teṣām īśvarāt bhedam āśaṅkya āha ayam iti
translated: This is the Lord who has attained the state of the individual soul. His ten horses are the ten sense organs, which are so called because they carry away the soul to the objects. These are hundreds and thousands according to the different kinds of living beings. Fearing that the Lord might be thought to be different from God, it is said 'This is He'.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ eva harayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the Lord Himself is the horses.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati ye punar iti

original: manomayādiśabdānāṃ mukhyavṛttyā guṇaparatvasaṃbhave niṣedhalakṣaṇāpi na yuktetyāhaśrutyā ceti /

translated: When it is possible for words like 'consisting of mind' to primarily refer to qualities, even the interpretation as prohibition is not proper. He says: And by the scripture.

original: kiṃ cākārānākāraśrutidvaividhye sati brahmanākāramevetyatra kiṃ vinigamakamiti śaṅkotthānādasthūlādiśrutīnāṃ nirākāratātparyaṃ niyāmakamiti
analyzed: kim ca ākāra anākāra śruti dvaividhye sati brahman nākāram eva iti atra kim vinigamakam iti śaṅkā utthānāt asthūla ādi śrutīnām nirākāra tātparyam niyāmakam iti
translated: Moreover, when there is a twofold scripture regarding form and formlessness, what is the determining factor in this matter that Brahman is only formless? Thus, the doubt arising, the purpose of this aphorism is to state that the scriptures about non-grossness etc. have the purport of formlessness.

analyzed: kathana artham idam sūtram arthavat bhavati
translated: This aphorism becomes meaningful.

original: sarvaśrutīnāṃ niṣedhārthatve tu śaṅkānutthānānniyāmakasūtraṃ vyarthaṃ syādityāhasarveṣāṃ ceti /
analyzed: sarva śrutīnām niṣedha artha tve tu śaṅkā anutthānāt niyāmaka sūtram vyartham syāt iti āha sarveṣām ca iti
translated: But if all the scriptures have the purport of prohibition, then the doubt not arising, the determining aphorism would be useless. Thus he says: And of all.

original: nanūpāsanār'thakavākyānāṃ svārthe phalābhāvāt saphalaniṣedhavākyaśeṣatvamityāśaṅkya phalasya śrutatvānnānyaśeṣatetyāhaphalamapīti /
analyzed: nanu upāsana arthaka vākyānām svārthe phala abhāvāt sa phala niṣedha vākya śeṣa tvam iti āśaṅkya phalasya śruta tvāt na anyaśeṣatā iti āha phalam api iti
translated: Now, since the sentences having the purpose of meditation do not have their own meaning as fruit, they are supplementary to the fruitful prohibitive sentences. Suspecting this, he says that since the fruit is heard, it is not supplementary to another. He says: The fruit also.

analyzed: artha aikya abhāvāt ca na ekavākyatā iti āha katham ca iti
translated: And because there is no unity of meaning, there is no syntactical unity. He says: And how?

analyzed: artha aikyam śaṅkate eka iti
translated: He suspects the unity of meaning, saying: As one.

analyzed: yathā phalavat parama apūrva ākhya niyoga aikyāt aṅga pradhāna vākyānām eka vākya tā tathā tattva avabodha kāmasya
translated: Just as the sentences about the subsidiaries and the primary have syntactical unity due to the unity of the injunction called the supreme unseen potency which has a fruit, so for one who desires to understand the truth,

analyzed: prapañca pravilaya viṣayakaḥ ekaḥ niyoga rūpaḥ ūrthaḥ sti iti ākāra anākāra vākyānām sarveṣām ekavākyatā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that all statements, whether with form or without form, have the same purport, which is a single injunction having as its content the dissolution of the world.

analyzed: niyoga asidyā dūṣayati na iti  viṣayam śaṅkate nanu dvaita iti
translated: He refutes the establishment of the injunction, saying No.🔽He raises an objection, saying But surely, etc.
Opposing means obstructing.

original: nanu prapañcavilaye brahmalayaḥ syādabhedādityata āhabrahmasvabhāvo hi prapañca iti /
analyzed: nanu prapañca vilaye brahma layaḥ syāt abhedāt iti atas āha brahma svabhāvaḥ hi prapañcaḥ iti
translated: But surely, when the world dissolves, Brahman would also dissolve, because of non-difference. To this he says, For the world is of the nature of Brahman.

original: kāraṇaṃ hi kāryasya svarūpamataḥ kāryanāśe 'pi kāraṇasya na layaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇam hi kāryasya svarūpam atas kārya nāśe pi kāraṇasya na layaḥ
translated: The cause is indeed the nature of the effect. Therefore, even when the effect is destroyed, there is no dissolution of the cause.

analyzed: ghaṭa nāśe pi mṛd darśanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even when the pot is destroyed, clay is seen.

original: prapañcasya satyasya kalpitasya vā laye vidhiriti vikalpyādyaṃ dūṣayatitatra yadi tāvaditi /
analyzed: prapañcasya satyasya kalpitasya vā laye vidhiḥ iti vikalpya ādyam dūṣayati tatra yadi tāvat iti
translated: Whether the world is real or imagined, if it dissolves, there is an injunction. Considering this, he criticizes the first option, saying If, first of all, etc.

original: satyasya jñānādadhvasteḥ musalādinā ca kṛtsnadvaitadhvaṃsāyogāt nabhograsanavidhivadaśakyaviṣayo 'yaṃ vidhiḥ /

analyzed: dvitīyam anūdya dūṣayati atha ityādinā
translated: He raises the second option and criticizes it with But if, etc.

analyzed: upadeśa janya jñānāt eva avidyā tad ja prapañca laya siddheḥ niyogaḥ vṛthā eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the injunction is useless, since the destruction of ignorance and the world born of it is accomplished by knowledge born of instruction itself.

original: kiñca brahmajñānādau vidhiḥ kiṃ brahmaṇyajñāte jñāte vā /

analyzed: na ādyaḥ aśakya tvāt iti āha an āvedite tu iti

analyzed: dvitīyam śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He raises the second doubt in But if it is known.

original: upadeśādeva jñāte brahmaṇi sākṣātkāradvaitabādhayoḥ siddhervidhivaiyarthyaṃ siddhasya vidhinā kartumayogādityāhaneti /

translated: Since the direct realization of Brahman and the removal of duality are accomplished by instruction itself, the injunction is useless, because what is already accomplished cannot be made by the injunction. He says No.

analyzed: evam viṣaya abhāvāt niyoga abhāvam uktvā niyojya abhāvāt tad abhāvam āha niyojya u pi ca iti
translated: Having said that there is no injunction due to the absence of such an object, he says that there is no injunction due to the absence of one to be enjoined in And the one to be enjoined is also.

analyzed: ādye jīva nāśāt vidhi ayogaḥ
translated: In the first case, there is no injunction due to the destruction of the individual soul.

original: dvitīye niyojyāsiddhiḥ /🔽tarhi jñāne vidhipratyayānāṃ kā gatirityata āhadraṣṭavyādiśabdā iti /

translated: In the second case, the one to be enjoined is not established.🔽Then what is the status of the notions of injunction in knowledge? He says The words 'should be seen' etc.

original: nanu śrutaṃ jñānaṃ tyaktvā tatsādhanavyāpāravidhiḥ kimiti kalpyata ityāśaṅkya jñānasya puruṣakṛtyasādhyatvādityāhajñeyābhimukhasyāpīti /
analyzed: nanu śrutam jñānam tyaktvā tad sādhana vyāpāra vidhiḥ kim iti kalpyate iti āśaṅkya jñānasya puruṣa kṛtya sādhya tvāt iti āha jñeya abhimukhasya api iti
translated: How is it that the injunction of the operation leading to that is imagined, abandoning the knowledge that is heard? Suspecting this, he says Even of one facing the knowable etc., because knowledge is accomplished by human effort.

analyzed: na iti āha na ca iti

translated: For those who maintain injunctions in the Vedanta, there is another fault as well. He says What is more etc.

original: brahmātmaikyeniyoge ca vedāntavākyasya prāmāṇyamāśaṅkyārthabhedādvākyabhedo viruddhārthatvādaprāmāṇyaṃ ceti dūṣayatiathetyādinā /

translated: For something is denied as real only by positing an ultimate reality, just as a snake, etc. is denied in a rope, etc.

analyzed: tat ca pariśiṣyamāṇe kasmiṃścid bhāve
translated: And that is possible only when some entity remains.

analyzed: ubhaya pratiṣedhe tu kaḥ nyaḥ bhāvaḥ pariśeṣyāt
translated: But if both are denied, what other entity remains?

original: apariśiṣyamāṇe cānyasminya itaraḥ pratiṣeddhumārabhyate pratiṣeddhumaśakyatvāttasyaiva paramārthatvāpatteḥ pratiṣedhānupapattiḥ /🔽nāpi brahmapratiṣedha upapadyate ''brahma te bravāṇi' bṛ / / /
analyzed: a pariśiṣyamāṇe ca anyasmin yaḥ itaraḥ pratiṣeddhum ārabhyate pratiṣeddhum aśakya tvāt tasya eva paramārtha tva āpatteḥ pratiṣedha anupapattiḥ  na api brahma pratiṣedhaḥ upapadyate brahma te bravāṇi bṛ
translated: And if nothing else remains, then what is to be denied, since it is impossible to deny what is not? It would follow that it alone is the ultimate reality. So the denial is impossible.

original: ityādyupakramavirodhāt /🔽'asanneva sa bhavati /🔽asadbrahmeti veda cet' taitti / / /
analyzed: ityādi upakrama virodhāt  a sannā iva sa bhavati  asat brahma iti veda ced taitti
translated: Nor is the denial of Brahman tenable, because it contradicts the introductory statement, I will declare Brahman to you.

analyzed: ityādi nindā virodhāt  asti iti eva upalabdhavyaḥ kaṭha
translated: And because it contradicts the condemnation, If one knows Brahman as non-existent, he becomes non-existent.

analyzed: iti avadhāraṇa virodhāt
translated: And because it contradicts the restriction, He is to be apprehended as existing.

analyzed: sarva vedānta vyākopa prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because it would lead to the contradiction of all the Vedanta texts.

analyzed: vāc manasā atīta tvam api brahmaṇaḥ na abhāva abhiprāyeṇa abhidhīyate
translated: And the statement that Brahman is beyond speech and mind is not made with the intention of denying its existence.

analyzed: nahi mahatā parikara bandhena brahma vidā āpnoti param
translated: For it would not be possible that in the Vedānta texts, after Brahman has been taught by such passages as, 'He who knows Brahman attains the highest' (Tai. 2.1),

analyzed: satyam jñānam anantam brahma taiḥ
translated: 'Brahman is truth, knowledge, infinite' (Tai. 2.1),

analyzed: iti evamādinā vedānteṣu brahma pratipādya tasya eva punar abhāvaḥ
translated: that its non-existence should be stated again.

original: prakṣālanāddhi paṅ kasya dūrādasparśaṃ varam iti hi nyāyaḥ /
analyzed: prakṣālanāt hi paṅ kasya dūrāt asparśam varam iti hi nyāyaḥ
translated: For the rule is, 'It is better to keep far away from mud, than to wash it off.'

analyzed: pratipādana prakriyā tu eṣā yatas vācaḥ nivartante
translated: But this is the method of teaching: 'From which speech turns away,

analyzed: a prāpya manasā saha taiḥ iti
translated: unable to reach it, together with the mind' (Tai. 2.1).

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati vāṅmanasātītamaviṣayāntaḥpāti pratyagātmabhūtaṃ nityaśuddhabuddhamuktasvabhāvaṃ brahmeti /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati vāc manasā atītam aviṣaya antaḥpāti pratyagātma bhūtam nitya śuddha buddha mukta svabhāvam brahma iti
translated: This is what is said: Brahman is that which is beyond speech and mind, which is not an object, which is internal, which is the self, which has the nature of being eternally pure, knowledge, and free.

analyzed: tasmāt brahmaṇaḥ rūpa prapañcam pratiṣedhati pariśinaṣṭi brahma iti abhyupagantavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be accepted that Brahman is denied, that is, Brahman is excluded, in relation to the world of forms.

analyzed: tat etat ucyate prakṛtā etāvat tvam hi pratiṣedhati iti
translated: This is what is said: 'It denies the extent of the subject-matter.'

original: prakṛtaṃ yadetāvadiyattāparicchinnaṃ mūrtāmūrtalakṣaṇaṃ brahmaṇo rūpaṃ tadeṣa śabdaḥ pratiṣedhati /
analyzed: prakṛtam yat etāvat iyat tā paricchinnam mūrta amūrta lakṣaṇam brahmaṇaḥ rūpam tat eṣa śabdaḥ pratiṣedhati
translated: This word denies that limited form of Brahman, characterized as consisting of the material and immaterial, which is the extent of the subject-matter.

original: taddhi prakṛtaṃ prapañcitaṃ ca pūrvasminagranthe 'dhidaivatamadhyātmaṃ ca tajjanitameva
analyzed: tat hi prakṛtam prapañcitam ca pūrvasmin a granthe dhidaivatam adhyātmam ca tat janitam eva
translated: For that has been stated and discussed in the previous part of the text, both in relation to the gods and in relation to the self, and it is only the latent impressions generated by that

analyzed: ca aparam rūpam amūrta rasa bhūtam puruṣa śabda uditam liṅga ātma vyapāśrayam
translated: which is the other form characterized by latent impressions, which is in the nature of the formless essence, indicated by the word 'purusha', which is based on the linga-self,

analyzed: mahā jana ādi upamābhiḥ darśitam
translated: which has been shown by similes such as the great man etc.

analyzed: amūrta rasasya puruṣasya cakṣuḥ grāhya rūpa yogi tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for the formless essence of the purusha to be associated with a form that can be grasped by the eye.

original: tadetatsaprapañcaṃ brahmaṇo rūpaṃ saṃnihitālambanenetikaraṇena pratiṣedhakaṃ nañaṃ pratyupanīyata iti gamyate /
analyzed: tat etat sa prapañcam brahmaṇaḥ rūpam saṃnihita ālambanena iti karaṇena pratiṣedhakam nañam pratyupanīyate iti gamyate
translated: It is understood that this form of Brahman along with its details is presented to the negative particle 'na' (not) through the particle 'iti' (thus) which refers to something present.

original: brahma tu rūpaviśeṣaṇatvena ṣaṣṭhyā nirdiṣṭaṃ pūrvasmingranthe na svapradhānatvena /
analyzed: brahma tu rūpa viśeṣaṇa tvena ṣaṣṭhyā nirdiṣṭam pūrvasmin granthe na sva pradhāna tvena
translated: But Brahman is indicated by the genitive case as a qualifier of form in the previous part of the text, not as the principal itself.

original: prapañcite ca tadīye rūpadvaye rūpavataḥ svarūpajijñāsāyāmidamupakrāntam 'athāta ādeśo neti neti'' bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: prapañcite ca tadīye rūpa dvaye rūpavataḥ svarūpa jijñāsāyām idam upakrāntam atha atas ādeśaḥ na iti na iti iti
translated: And when the two forms belonging to it have been discussed, when there is a desire to know the nature of the one possessing the forms, this is begun: 'Now, therefore, the teaching - not so, not so' (Br. 3.9.26).

analyzed: tatra kalpita rūpa pratyākhyānena brahmaṇaḥ svarūpa āvedanam idam iti nirṇīyate
translated: It is determined that in this (text), by rejecting the imagined forms, the nature of Brahman is indicated.

original: tadāspadaṃ hīdaṃ samastaṃ kāryaṃ neti netīti pratiṣiddham /
analyzed: tad āspadam hi idam samastam kāryam na iti na iti iti pratiṣiddham
translated: For this entire effect, which has that (Brahman) as its basis, is negated by 'not so, not so'.

original: yuktaṃ ca kāryasya vācārambhaṇasabdhādibhyo 'sattvamiti neti netīti pratiṣedhanaṃ na tu brahmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: yuktam ca kāryasya sattvam iti na iti na iti iti pratiṣedhanam na tu brahmaṇaḥ
translated: And it is proper that the effect should be denied by the words, 'It is not, it is not,' because it is unreal, as shown by the words, 'It is a mere name,' etc., but not Brahman.

analyzed: karu a kalpanā mūla tvāt
translated: For Brahman is the root of the imagination of the effect.

original: nacātreyamāśaṅkā kartavyā kathaṃ hi śāstraṃ svayameva rūpadvayaṃ darśayitvā svayameva punaḥ pratiṣedhati 'prakṣālanāddhi paṅ kasya dūrādasparśanaṃ 🔽varam' iti /
analyzed: na ca atra iyam āśaṅkā kartavyā katham hi śāstram svayam eva rūpa dvayam darśayitvā svayam eva punar pratiṣedhati prakṣālanāt hi paṅ kasya dūrāt asparśanam  varam iti
translated: And here this doubt should not be entertained: How is it that the scripture itself, having shown two forms, denies them again itself? 'For it is better to keep far away from mud, than to wash it off.'

original: yato nedaṃ śāstraṃ pratipādyatvena brahmaṇo rūpadvayaṃ nirdiśati /
analyzed: yatas na idam śāstram pratipādya tvena brahmaṇaḥ rūpa dvayam nirdiśati
translated: For this scripture does not point out the two forms of Brahman as to be taught.

original: lokaprasiddhaṃ tvidaṃ rūpadvayaṃ brahmaṇi kalpitaṃ parāmṛśati pratiṣedhyatvāya śuddhabrahmasvarūpapratipādanāya ceti niravadyam /
analyzed: loka prasiddham tu idam rūpa dvayam brahmaṇi kalpitam parāmṛśati pratiṣedhya tvāya śuddha brahma svarūpa pratipādanāya ca iti niravadyam
translated: But it refers to the two forms of Brahman imagined in the world, in order to deny them and to teach the pure nature of Brahman. Thus there is no fault.🔽And these two denials, according to the rule of enumeration, deny both the material and the immaterial.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.

original: dvau caitau pratiṣedhau yathāsaṃkhyanyāyena dve api mūrtāmūrte pratiṣedhataḥ /
analyzed: dvau ca etau pratiṣedhau yathā saṃkhya nyāyena dve api mūrta amūrte pratiṣedhataḥ
translated: Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.🔽Or the former denial denies the aggregate of elements, and the latter the aggregate of impressions.

original: yadvā pūrvaḥ pratiṣedho bhūtarāśiṃ pratiṣedhatyuttaro vāsanārāśim /🔽athavā 'neti neti' bṛ / / /
analyzed: yat vā pūrvaḥ pratiṣedhaḥ bhūta rāśim pratiṣedhati uttaraḥ vāsanā rāśim 🔽athavā na iti na iti bṛ
translated: Or the former denial denies the aggregate

original: iti vīpseyamitīti yāvatkiñcidutprekṣyate tatsarvaṃ na bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti vīpsā iyam iti iti yāvat kiñcid utprekṣyate tat sarvam na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, whatever is imagined to be something, all that is not, is the meaning.

original: parigaṇitapratiṣedhe hi kriyamāṇe yadi naitadbrahma kimanyadbrahma bhavediti jijñāsā syāt /
analyzed: parigaṇita pratiṣedhe hi kriyamāṇe yadi na etat brahma kim anyat brahma bhavet iti jijñāsā syāt
translated: For if a limited negation were being made, if this is not Brahman, what else could Brahman be? There would be an inquiry.

original: vāpsāyāṃ tu satyāṃ samastasya viṣayajātasya pratiṣedhādaviṣayaḥ pratyagātmā brahmeti jijñāsā nivartate /
analyzed: vāpsāyām tu satyām samastasya viṣaya jātasya pratiṣedhāt aviṣayaḥ pratyagātmā brahma iti jijñāsā nivartate
translated: But when there is a negation, since the entire class of objects is negated, the inquiry ceases, thinking that Brahman is the inner self, which is not an object.

original: tasmātprapañcameva brahmaṇi kalpitaṃ pratiṣedhati pariśnaṣṭi brahmeti nirṇayaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt prapañcam eva brahmaṇi kalpitam pratiṣedhati pariśnaṣṭi brahma iti nirṇayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the conclusion is that it negates, excludes, only the imagined universe in Brahman, not Brahman.

analyzed: itas ca eṣaḥ eva nirṇayaḥ
translated: And for this very reason, the conclusion is this.

analyzed: yatas tatas pratiṣedhāt bhūyas bravīti anyat param asti iti
translated: Because after that negation, it says again, There is another, higher one.

original: abhāvāvāsane hi pratiṣedhe kriyamāṇe kimanyatparamastīti brūyāt /
analyzed: abhāva avāsane hi pratiṣedhe kriyamāṇe kim anyat param asti iti brūyāt
translated: For if a negation were being made without any basis, what else could it say, Is there another, higher one?

original: tatraiṣākṣarayojanā neti netīti brahmādiśya tamevādeśaṃ punarnirvakti /
analyzed: tatra eṣā akṣara yojanā na iti na iti iti brahma ādiśya tam eva ādeśam punar nirvakti
translated: There, this is the interpretation of the word: Not so, not so. It points to Brahman and again explains that very pointing.

analyzed: na iti na iti iti asya kaḥ ṛthaḥ
translated: What is the meaning of Not so, not so?

original: nahyetasmādbrahmaṇo vyatiriktamastītyato neti netītyucyate na punaḥ svayameva nāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: nahi etasmāt brahmaṇaḥ vyatiriktam asti iti atas na iti na iti iti ucyate na punar svayam eva na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: It is said that Not so, not so means that there is nothing apart from this Brahman, not that it itself does not exist.

original: tacca darśayatyanyatparamapratiṣiddhaṃ brahmāstīti /🔽yadā punarevamakṣarāṇi yojyante nahyetasmāditi neti neti /
analyzed: tat ca darśayati anyat parama pratiṣiddham brahma asti iti  yadā punar evam akṣarāṇi yojyante na hi etasmāt iti na iti na iti
translated: And this is shown by another passage, which does not deny Brahman, but declares that it exists.

analyzed: nahi prapañca pratiṣedha rūpāt ādeśanāt anyat parādeśanam brahmaṇaḥ sti iti
translated: When, on the other hand, the words are construed in the following manner, ‘Not so, not so,’ ‘not from this,’ then there is no other declaration of Brahman than the mere denial of the world.

original: tadā tato bravīti ca bhūya ityetannāmadheyaviṣayaṃ yojayitavyam /
analyzed: tadā tatas bravīti ca bhūyas iti etat nāmadheya viṣayam yojayitavyam
translated: Then the words, ‘And he declares it again,’ must be construed as referring to the name.

original: atha nāmadheyam 'satyasya satyamiti prāṇa vai satyaṃ teṣāmeṣa satyam' bṛ / / /
analyzed: atha nāmadheyam satyasya satyam iti prāṇa vai satyam teṣām eṣa satyam
translated: And the name is this, ‘The truth of the truth,’ ‘The truth is the vital air, and this is the truth of that.’

analyzed: iti hi bravīt iti
translated: For thus it is declared.

analyzed: tat ca brahma avasāne pratiṣedhe samañjasam bhavati
translated: And this is consistent with a denial which ends in Brahman.

original: abhāvāvasāne tu pratiṣedhe kiṃ satyasya satyamityucyeta /
analyzed: abhāva avasāne tu pratiṣedhe kim satyasya satyam iti ucyeta
translated: But in a denial which ends in non-existence, what is the meaning of ‘the truth of the truth’?

analyzed: tasmāt brahma avasānaḥ yam pratiṣedhaḥ na abhāva avasānaḥ iti adhyavasyāmaḥ
translated: Therefore we conclude that this denial ends in Brahman, and not in non-existence.

analyzed: pṛthivī ap tejaḥ rūpam bhūta trayam mūrtam
translated: The three elements earth, water, and fire are gross,

analyzed: vāyu ākāśa rūpam ca amūrtam iti dvis āśi tvena
translated: and the two elements air and ether are subtle, thus making two classes.

analyzed: mahārājanam haridrā
translated: Mahārāja is turmeric.

original: brahmaṇo nirviśeṣacinmātratvamuktvā sarvaniṣedhāvadhitvena sadrūpatvamāhaprakṛtaitāvattvaṃ hi pratiṣedhati tato bravīti ca bhūya iti /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nirviśeṣa cit mātra tvam uktvā sarva niṣedha avadhi tvena sat rūpa tvam āha prakṛta etāvattvam hi pratiṣedhati tatas bravīti ca bhūyas iti
translated: Having stated that Brahman is pure consciousness without distinctions, he now says that it is of the nature of existence as the ultimate limit of all negations, by the words 'but denies the limitedness of the subject, and then speaks further'.

original: pṛthivyaptejobhūtatrayaṃ mūrtaṃ vāyvākāśadvayamamūrtamiti rāśidvayamuktvā bhūtadvayasyāmūrtasya🔽sāraḥ 'karaṇātmā hiraṇyagarbho ya eṣa etasmin sūryamaṇḍale puruṣo yaścāyaṃ dakṣiṇe
analyzed: pṛthivī ap tejaḥ bhūta trayam mūrtam vāyu ākāśa dvayam amūrtam iti rāśi dvayam uktvā bhūta dvayasya amūrtasya  sāraḥ karaṇa ātmā hiraṇya garbhaḥ yaḥ eṣaḥ etasmin sūrya maṇḍale puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam dakṣiṇe
translated: Having mentioned two groups, the group of three gross elements earth, water and fire, and the group of two subtle elements air and space, he speaks of the essence of the two subtle elements,

analyzed: kṣiṇi puruṣaḥ iti uktaḥ  tasya vāsanā mayāni svapna rūpāṇi tat yathā māhārajanam
translated: which is the person consisting of the organs, Hiranyagarbha, who is mentioned as 'the person in the sun-disc here, and the person in the right eye'.🔽The dreams, which are made of impressions of that person, are mentioned by similes as various, 'like red lac,

analyzed: vāsaḥ yathā pāṇḍvāvikam yathā indragopaḥ iti upamābhiḥ uktāni vicitrāṇi
translated: like a pale blanket, like an Indragopa insect'.

original: tatra mahārajanaṃ haridrā tayā liptaṃ vastraṃ māhārajanaṃ /🔽pāṇḍvādikamiti dhavalaṃ kambalādi /
analyzed: tatra mahārajanam haridrā tayā liptam vastram māhārajanam  pāṇḍu ādikam iti dhavalam kambala ādi
translated: Here, red lac is turmeric, and a cloth smeared with it is red lac.🔽Pale etc. means white, like a blanket.

original: kecittu śrutimupalakṣaṇaṃ kṛtvā sūkṣmapañcabhūtānyamūrtāni pañcīkṛtāni mūrtāni tataścāmūrtarasatvoktyā karaṇānāṃ pāñcabhautikatvasiddhiriti
analyzed: kecid tu śrutim upalakṣaṇam kṛtvā sūkṣma pañcabhūtāni amūrtāni pañcīkṛtāni mūrtāni tatas ca amūrta rasa tva uktyā karaṇānām pāñcabhautika tva siddhiḥ iti
translated: Some, taking the Vedic text as an indication, say that the subtle five elements are subtle, and the gross elements are gross. Thus, by the statement of the essence of the subtle elements, it is established that the organs are composed of the five elements.

analyzed: vyācakṣate
translated: explain.

analyzed: atha sat pada ātmaka prapañca ukti anantaram
translated: Then, after the statement of the world consisting of the true Self,

original: ata uktāropasya niṣedhārthatvānneti netīti niṣedhenopadeśaḥ kriyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas ukta āropasya niṣedha ārtha tvāt na iti na iti iti niṣedhena upadeśaḥ kriyate iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that because the statement of what is said is for the purpose of negation, the teaching is done by the negation neti neti.

analyzed: na iti śabda artham āha nahi iti
translated: The meaning of the word neti is stated by na hi.

analyzed: etasmāt ātmanaḥ nyat na asti iti na iti iti ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is said neti because there is nothing other than this Self.

analyzed: śūnyatā nirāsa artham param brahma asti iti uktam iti siddhānta rītyā śruti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the scripture is that the highest Brahman exists in order to refute emptiness, according to the established doctrine.

analyzed: atra niṣedhya viśeṣa anupalambhāt saṃśayam āha tatra kaḥ sya ityādinā
translated: Here, because no particular object of negation is perceived, he states the doubt with What is this? etc.

analyzed: nañ prayogasya na ākāra asya iti śabda upasthāpita vastu niṣedhaka tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because the usage of the negative has the nature of negating the entity presented by the word iti,

analyzed: iti śabdāt niṣedhya sāmānya samarpaṇe viśeṣa ākāṅkṣāyām prakaraṇāt rūpa dvayasya rūpi brahmaṇaḥ ca
translated: when the word iti presents the general object of negation and there is a desire for a particular, due to the context, the two forms and the Brahman with form

analyzed: niṣaidhya tva bhānāt saṃśayam uktvā pūrva uktam nirviśeṣam brahma na asti iti ākṣepa saṅgatyā
translated: are seen to be objects of negation, so after stating the doubt, he raises the objection that the previously stated Brahman without distinctions does not exist,

analyzed: pūrvapakṣayati tatra prakṛta tva iti
translated: and then argues for the prima facie view with There, because it is the subject matter.
In the prima facie view, because the object denoted by the word tat does not exist, the non-difference of the meaning of the sentence is not established.

analyzed: siddhānte tad siddhiḥ iti phalam
translated: The result is that in the established view, that is established.

original: niradhiṣṭhānaniṣedhādarśanātsarvaniṣedho na yukta ityarucyā prapañce brahmaniṣedha ityāhaathaveti /
analyzed: niradhiṣṭhāna niṣedha adarśanāt sarva niṣedhaḥ na yuktaḥ iti arucyā prapañce brahma niṣedhaḥ iti āha athavā iti
translated: Because of the non-observation of a negation without a basis, the negation of everything is not proper. Therefore, out of dislike, he says that the negation of Brahman is in the world of effects.

original: ekabrahmaṇa eva niṣedhe nakāradvayasya paunaruktyāmityata āhaabhyāsastviti /
analyzed: eka brahmaṇaḥ eva niṣedhe nakāra dvayasya paunaruktyām iti atas āha abhyāsaḥ tu iti
translated: If there is only the negation of one Brahman, the repetition of the negative particle is redundant. To this he says but the repetition.

analyzed: utsūtram eva tāvat siddhāntam upakramate evam iti
translated: He begins the established view, which is not in accordance with the sutra, with thus.

analyzed: śūnya prasaṅgaḥ iṣṭaḥ iti vadantam pratyāha kiñcid hi iti
translated: In reply to one who says that the undesirable consequence of emptiness is intended, he says some cognition.

original: tacceti pratiṣedhanamityarthaḥ /🔽adhiṣṭhānānavaśeṣe tatpramārūpahetvabhāvāt niṣedhavākyārthaḥ pramā na syāt 'idamatra nāsti'iti loke niṣedhasya sādhiṣṭhānasyaiva pramitidarśanādityarthaḥ
analyzed: tat ca iti pratiṣedhanam iti arthaḥ  adhiṣṭhāna anavaśeṣe tad pramā rūpa hetu abhāvāt niṣedha vākya arthaḥ pramā na syāt idam atra na asti iti loke niṣedhasya sa adhiṣṭhānasya eva pramiti darśanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And that, means the negation, is the meaning.🔽If there is no remainder of the basis, then due to the absence of the cause in the form of valid cognition, the meaning of the sentence of negation would not be valid cognition, because in the world, negation is seen to have a basis, as in this is not here.

analyzed: kiñca yat bhāti tat sat iti utsargasya bhāna artha abhāva adhiṣṭhāna pramitiḥ apavādaḥ tayā pūrva bhānasya bhrama tva niścayena artha sattva apalāpāt
translated: Moreover, the exception to the general rule that what appears exists is the valid cognition of the basis of the non-existence of the object. By the ascertainment of the error of the previous appearance through that, the existence of the object is denied.

analyzed: apavāda anaṅgīkāre tu utsargataḥ prapañcasya satya tva āpatteḥ niṣedha anupapattiḥ iti āha a pariśiṣyamāṇe ca iti
translated: If denial is not accepted, then, because the world would be true by the general rule, denial would be impossible. Thus he says: And if nothing is left over.

original: adhiṣṭhānasattvaṃ vinā bhrāntiniṣedhayorayogācchūnyavādo na yukta ityuktvā pūrvavādinaḥ pakṣāntaraṃ dūṣayatināpīti /
analyzed: adhiṣṭhāna sattvam vinā bhrānti niṣedhayoḥ ayogāt śūnyavādaḥ na yuktaḥ iti uktvā pūrvavādinaḥ pakṣa antaram dūṣayati nā api iti
translated: Since denial and illusion are impossible without the existence of a substratum, the doctrine of emptiness is not proper. Having said this, he refutes another view of the opponent with the word nor.

original: dehātmābhimānavallaukikamānaprāptadvaitasya niṣedho yukto na vedāntapramitabrahmaṇa iti bhāvaḥ yaduktaṃ vāṅmanasātītvāt niṣedhārhaṃ brahma
analyzed: deha ātma abhimāna vat laukika māna prāpta dvaitasya niṣedhaḥ yuktaḥ na vedānta pramita brahmaṇaḥ iti bhāvaḥ yat uktam vāc manasā atī tvāt niṣedha arham brahma
translated: The meaning is that the denial of the duality attained by worldly means, like the conceit of the self in the body, is proper, but not of Brahman known by the Vedanta. What was said, that Brahman is fit to be denied because it is beyond speech and mind,

analyzed: iti tatra āha vāc manasā iti
translated: there he says: Speech and mind, etc.

original: brahmaṇo vāgādyatītatvaṃ niṣedhārthaṃ na cet kimarthaṃ taduktirityata āhapratipādaneti /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ vāc ādi atīta tvam niṣedha artham na ced kimartham tad uktiḥ iti atas āha pratipādana iti
translated: If the transcendence of Brahman by speech, etc. is not for the purpose of denial, for what purpose is that stated? Therefore he says: For the purpose of teaching, etc.

analyzed: ukta arthe sūtram yojayati tat etat ityādinā
translated: He connects the sutra with the stated meaning with the words that, etc.

original: 'dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe'iti rūpadvayasyaiva prādhānyena prakṛtatvānnetīti niṣedha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: dve vāva brahmaṇaḥ rūpe iti rūpa dvayasya eva prādhānyena prakṛta tvāt na iti iti niṣedhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because only the two forms are primarily referred to in the words Verily, Brahman has two forms, the denial is of that.

original: nanu 'ādityamaṇḍale puruṣa'iti brahmāpyatra prādhānyenoktamityāśaṅkya puruṣo liṅgātmā amūrtarasatvaśrutyā bhūtajanitatvabhānāt svapnarūpatvaśruteścetyāhatajjanitameveti
analyzed: nanu āditya maṇḍale puruṣaḥ eti brahma api atra prādhānyena uktam iti āśaṅkya puruṣaḥ liṅga ātmā amūrta rasa tva śrutyā bhūta janita tva bhānāt svapna rūpa tva śruteḥ ca iti āha tat janitam eva iti
translated: But it may be argued that Brahman also is mentioned here as the principal object, in the passage, A person in the sun, and so on. To this he says, The person is the individual soul, on account of the passage about the essence of the immortal, on account of the declaration of its being produced from the elements, and on account of the declaration of its being of the nature of dreams. It is produced from that.

original: rūparūpiṇorabheda uktaḥ nanu vāsanāmayaṃ rūpameva kimityupamīyate prasiddharūpameva kiṃ na syādityata āhaamūrtarasasyeti /
analyzed: rūpa rūpiṇoḥ abhedaḥ uktaḥ nanu vāsanā mayam rūpam eva kim iti upamīyate prasiddha rūpam eva kim na syāt iti atas āha amūrta rasasya iti
translated: But it may be argued that Brahman also is mentioned here as the principal subject, in the passage the person in the sun - to this he says that is produced by that etc. The non-difference of form and the possessor of form is stated. But why is the form itself, which is of the nature of impressions, compared? Why cannot it be the well-known form itself? To this he says of the one whose essence is incorporeal.

analyzed: rūpa dvayasya eva prādhānyena prakṛta tve phalitam āha tat iti
translated: When the two forms are stated as the principal subject, he states the result in the words that etc.

analyzed: pratiyogi tvena samarpyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is indicated as the counter-correlate.

original: na cārthataḥ pradhānyadbrahmaṇo niṣedhaḥ rājño bhṛtyo nāstītyatra rājaniṣedhaprasaṅgāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na ca arthataḥ pradhānyat brahmaṇaḥ niṣedhaḥ rājñaḥ bhṛtyaḥ na asti iti atra rāja niṣedha prasaṅgāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And it is not that Brahman is negated because of being the principal subject by meaning, because then there would be the undesirable consequence of the negation of the king in the sentence the servant of the king does not exist - this is the idea.

original: kiñcaitra brahmaṇaḥ pratipādyatvāt na niṣedha ityāhaprapañcite ceti /
analyzed: kiñca etra brahmaṇaḥ pratipādya tvāt na niṣedhaḥ iti āha prapañcite ca iti
translated: Moreover, Brahman is not negated because it is the subject matter, he says and it is elaborated etc.

original: nanu brahmaṇi niṣiddhasyāpyanyatra sthitisaṃbhavāt kathaṃ kalpitatvamityata āhatadāspadamiti /
analyzed: nanu brahmaṇi niṣiddhasya api anyatra sthiti saṃbhavāt katham kalpita tvam iti atas āha tad āspadam iti
translated: But since what is negated in Brahman can exist elsewhere, how can it be imagined? To this he says that is its basis etc.

analyzed: upādāne niṣiddhasya anyatra na sthitiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that what is negated in the material cause does not exist elsewhere.

analyzed: yat tu dvaita niṣedhe pratyakṣa ādi virodhaḥ iti
translated: As for the objection that there is contradiction with perception etc. in the negation of duality,

analyzed: tatra āha yuktam ca iti
translated: he says it is not proper, etc.

original: sthāpitaṃ hi ārambhaṇādhikaraṇe pratyakṣādervyāvahārikaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ na tatvāvedakamiti /
analyzed: sthāpitam hi ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇe pratyakṣa ādeḥ vyāvahārikam prāmāṇyam na tatva āvedakam iti
translated: For it has been established in the Adhikaraṇa on the beginning that perception etc. have validity only in worldly usage, not in revealing reality.

analyzed: atas tattvataḥ niṣedhāt na virodhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that there is no contradiction because of the negation of reality.

analyzed: nanu vastu tva advaita vat brahmaṇaḥ pi niṣedhaḥ stu
translated: But let there be a negation of Brahman also like the non-duality of reality.

analyzed: na iti āhanatu iti
