analyzed: dvaita bhāva abhāva sākṣi tvāt aśakyaḥ niṣedhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it cannot be negated because it is the witness of the existence and non-existence of duality.

analyzed: na ca ityādi spaṣṭa artham
translated: And what is stated is clear.

original: yaccoktaṃ niṣedhābhyāṃ rūpaṃ rūpi brahma ca niṣidhyata iti /
analyzed: yat ca uktam niṣedhābhyām rūpam rūpi brahma ca niṣidhyate iti
translated: And what was said, that the form and the Brahman with form are negated by the two negations,

analyzed: tatra āha dvau ca etau iti
translated: there he says these two, etc.

original: uddeśyavidheyārthānāṃ saṃkhyāsāmye yathākramaṃ saṃbandha iti nyāyaḥ 'yathāsaṅkhyamanudeśaḥ samānām'iti pāṇinisūtrasiddhastenātra rūpadvayoddeśena
analyzed: uddeśya vidheya arthānām saṃkhyā sāmye yathākramam saṃbandhaḥ iti nyāyaḥ yathāsaṅkhyam anudeśaḥ samānām iti pāṇini sūtra siddhaḥ tena atra rūpa dvaya uddeśena
translated: The rule is that when the number of the objects to be specified and the objects to be enjoined is the same, they are connected in order. This is established by the Panini sutra Anudeśaḥ samānānām yathāsankhyam. Therefore, here the injunction of the two negations is by specifying the two forms.

analyzed: niṣedha dvaya vidhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is by the injunction of the two negations.

analyzed: vīpsā pakṣe sarva dṛśya niṣedhāt jijñāsā śāntiḥ iti viśeṣam āha parigaṇita iti

analyzed: sūtra śeṣam vyācaṣṭe itas ca iti

analyzed: rūpa ādi abhāvāt avyaktam indriya agrāhyam na tu asattvāt iti arthaḥ

translated: The meaning is: because there is no difference in connection, form, injunction, etc.

original: yathaikasminnagnihotre śākhābhede 'pi puruṣaprayatnastādṛśa eva codyate juhuyāditi /🔽evam 'yo ha vai jyoṣṭhaṃ ca śreṣṭhaṃ ca veda' bṛ / / / / chā / / /
analyzed: yathā ekasmin agnihotre śākhā bhede pi puruṣa prayatnaḥ tādṛśaḥ eva codyate juhuyāt iti  evam yaḥ ha vai jyoṣṭham ca śreṣṭham ca veda chā
translated: Just as in the Agnihotra, even when there is a difference of Śākhās, the human effort is enjoined in the same way, One should offer.

original: iti vājasaneyināṃ chandogānāṃ ca tādṛśyeva codanā /
analyzed: iti vājasaneyinām chandogānām ca tādṛśī eva codanā
translated: Similarly, in the Vājasaneyaka and the Chandogya, the injunction is the same: One who knows the highest and the best...

original: prayojanasaṃyogo 'pyaviśiṣṭa eva 'jyeṣṭhaśca śreṣṭhaśca svānāṃ bhavati'' bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: prayojana saṃyogaḥ pi a viśiṣṭaḥ eva jyeṣṭhaḥ ca śreṣṭhaḥ ca svānām bhavati iti
translated: The connection with the purpose is also the same: He becomes the best and the greatest of his own people.

original: rūpamapyubhayatra tadeva vijñānasya yaduta jyeṣṭhaśreṣṭhādiguṇaviśeṣaṇānvitaṃ prāṇatattvam /
analyzed: rūpam api ubhayatra tat eva vijñānasya yat uta jyeṣṭha śreṣṭha ādi guṇa viśeṣaṇa anvitam prāṇa tattvam
translated: The form of the knowledge is the same in both: the essence of the vital breath, qualified by the attributes of being the highest, the best, etc.

original: yathā ca dravyadevate yāgasya rūpamevaṃ vijñeyaṃ rūpaṃ vijñānasya tena hi tadrūpyate /
analyzed: yathā ca dravya devate yāgasya rūpam evam vijñeyam rūpam vijñānasya tena hi tat rūpyate
translated: And just as the substance and deity are the form of the sacrifice, so should the form of knowledge be known, for by that it is made to have that form.

analyzed: samākhyā api sā eva prāṇa vidyā iti
translated: And the same is the designation, as the knowledge of the vital breath.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva vedānta pratyaya tvam vijñānānām
translated: Therefore, the knowledge is based on all the Vedānta texts.

analyzed: evam pañca agni vidyā vaiśvānara vidyā śāṇḍilya vidyā iti evamādiṣu yojayitavyam
translated: Similarly, it should be applied to the five-fire knowledge, the Vaiśvānara knowledge, the Śāṇḍilya knowledge, and so on.

original: ye tu nāmarūpādayo bhedahetvābhāsāste prathama eva kāṇḍe na nāmnā syādacodanābhidhānatvāt ityārabhya parihṛtāḥ // //
analyzed: ye tu nāma rūpa ādayaḥ bheda hetvābhāsāḥ te prathame eva kāṇḍe na nāmnā syāt acodana abhidhāna tvāt iti ārabhya parihṛtāḥ
translated: But the apparent causes of difference such as name, form, etc. have been refuted in the very first section, beginning with It cannot be by name, because it is not an injunction.

original: FN / codyata iti codanā puruṣaprayatnaḥ sa hi puruṣavyāpāraḥ /
analyzed: codyate iti codanā puruṣa prayatnaḥ sa hi puruṣa vyāpāraḥ
translated: The injunction is that which is enjoined, it is human effort, for that is human activity.

analyzed: brahma svarūpam nirdhārya tad jñāna sādhana upāsanā svarūpam āha sarva vedānta pratyayam codanā ādi aviśeṣāt iti
translated: Having determined the nature of Brahman, he states the nature of meditation, which is the means of knowing that, as being based on all the Vedānta texts, because of the non-distinction of injunction and so on.

analyzed: pāda saṃgatim āha vyākhyātam iti
translated: He states the connection with the section as follows: It has been explained.

analyzed: pūrva pāde tattvam padārtha vivekaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: In the previous section, the meaning of the word tat (that) has been analyzed.

original: iha tatphalaṃ vākyārthajñānamānandādayaḥ pradhānasyeti sūtreṇāpunaruktāpekṣitatatpadadvācyārthopasaṃhāreṇa nirdhāryata iti phalaphalibhāvaḥ
analyzed: iha tad phalam vākya artha jñānam ānanda ādayaḥ pradhānasya iti sūtreṇa apunarukta apekṣita tad pada dvācyārtha upasaṃhāreṇa nirdhāryate iti phala phali bhāvaḥ
translated: Here, the result is the knowledge of the meaning of the sentence, and the bliss etc. are of the principal, as determined by the sutra, by including the meanings denoted by the two words required by non-repetition, thus the relation of means and end.

analyzed: saṃgatiḥ
translated: This is the connection.

original: saguṇavākyārthavidyācintā tu tadvidyānāṃ cittaikāgryadvārā nirguṇajñānasādhanatvātkriyata iti mantavyam /
analyzed: sa guṇa vākya artha vidyā cintā tu tad vidyānām citta aikāgrya dvārā nirguṇa jñāna sādhana tvāt kriyate iti mantavyam
translated: But the consideration of the knowledge of the meaning of the scripture with attributes is to be understood as done because those knowledges are the means of knowing the attributeless by way of the one-pointedness of the mind.

analyzed: saṃpratiḥ
translated: This is the present topic.

analyzed: nirguṇa jñānam bheda abheda vicāra viṣaya tvena uktam iti manvānaḥ ākṣipati nanu iti
translated: Thinking that the knowledge of the attributeless has been stated as the subject of the consideration of difference and non-difference, he raises the question thus: But how can there be a consideration of the difference of knowledge?

original: vedyabhede vidyābhedacintā syāt brahmaṇastu vedyasyaikyānna cintāvasara ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vedya bhede vidyā bheda cintā syāt brahmaṇaḥ tu vedyasya aikyāt na cintā avasaraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The consideration of the difference of knowledge would be if there were a difference of the object of knowledge. But since Brahman, the object of knowledge, is one, there is no occasion for consideration, this is the meaning.

analyzed: brahma aikye pi dharma bhedāt cintā iti atas āha eka rūpa tvāt ca iti
translated: Even if Brahman is one, there is consideration due to the difference of attributes. To this he says: And because of the one form, etc.

analyzed: nirdharma tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of the absence of attributes.

analyzed: eka rūpe pi brahmaṇi aneka prakāra saṃbhavāt bheda śaṅkā iti atas āha na ca ityādinā
translated: Even in the one form of Brahman, there is the possibility of many kinds, so there is doubt of difference. To this he says And not because of the one form, etc.

original: pūrvapakṣe jñānabhedaśaṅkānupapattimuktvā codanādyabhedājjñānābheda iti siddhānto 'pyayukta ityāhanāpyasyeti /
analyzed: pūrvapakṣe jñāna bheda śaṅkā anupapattim uktvā codanā ādi abhedāt jñāna abhedaḥ iti siddhāntaḥ pi ayuktaḥ iti āha na api asya iti
translated: Having stated the impossibility of the doubt of the difference of knowledge in the prima facie view, he says Nor is the conclusion that the knowledge is non-different because of the non-difference of the injunction, etc.

analyzed: evam pāda ārambham ākṣipya samādhatte etat ucyate iti
translated: Having thus raised the question of the commencement of the chapter, he answers it with the words That is said.

original: saguṇavidyāsveva bhedābhedacintā kriyate nirguṇavidyāyāṃ tvaikyaṃ siddhamiti vācyārtharūpaguṇopasaṃhāramātraṃ kriyate vākyārthanirṇayāyeti
analyzed: saguṇa vidyāsu eva bheda abheda cintā kriyate nirguṇa vidyāyām tu aikyam siddham iti vācya artha rūpa guṇa upasaṃhāra mātram kriyate vākya artha nirṇayāya iti
translated: The discussion of difference and non-difference is carried out only in the vidyas with attributes. In the vidya without attributes, oneness is established. Only the conclusion of the meaning of the words is carried out for the purpose of determining the meaning of the sentence.

analyzed: pañca agni prāṇa dahara śāṇḍilya vaiśvānara ādi vidyāḥ mithas bhinnāḥ iti nānā śabda ādi bhedāt iti atra vakṣyate
translated: It will be said in Due to the difference of different words etc. that the vidyas of the five fires, prana, dahar, sandilya, vishvānara etc. are different from each other.

original: atra tu mithobhinnāstāḥ kiṃ pratiśākhaṃ bhidyānte na veti nāmādibhedāccodanādyaviśeṣācca saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: atra tu mithas bhinnāḥ tāḥ kim pratiśākham bhidyānte na vā iti nāma ādi bhedāt codanā ādya viśeṣāt ca saṃśayaḥ
translated: Here, however, the doubt is whether those which are different from each other are divided according to each branch or not, due to the difference of names etc. and the non-difference of injunction etc.

original: pūrvapakṣe vidyābhedādguṇānupasaṃhāraḥ siddhānte tvabhedādupasaṃhāra iti phalabhedaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvapakṣe vidyā bhedāt guṇa anupasaṃhāraḥ siddhānte tu abhedāt upasaṃhāraḥ iti phala bhedaḥ
translated: In the prima facie view, due to the difference of vidya, there is no combination of qualities. In the conclusion, however, due to non-difference, there is combination. This is the difference in results.

analyzed: pūrva tantre śākhā antara adhikaraṇa pūrvapakṣa sūtram nāma rūpa dharma viśeṣa punarukti nindā śakti samāpti vacana prāyaścitta anya artha darśanāt śākhā antare karma bhedaḥ 🔽syāt iti
translated: In the previous section, the prima facie view of the Shakhaantara adhikarana is stated in the sutra Nama, rupa, dharma, vishesha, punarukta, ninda, shakti, sampatti vacana, prayaschitta, anyartha darshanat, karma bheda syat shakha antare.

original: tatroktā hetavo nāmādayo vidyābhedārthamihocyante 'athaiṣa jyotirathaiṣa sarvajyotiretena
analyzed: tatra uktāḥ hetavaḥ nāma ādayaḥ vidyā bheda artham iha ucyante atha eṣa jyotiḥ atha eṣa sarva jyotiḥ etena
translated: The reasons stated there, such as the names, are mentioned here for the purpose of distinguishing the knowledge. In the text Now this is the light, now this is all the light, with this one should sacrifice with a thousand as the sacrificial fee,

original: sahasradakṣiṇena yajeta'ityatra prakṛtajyotiṣṭomānuvādena sahasradakṣiṇākhyaguṇavidhimāśaṅkya🔽jyotiritipadasya karmāntaranāmatvasaṃbhave jyotiṣṭomalakṣakatvāyogādatheti prakaraṇavicchedācca🔽jyotiṣṭomātkarmāntaraṃ viśiṣṭadakṣiṇākaṃ vidhīyata iti nāmnaḥ karmabhedakatvamuktama /
analyzed: sahasra dakṣiṇena yajeta iti atra prakṛta jyotiṣṭoma anuvādena sahasra dakṣiṇā ākhya guṇa vidhim āśaṅkya  jyotiḥ iti padasya karma antara nāmatva saṃbhave jyotiṣṭoma lakṣaka tva ayogāt atha iti prakaraṇa vicchedāt ca  jyotiṣṭomāt karma antaram viśiṣṭa dakṣiṇākam vidhīyate iti nāmnaḥ karma bhedaka tvam uktam
translated: suspecting a statement of the quality called a thousand as the sacrificial fee by way of a restatement of the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice that is the subject,🔽since it is possible that the word light is the name of a different sacrifice, and since now indicates a break in the context,🔽it is stated that the name indicates a difference in the sacrifice, by enjoining a different sacrifice with a distinguished sacrificial fee from the Jyotiṣṭoma.

analyzed: jyotiḥ ādiṣu iti ādi padena ādhvaryavam hautram iti saṃjñā bhedāt karma bhedaḥ grāhyaḥ
translated: In the words beginning with light, the difference in the sacrifice should be understood from the difference in names such as Adhvaryu, Hotṛ.

analyzed: taptam kṣīram dadhnā kaṭhinam āmikṣā
translated: Hot milk curdled with yogurt is āmikṣā.

analyzed: tatra dravam jala rūpam vājinam iti bhedaḥ
translated: There, the liquid in the form of water is vājin. This is the difference.

original: 'tapte payasi dadhyānayati sā vaiśvadevyāmikṣā vājibhyo vājinam'ityatra vaiśvadevyāmikṣāyāge
analyzed: tapte payasi dadhi ānayati sā vaiśvadevī āmikṣā vājibhyaḥ vājinam iti atra vaiśvadevī āmikṣā yāge
translated: In the text He mixes yogurt in heated milk. That is the āmikṣā for the Viśvedevas. The vājin is for the vājin-worthy, in the āmikṣā sacrifice for the Viśvedevas,

original: vājinākhyaguṇavidhiḥ vājibhya iti viśvedevānuvādādityāśaṅkyāmikṣāṃ paryupasarjanatvenoktaviśvadevānāṃ🔽vājibhya ityanuvādāyogādutpattiśiṣṭāmikṣāvaruddhe karmaṇi vājinadravyasyānākāṅkṣitasya
analyzed: vājina ākhya guṇa vidhiḥ vājibhyaḥ iti viśvedeva anuvādāt iti āśaṅkya āmikṣām paryupasarjana tvena ukta viśvadevānām  vājibhyaḥ iti anuvāda ayogāt utpatti śiṣṭa āmikṣā avaruddhe karmaṇi vājina dravyasya an ākāṅkṣitasya
translated: The injunction of the quality called 'vājin' is 'to the vājin horses', but fearing that this would be a mere reference to the Viśvedevas, the curds are mentioned as subordinate,🔽and since it is not possible to refer to the Viśvedevas mentioned in the injunction, in the rite restricted by the curds prescribed in the originative injunction, the substance vājin, which is not required,

analyzed: vidhi ayogāt vāji devatākaḥ vājina yāgaḥ karma antaram iti dravya devatā ākhya rūpa bhedāt karma bhedaḥ siddhāntitaḥ
translated: and since it is not possible to enjoin it, the sacrifice of vājin dedicated to the vājin deity is a different rite. Thus the difference of rites is established by the difference of form called substance and deity.

analyzed: ādi padāt aindram dadhi aindram payaḥ iti dravya bhedāt yāga bhedaḥ grāhyaḥ
translated: By the word 'ādi' (in the Bhāṣya), the difference of sacrifices due to the difference of substances like 'curds for Indra' and 'milk for Indra' should be accepted.

analyzed: evam iha api pañca agni ṣaṣ agni rūpa bhedāt vidyā bhedaḥ vāji chandogayoḥ
translated: Similarly, here also, there is a difference of knowledge due to the difference of form as five fires and six fires for the Vājasaneyins and the Chāndogyins.

original: tathā retonyūnā vāgādayaśchāndogye tatsahitā vājināmiti prāṇavidyābhedaḥ /
analyzed: tathā retaḥ nyūnāḥ vāc ādayaḥ chāndogye tad sahitāḥ vājinām iti prāṇa vidyā bhedaḥ
translated: Similarly, there is a difference of knowledge of the vital air, because in the Chāndogya the speech etc. are deficient in semen, while in the Vājasaneyins they are accompanied by it.

original: kārīrivākyādhyayane taittirīyakāṇāṃ bhūmau bhojanaṃ dharmaviśeṣo nānyeṣāṃ /
analyzed: kārīri vākya adhyayane taittirīyakāṇām bhūmau bhojanam dharma viśeṣaḥ na anyeṣām
translated: In the study of the Kārīrī hymn, eating on the ground is a special duty for the Taittirīyakas, not for others.

analyzed: agni adhyayane keṣāñcid upādhyāya artham udaka āharaṇam dharmaḥ na anyeṣām
translated: In the study of the Agni (Veda), fetching water for the teacher is a duty for some, not for others.

analyzed: aśvamedha adhyayane śvaghāsa ānayanam keṣāñcid eva na anyeṣām
translated: In the study of the Aśvamedha, the bringing of the horse's fodder is for some, not for others.

original: naca tānyeva kārīryādīni karmāṇi dharmaviśeṣamapekṣante nāpekṣante ceti yuktaṃ /
analyzed: na ca tāni eva kārīrī ādīni karmāṇi dharma viśeṣam apekṣante na apekṣante ca iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that those very rites like the Kārtīrvijaya require a special dharma and do not require it.

original: ato dharmaviśeṣācchākhāntare karmabhedaḥ śaṅkitastathātrāpi muṇḍakādhyayena keṣāñcideva śirasyaṅgārapātradhāraṇarūpaṃ vrataṃ nānyeṣāmiti vidyābhedaḥ
analyzed: atas dharma viśeṣāt śākhā antare karma bhedaḥ śaṅkitaḥ tathā atra api muṇḍaka adhyayena keṣāñcid eva śirasi aṅgāra pātra dhāraṇa rūpam vratam na anyeṣām iti vidyā bhedaḥ  /
translated: Therefore, the difference in rites in another branch is suspected due to the special dharma. Similarly here also, due to the Muṇḍaka chapter, the vow in the form of holding a pot of charcoal on the head is for some only, not for others. Thus there is a difference in knowledge.

analyzed: syāt punaruktiḥ abhyāsaḥ
translated: Again, repetition is the reiteration.

original: yathā 'samidho yajati tanūnapātaṃ yajati'iti yajatyabhyāsātprayājānāṃ bheda uktastathā śākhāntare 'bhyāsādvidyābhedaḥ /
analyzed: yathā samidhaḥ yajati tanūnapātam yajati iti yajati abhyāsāt prayājānām bhedaḥ uktaḥ tathā śākhā antare bhyāsāt vidyā bhedaḥ
translated: Just as the difference of the prayājas is stated due to the reiteration of the word 'yajati' in 'samidh yajati', 'tanūnapātam yajati', similarly the difference of knowledge is due to the reiteration in another branch.

analyzed: ādi padāt nindā ādi grahaḥ
translated: By the word 'ādi' (etc.), censure etc. are included.🔽There is a difference between the offering before sunrise and

analyzed: prātar prātar anṛtam te vadanti purā udayāt juhvati ye gnihotram iti anudita homasya
translated: the offering after sunrise, because of the statement of censure of the offering before sunrise in 'They speak untruth to you every morning, those who offer agnihotra before sunrise',

analyzed: yat udite sūrye prātar juhuyāt yathā atithaye pradrutāya śūnyāya avasāthāya āhāryam haranti
translated: and of the offering after sunrise in 'If one offers the morning oblation after sunrise, it is as if they carry away the food meant for a guest who has started on a journey, leaving the house empty.

analyzed: tādṛś eva tatityudita homasya ca nindā śruteḥ bhedaḥ
translated: It is just like that.'

analyzed: ekasya eva udite n udite ca anuṣṭhāna ayogāt
translated: Because it is impossible to perform the same act both when the sun has risen and when it has not risen.

analyzed: tathā udita anudita homa atikrama kṛta prāyaścittāt api agnihotra bhedaḥ śaṅkitaḥ
translated: Similarly, the difference in the Agnihotra is suspected due to the expiation performed for the omission of the Homa when the sun has risen or not risen.

original: ete nindāprayaścitte vedāntavidyāsu na vidyete iti nodāhriyete /
analyzed: ete nindā prayaścitte vedānta vidyāsu na vidyete iti nā udāhriyete
translated: These censures and expiations are not found in the Vedanta studies, so they are not cited.

original: yathā sarvaśākhāvihitasya karmaṇo jñātuṃ kartuṃ cāśakterbhedastathā sarvavedāntādhyayanajñānādyaśaktestattadvedāntavidyābhedaḥ
analyzed: yathā sarva śākhā vihitasya karmaṇaḥ jñātum kartum ca aśakteḥ bhedaḥ tathā sarva vedānta adhyayana jñāna ādi aśakteḥ tad tad vedānta vidyā bhedaḥ
translated: Just as there is a difference in the ritual enjoined by all the branches due to the inability to know and perform it, so there may be a difference in the various Vedanta studies due to the inability to study and know all the Vedantas.

original: syāt tathā śākhānāṃ sarvāsāmekarūpā samāptirnocyate kintu kasyāścitkvacitkarmaṇi
analyzed: syāt tathā śākhānām sarvāsām eka rūpā samāptiḥ nā ucyate kintu kasyāścid kvacid karmaṇi
translated: Similarly, the completion of all the branches is not said to be of the same form, but rather the completion of some in some rituals.

analyzed: samāptiḥ atas samāpti vacana bhedāt pratiśākham karma bhedaḥ śaṅkitaḥ
translated: Therefore, the difference in rituals is suspected due to the difference in the statements of completion.

analyzed: tathā kasyacid vedāntasya oṅkāra sārvātmye samāptiḥ kasyacid anyatra iti vidyā bhedaḥ
translated: Similarly, the completion of some Vedanta in the all-pervasiveness of Om and of some elsewhere is the difference in knowledge.

original: anyārthadarśanamarthavādastadbhedātkarmabhedavadvidyābheda iti pūrvapakṣasūtroktā hetavo darśitāste kecitsiddhānte pūrvapakṣe cātropayuñjanta
analyzed: anya artha darśanam arthavādaḥ tad bhedāt karma bheda vat vidyā bhedaḥ iti pūrvapakṣa sūtra uktāḥ hetavaḥ darśitāḥ te kecid siddhānte pūrvapakṣe ca atra upayuñjanta
translated: The reasons stated in the pūrvapakṣa sūtra that the difference in knowledge is like the difference in rituals due to the difference in arthavāda seeing other meanings are used in the siddhānta and pūrvapakṣa here.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tathā śabda antara abhyāsa saṃkhyā guṇa prakriyā nāmadheyāni karma bhedakāni
translated: Similarly, the difference of injunctions is indicated by the difference of words, repetition, number, quality, process, and names.

original: tatra nāmadheyaṃ guṇo rūpamabhyāsaśceti trayaṃ vyākhyātaṃ /
analyzed: tatra nāmadheyam guṇaḥ rūpam abhyāsaḥ ca iti trayam vyākhyātam
translated: Among them, name, quality, and repetition - these three have been explained.

analyzed: yajet dadyāt juhuyāt iti prakṛti śabda bhedena dhātvartha bhedāt tad avacchinna bhāvanā ākhya karma bhedaḥ uktaḥ tathā atra veda upāste ityādi śabda bhedāt vidyā bhedaḥ
translated: It is said that the difference of injunctions called bhāvanā is indicated by the difference in the meaning of the root due to the difference in the original words such as 'yajeta', 'dadyāt', 'juhuyāt'. Similarly, here, the difference in vidyā is indicated by the difference in words such as 'vedopāsīta' etc.

original: 'tisra āhutīrjuhoti'iti saṃkhyayā karmabhedavat 'vāyuprāṇau'iti dvitvasaṃkhyayā saṃvargavidyābhedaḥ syāt /

translated: Just as the difference in action is indicated by the number 'atitisra āhutīrjuhoti' (one offers three oblations), similarly, the difference in the saṃvarga-vidyā would be indicated by the number 'two' in 'vāyu-prāṇau' (vāyu and prāṇa).

translated: Even so, the qualities of being dear, having a head, etc. are not applicable to other things.🔽The teacher has shown this to be the mere principle, that the qualities of Brahman, such as being dear, having a head, etc. are not applicable to other things.

original: sa ca nyāyo 'nyeṣu niściteṣu brahmadharmeṣūpāsanāyopadiśyamāneṣu netavyaḥ saṃyadvāmādiṣu satyakāmādiṣu ca /

translated: Smṛti also declares this, He is the embodied one, he is the first, he is called the person;🔽he is the creator of the beings, he, Brahmā, existed in the beginning Śve Up ,🔽The Aitareyins also in the preceding part of the chapter beginning with the words, Now then of the seed of Prajāpati, the gods, describe a manifold creation effected by Prajāpati🔽The word Self also is seen to be applied to him, He was this world in the beginning, the person of the form of an embodied being Bṛ Up , ,🔽The assertion of unity also is possible, if referred to the time before creation, and to the created effects of Brahman🔽The act of looking also is possible, as Brahman is admitted to be intelligent

translated: Smṛti also declares that Brahman is the cause of the world, He is the first embodied soul, he is called the person, the primeval creator of the beings, Brahman existed in the beginning Śve Up , , and that the world is evolved from him, He is all this, he is the Self, he is to be known Bṛ Up , , 0 The Aitareyins also in the chapter preceding the one quoted by the pūrvapakṣin describe the creation as the work of Prajāpati, Now, then, of the seed of Prajāpati; the gods are the seed Bṛ Up , , 0 The word Self also is seen to be applied to him, He was this world in the beginning, the person of the form of an individual Bṛ Up , , 0 The determination of unity also is possible, if we consider that the Self is the cause of its own effects The act of looking also is possible, if we admit that Brahman is endowed with consciousness Moreover, we observe in ordinary life that the word Self is applied to particular individual souls, as is seen from such expressions as those souls which he brought from there, bring hither the cow, bring hither the horse, bring hither the man, they said Bṛ Up , , 0, which refer to a multitude of particular acts of the souls For this reason we conclude that the word Self in the passage under discussion also denotes a particular individual soul To this we make the following reply The word Self denotes the highest Self only, like other words denoting particular individual souls

analyzed: athavā ācamanam eva vidīyate  vispaṣṭā hi tasmin vidhi vibhaktiḥ tasmāt evaṃvid aśṣyan ācāmet aśitvā ca ācāmet iti
translated: Or only the sipping of water is to be enjoined.🔽For the injunctive suffix is clearly seen in that, ‘One who knows this, when he is going to eat, should sip water and after eating should sip water.’

original: tasyaiva stutyarthamanagnatāsaṃkīrtanamiti /🔽evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ nācamanasya vidheyatvamupapadyate kāryākhyānāt /
analyzed: tasya eva stuti artham anagna tā saṃkīrtanam iti  evam prāpte brūmaḥ na ācamanasya vidheya tvam upapadyate kārya ākhyānāt
translated: The mention of the breath as free from fire is for the purpose of praising that act of sipping water.🔽To this we reply: The sipping of water cannot be enjoined, because it is already known from Smṛti.

analyzed: prāptam eva hi idam kārya tvena ācamanam prāyatyā artham smṛti prasiddham anvākhyāyate
translated: For the sipping of water as a means of purification is already known as an act to be performed, and is here mentioned as such.

analyzed: nanu iyam śrutiḥ tasyāḥ smṛteḥ mūlam syāt
translated: But this Vedic text might be the basis of that Smṛti text.

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: No, we reply.

analyzed: viṣaya nānātvāt
translated: Because the subjects are different.

original: sāmānyaviṣayā hi smṛtiḥ puruṣamātrasaṃbaddhaṃ prāyatyārthamācamanaṃ prāpayati /
analyzed: sāmānya viṣayā hi smṛtiḥ puruṣa mātra saṃbaddham prāyatyā artham ācamanam prāpayati
translated: The Smṛti text has a general subject; it enjoins the sipping of water which is connected with man in general, for the purpose of purification.

analyzed: śrutiḥ tu prāṇa vidyā prakaraṇa paṭhitā tad vaṣayam eva ācamanam vidadhatī vidadhyāt
translated: But the Vedic text, being recited in the context of the knowledge of the vital air, would enjoin the sipping of water which has that (vital air) for its subject.

analyzed: na ca bhinna viṣayayoḥ śruti smṛtyoḥ mūla mūli bhāvaḥ
translated: And it is not possible for a Vedic text and a Smṛti text, which have different subjects, to stand in the relation of basic and based.

analyzed: na ca iyam śrutiḥ prāṇa vidyā saṃyogi a pūrvam ācamanam vidhāsyati iti śakyam āśrayitum
translated: And it cannot be maintained that this Vedic text will enjoin the sipping of water which is connected with the knowledge of the vital air, as something not already enjoined.

analyzed: pūrvasya eva puruṣa mātra saṃyoginaḥ ācamanasya iha pratyabhijñāyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the same sipping of water which is connected with man in general is recognized here.

analyzed: atas eva ca na ubhaya vidhānam
translated: And for this very reason, it is not an injunction of both (the sipping of water before and after eating).

analyzed: ubhaya vidhāne ca vākyam bhidyeta
translated: And if it were an injunction of both, the sentence would be split.

original: tasmātprāptamevāśisiṣatāmaśitavatāṃ cobhayata ācamanamanūdya 'etameva tadanamanagnaṃ kurvanto manyante' bṛ / / /
analyzed: tasmāt prāptam eva aśisiṣatām aśitavatām ca ubhayatas ācamanam anūdya etam eva tat anam anagnam kurvantaḥ manyante bṛ
translated: Therefore, the sipping of water on both sides (before and after eating), which is already established for those who are hungry and those who have eaten, is referred to, and they think that they are making that (sipping of water) not-hot.

analyzed: iti prāṇasya anagna tā karaṇa saṃkalpaḥ nena vākyena ācamanīyāsu apsu prāṇa vidyā saṃbandhi tvena apūrvaḥ upadiśyate
translated: Thus the resolution to make the vital air not hot is taught in this sentence as a new rite connected with the water for sipping, in the knowledge of the vital air.

analyzed: na ca ayam anagna tā vādaḥ ācamana stuti arthaḥ iti nyāyyam
translated: And it is not proper to say that this statement about not being hot is for the praise of sipping.

analyzed: ācamanasya a vidheya tvāt
translated: Because sipping is not enjoined.

analyzed: svayam ca anagna tā saṃkalpasya vidheya tva pratīteḥ
translated: And because the resolution to be not hot is itself understood to be enjoined.

original: nacaivaṃ satyekasyācamanasyobhayārthatābhyupagatā bhavati prāyatyārthatā paridhānārthā cheti /
analyzed: na ca evam sati ekasya ācamanasya ubhaya artha tā abhyupagatā bhavati prāyatya artha tā paridhāna arthā cha iti
translated: And if this is so, it is not accepted that a single sipping serves both purposes, being for the purpose of purification and for the purpose of clothing.

original: kriyāntaratvābhyupagamāt kriyāntarameva hyācamanaṃ nāma prāyatyārthaṃ puruṣasyābhyupagamyate /
analyzed: kriyā antara tva abhyupagamāt kriyā antaram eva hi ācamanam nāma prāyatyā artham puruṣasya abhyupagamyate
translated: Because it is accepted as a separate rite. For sipping, which is a separate rite for the purpose of purification, is accepted for a person.

original: tadīyāsu tvapsu vāsaḥsaṃkalpanaṃ nāma kriyāntarameva paridhānārthaṃ prāṇasyābhyupagamyata ityanavadyam /🔽apica 'yadidaṃ kiñcāśvasya ā kṛmibhya ā kīṭapataṅgebhyastatte 'nnam bṛ / / /
analyzed: tadīyāsu tu apsu vāsaḥ saṃkalpanam nāma kriyā antaram eva paridhāna artham prāṇasya abhyupagamyate iti anavadyam  apica yat idam kiñca aśvasya ā kṛmibhyaḥ ā kīṭa pataṅgebhyaḥ tat te nnam bṛ
translated: But the resolution of the garment in its water is accepted as a separate rite for the purpose of clothing the vital air. Thus there is no fault.

analyzed: iti atra sarvānna abhyavahāraḥ codyate iti śakyam vaktum
translated: Moreover, it can be said that the eating of all food is enjoined in the text, Whatever there is from the horse to the worm, to the insect and the moth, that is your food.

analyzed: a śabda tvāt aśakya tvāt ca
translated: Because it is not mentioned in the text and because it is impossible.

original: sarvaṃ tu prāṇasyānnamitīyamannadṛṣṭiścodyate tatsāhacaryāccāpo vāsa ityatrāpi nāpāmācamanaṃ codyate prasiddhāsvevatvācamanīyāsvapsu paridhānadṛṣciścodyata
analyzed: sarvam tu prāṇasya annam iti iyam anna dṛṣṭiḥ codyate tad sāhacaryāt ca apaḥ vāsaḥ iti atra api na apām ācamanam codyate prasiddhāsu eva tu ācamanīyāsu apsu paridhāna dṛṣciḥ codyata
translated: But the view of water as clothing is enjoined, and because of the connection with that, even here in the statement water is clothing, the sipping of water is not enjoined. The view of water as clothing that is well-known is enjoined.

analyzed: iti yuktam
translated: Thus it is proper.

analyzed: na hi ardhavaiśasam saṃbhavati  api ca ācāmanti iti vartamāna apadeśi tvam śabdaḥ vidhi kṣamaḥ
translated: For a half-oblation is not possible.🔽Moreover, the statement they sip is capable of enjoining, being in the present tense.

analyzed: nanu manyante iti api samānam vartamāna apadeśi tvam
translated: But the statement they think also has the same present tense form.

analyzed: satyam evam etat
translated: This is true.

original: avaśyavidheye tvanyatarasminvāsaḥkāryākhyānādapāṃ vāsaḥsaṃkalpanamevāpūrvaṃ vidhīyate nācamanaṃ pūrvavaddhi tadityupapāditam /
analyzed: avaśya vidheye tu anyatarasmin vāsaḥ kārya ākhyānāt apām vāsaḥ saṃkalpanam eva apūrvam vidhīyate na ācamanam pūrvavat hi tat iti upapāditam
translated: But when one of them must be enjoined, the mere thinking of water as clothing is enjoined as a new unseen result, because of the statement about the function of clothing. Sipping is not enjoined, as it is already established. This has been explained.

original: yadapyuktaṃ vispaṣṭā cācamane vidhivibhaktiriti tadapi pūrvavattvenaivācamanasya pratyuktam /
analyzed: yat api uktam vispaṣṭā ca ācamane vidhi vibhaktiḥ iti tat api pūrvavat tvena eva ācamanasya pratyuktam
translated: And what was said about the clear injunctive suffix in the sipping, that is also answered by the fact that the sipping is already established.

original: ata evācamanasyāvidhitsitatvādetameva tadanamanagnaṃ kurvanto manyanta ityatraiva kāṇvāḥ paryavasyanti nāmananti tasmādevaṃvidityādi /
analyzed: atas eva ācamanasya a vidhitsita tvāt etam eva tat anam anagnam kurvantaḥ manyante iti atra eva kāṇvāḥ paryavasyanti na āmananti tasmāt evaṃvid ityādi
translated: For this very reason, because the sipping is not intended to be enjoined, the Kāṇvas conclude right there in the statement they think that he is not naked by merely this, and do not continue with therefore one who knows thus... etc.

original: tasmānmādhyandinānāmapi pāṭha ācamanānuvādenaivaṃvittvameva prakṛtaprāṇavāsovittvaṃ vidhīyata iti pratipattavyam /
analyzed: tasmāt mādhyandinānām api pāṭhe ācamana anuvādena evaṃvid tvam eva prakṛta prāṇa vāsaḥ vid tvam vidhīyate iti pratipattavyam
translated: Therefore, it should be understood that even in the Madhyandina recension, the knowledge of the person who knows thus, which is the subject of the injunction to sip water, is enjoined as the knowledge of the abode of the vital air which is the subject-matter of the context.

original: yo 'pyayamabhyupagamaḥ kvacidācamanaṃ vidhīyate kvacidvāsovijñānamiti so 'pi na sādhuḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ pi ayam abhyupagamaḥ kvacid ācamanam vidhīyate kvacid vāsaḥ vijñānam iti saḥ u pi na sādhuḥ
translated: The assumption that in some places sipping water is enjoined and in some places the knowledge of the abode is enjoined is also not proper.

original: āpo vāsa ityādikāyā vākyapravṛtteḥ sarvatraikarūpyāt tasmādvāsovijñānameveha vidhīyate nācamanamiti nyāyyam // //
analyzed: āpaḥ vāsaḥ ityādikāyāḥ vākya pravṛtteḥ sarvatra aikarūpyāt tasmāt vāsaḥ vijñānam eva iha vidhīyate na ācamanam iti nyāyyam  /
translated: Because the statement beginning with 'water is the abode' is everywhere of the same form, therefore it is proper to conclude that only the knowledge of the abode is enjoined here, not the sipping of water.

analyzed: kārya ākhyānāt apūrvam
translated: The unseen act is to be inferred from the statement of the result.

original: 'me kimannaṃ kiṃ vāsaḥ'iti prāṇena pṛṣṭā vāgādayaḥ ūcuḥ /
analyzed: me kim annam kim vāsaḥ iti prāṇena pṛṣṭāḥ vāc ādayaḥ ūcuḥ
translated: When asked by the vital air, 'What is food? What is clothing?' speech and the others said,

original: 'yadidaṃ kiṃ cāśvabhya ā kṛmibhyastatte 'nnamāpo vāsaḥ'iti sarvaprāṇibhirbhujyamānaṃ
analyzed: yat idam kim ca aśvabhyaḥ ā kṛmibhyaḥ tat te nnam āpaḥ vāsaḥ iti sarva prāṇibhiḥ bhujyamānam
translated: 'Whatever there is from horses to worms, that is your food, water is clothing.'

original: yadidaṃ prasiddhaṃ śvādiparyantamannaṃ tatprāṇasya tavānnamāpa ācchādanamityupāsakena
analyzed: yat idam prasiddham śva ādi paryantam annam tat prāṇasya tava annam āpaḥ ācchādanam iti upāsakena
translated: The well-known food that extends from horses to worms, that is your food, O vital air. Water is the covering.

analyzed: cintanīyam iti arthaḥ
translated: This is what the worshipper should think about, is the meaning.

analyzed: śākhā dvaye pi aviśeṣa śrutim uktvā viśeśaṣa śruti bhedam āha anantaram ca iti
translated: After stating the non-distinction in both branches, he states the difference in the statements of distinction.

analyzed: tasmāt apām prāṇa vastra tvāt aśiśaṣyantaḥ śanam kurvantaḥ śrotriyāḥ etat kurvanti
translated: Therefore, the learned, while not eating, i.e. while fasting, perform this act, because water is the garment of the vital breaths.

original: kiṃ tat / bhojanātpūrvamūrdhvaṃ cācāmantīti yattadadbhiḥ prāṇaṃ paridadhatyācchādayantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: kim tat bhojanāt pūrvam ūrdhvam ca ācāmanti iti yat tat adbhiḥ prāṇam paridadhati ācchādayanti iti arthaḥ
translated: What is that? They sip water before and after meals. The meaning is that they cover the vital breath with water.

analyzed: pūrva uttara ācamana saṃbandhinīṣu apsu prāṇa vāsas tva cintana rūpam anagna tā dhyānam kāryam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the meditation on the vital breath as the garment, in the form of thinking of it as not being naked, should be done in the waters related to the first and second sippings.

original: tat tasmādityuktārthaṃ yataḥ pūrve vidvāṃso 'śanātprāgūrdhvaṃ cācāmanta etamevānāṃ prāṇaṃ tattenācamanenānagnamācchāditaṃ kurvanto manyante
analyzed: tat tasmāt iti ukta artham yatas pūrve vidvāṃsaḥ śanāt prāk ūrdhvam ca ācāmante etam eva anām prāṇam tat tena ācamanena anagnam ācchāditam kurvantaḥ manyante
translated: That, for the above-mentioned reason, the ancient learned ones sipped water before and after meals, considering that very vital breath of the ancestors to be covered by that sipping.

analyzed: tasmāt evaṃvid idānīntanaḥ pi upāsakaḥ evam kuryāt iti vāji śruti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the Vajaśruti is that one who knows this should do likewise even today.

analyzed: atra ubhayoḥ api apūrva tvāt saṃśayam āha tat kim iti
translated: Here, since both are new, he raises the doubt with Is that so?

original: saṃdigdhasadupakramasya vākyaśeṣānnirṇayavadācāmantīti padasya vidhitvasaṃdehe ācāmediti vākyaśeṣādvidhitvanirṇaya iti dṛṣṭāntasaṃgatyā pūrvapakṣamāhakiṃ 🔽tāvaditi /
analyzed: saṃdigdha sat upakramasya vākyaśeṣāt nirṇaya vat ācāmanti iti padasya vidhi tva saṃdehe ācāmet iti vākyaśeṣāt vidhi tva nirṇayaḥ iti dṛṣṭānta saṃgatyā pūrvapakṣam āha kim 🔽tāvat iti
translated: Just as the determination is made from the supplementary passages of the one whose beginning is doubtful, similarly, in the doubt of the injunctive nature of the word they sip, the determination of the injunctive nature is made from the supplementary passage one should sip. With this analogy, he presents the prima facie view with What then?
The connection of the topic should be understood from the consideration of the injunctions regarding the means of knowledge and the auxiliaries of meditation.

original: pūrvapakṣe prāṇavidyāṅgatvenāpūrvācamanaṃ vihitamanyatropasaṃhartavyamiti phalaṃ🔽siddhānte tasyāvidheyatvānnāṅgatvenopasaṃhāra iti vivekaḥ ubhayavidhāne vākyabhedaḥ
analyzed: pūrvapakṣe prāṇa vidyā aṅga tvena apūrva ācamanam vihitam anyatra upasaṃhartavyam iti phalam  siddhānte tasya avidheya tvāt na aṅga tvena upasaṃhāraḥ iti vivekaḥ ubhaya vidhāne vākya bhedaḥ
translated: In the prima facie view, the previously unknown sipping is enjoined as an auxiliary to the knowledge of the vital breath, and should be included elsewhere. The result is🔽In the conclusion, due to its not being enjoined, it is not included as an auxiliary. The distinction is that. If both are enjoined, there would be a split of the sentence.

analyzed: syāt iti arucyā pakṣa antaram āha athavā iti
translated: Out of dislike for that, he states another view, saying Or else.

original: praśastaṃ hīdamācamanaṃ yasmādanena prāṇamanagnaṃ manyanta iti stutiḥ /
analyzed: praśastam hi idam ācamanam yasmāt anena prāṇam anagnam manyante iti stutiḥ
translated: This sipping is praiseworthy, because by this they consider the vital breath to be unburned. This is praise.

analyzed: prasiddha anuvādena aprasiddham vidheyam iti nyāyena siddhāntayati evam iti
translated: By the principle that what is well-known is restated, what is not well-known is to be enjoined, he concludes in the same way.

analyzed: prayatasya prayatnavataḥ bhāvaḥ prāyatyaṃśuddhiḥ tad artham iti arthaḥ
translated: The state of being pure, the state of being purified, is for that purpose. This is the meaning.

original: smṛtyā śudyarthaṃ kāryatvena vihitasakalakarmāṅgatayā prāptācamanānuvādenāpūrvamanagnatādhyānameva vidhīyata iti sūtrārthaḥ /
analyzed: smṛtyā śudi artham kārya tvena vihita sakala karma aṅga tayā prāpta ācamana anuvādena apūrvam anagna tā dhyānam eva vidhīyate iti sūtra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the sutra is that by the restatement of the sipping that is obtained as an auxiliary to all the rites enjoined for the purpose of purification by smrti, the unseen meditation on being unburned is itself enjoined.

original: smārtamācamanaṃ śrutyā nānūdyate kiṃ tvanayā śrutyā vihitaṃ samṛtyānūdyata iti śaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: smārtam ācamanam śrutyā na anūdyate kim tu anayā śrutyā vihitam samṛtyā anūdyate iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: He doubts, saying But is not the sipping enjoined by smrti not restated by the Vedic text? Rather, what is enjoined by this Vedic text is restated by smrti.

analyzed: śruti smṛtyoḥ anayoḥ na mūla mūli bhāvaḥ bhinna viṣaya tvāt iti pariharati na iti
translated: To this he replies: No.

analyzed: dvijaḥ nityam upaspṛśa iti ādyā smṛtiḥ ācamana antara vidhim upetya mūla mūli tvam nirastam
translated: The Smṛti text beginning with 'The twice-born should always sip water' is taken as enjoining another sipping, and the relation of root and derivative is rejected.

analyzed: saṃprati vidhiḥ asiddhaḥ iti āha na ca iyam śrutiḥ iti
translated: Now he says that the injunction is not established: And this Vedic text...

analyzed: atas eva iti ācamana vidhi abhāvāt eva iti arthaḥ
translated: For this very reason, meaning for the very reason that there is no injunction of sipping.

original: apsu prāṇavāsastvadhyānākhyaḥ saṃkalpaḥ prāṇavidyāṅgatvena vidhīyata ityāhatasmāditi /
analyzed: apsu prāṇa vāsaḥ tu adhyāna ākhyaḥ saṃkalpaḥ prāṇa vidyā aṅgatvena vidhīyate iti āha tasmāt iti
translated: The resolve called meditation on the abode of the vital airs in water is enjoined as a subsidiary to the knowledge of the vital airs. He says: Therefore...

analyzed: svayam ca iti apūrva tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And by itself, meaning because it is not a restatement.

original: śudyarthaṃ viniyuktasyācamanasya prāṇācchādanārthatvaṃ viruddhamityāśaṅkyāhana caivaṃ satīti /
analyzed: śudi artham viniyuktasya ācamanasya prāṇa ācchādana artha tvam viruddham iti āśaṅkya āha na ca evam sati iti
translated: Fearing that the purpose of the sipping enjoined for the sake of purification would be contradicted by the purpose of covering the vital airs, he says: And in that case...

analyzed: ācamanasya ācchādana artha tvam asiddham iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the purpose of the sipping as covering is not established.

original: kiñca yathā pūrvavākye prāṇasyānnadhyānamaṅgaṃ vihitaṃ tathātrāpsu vāsodhyānaṃ vidhīyate
analyzed: kiñca yathā pūrva vākye prāṇasya anna dhyānam aṅgam vihitam tathā atra apsu vāsaḥ dhyānam vidhīyate
translated: Moreover, just as in the previous sentence the meditation on food of the vital air is enjoined as a subsidiary, so here the meditation on the abode in water is enjoined.

analyzed: anyathā ācamana vidhau pūrvatra dhyāna vidhiḥ uttaratra kriyā vidhiḥ iti ardha vaiśasam syāt iti āha api ca iti
translated: Otherwise, if the sipping were enjoined, the meditation would be enjoined in the previous sentence and the action in the subsequent sentence, which would be a half-verse. He says: Moreover...

original: bhakṣayediti śabdābhāvācchvādyannasya sarvasya manuṣveṇepāsakena bhoktumaśakyatvācca na pūrvavākye kriyāvidhirityarthaḥ /
analyzed: bhakṣayet iti śabda abhāvāt śvādi annasya sarvasya manuṣveṇa īpāsakena bhoktum aśakya tvāt ca na pūrva vākye kriyā vidhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the previous sentence there is no injunction of an action, because there is no word 'bhakṣayet' (should eat) and because it is impossible for a human being to eat all food that is to be chewed.

original: itaścācamanamatra na vidheyamityāhaapiceti /🔽anagnaṃ manyanta ityatra vāsastvadhyānamapi na vidheyaṃ doṣasāmyaditi śaṅkatenanviti /
analyzed: itas ca ācamanam atra na vidheyam iti āha api ca iti  anagnam manyante iti atra vāsastva dhyānam api na vidheyam doṣa sāmyat iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: And for this reason also, rinsing the mouth is not to be enjoined here - thus he says 'api ca' (and moreover).🔽In the sentence 'they consider him not to be in the fire', meditation on the garment is also not to be enjoined, due to the same fault - thus he doubts with 'nanu'.

original: ubhayorapyanuvādatve vaiphalyādavaśyamekānuvādenaikaṃ vidheyaṃ tacca vidheyaṃ vāsodhyānameva vāsaḥ kāryasyānagnatvasyākhyānādapūrvatvācceti
analyzed: ubhayoḥ api anuvāda tve vaiphalyāt avaśyam eka anuvādena ekam vidheyam tat ca vidheyam vāsaḥ dhyānam eva vāsaḥ kāryasya anagna tvasya ākhyānāt apūrva tvāt ca iti
translated: If both are restatements, they are useless. Therefore, one must be enjoined by restating the other. And that which is to be enjoined is the meditation on the garment, because the garment is mentioned as the cause of not being in the fire, and because it is not already known.

analyzed: samādhāna arthaḥ
translated: The purpose of the solution is

original: pūrvavaditi smṛtyā prāptamityarthaḥ /🔽ācāmediti na vidhiḥ kintu viṣṇurūpāṃśu yaṣṭavya itivadanuvāda ityatra liṅgamāhaata eveti /
analyzed: pūrvavat iti smṛtyā prāptam iti arthaḥ  ācāmet iti na vidhiḥ kintu viṣṇu rūpa aṃśu yaṣṭavyaḥ iti vat anuvādaḥ iti atra liṅgam āha atas eva iti
translated: that it is obtained by the Smṛti as before. The meaning is that it is obtained by the Smṛti as before.🔽The word 'ācāmet' (should rinse) is not an injunction, but a restatement, like 'Viṣṇu should be worshipped in the form of water'. The reason for this is stated with 'ata eva' (for this very reason).

original: astyātharvaṇikānāmupaniṣadārambhe mantrasamāmnāyaḥ 'sarvaṃ pravidhya hṛdayaṃ pravidhya dhamanīḥ pravṛjya śiro 'bhipravṛjyatridhā vipṛktaḥ'
analyzed: asti ātharvaṇikānām upaniṣad ārambhe mantra samāmnāyaḥ sarvam pravidhya hṛdayam pravidhya dhamanīḥ pravṛjya śiraḥ bhipravṛjya tridhā vipṛktaḥ  /
translated: At the beginning of the Upanishad of the Atharvaveda, there is a recitation of mantras: 'Having pierced through everything, having pierced through the heart, having cut the arteries, having cut the head, having separated in three ways'

analyzed: ityādiḥ

original: kaṭhānāṃ taittirīyāṇāṃ 'śaṃ no mitraḥ śaṃ varuṇaḥ' tai / / / ityādiḥ /
analyzed: kaṭhānām taittirīyāṇām śam naḥ mitraḥ śam varuṇaḥ te ityādiḥ
translated: The Kaṭhas, the Taittirīyas, have the mantra beginning with May Mitra be auspicious to us, may Varuṇa (Taitt. Āraṇyaka 1.11.1).

original: vājasaneyināṃ tūpaniṣadārambhe pravargyabrāhmaṇaṃ paṭhyate 'devā ha vai niṣeduḥ' ityādi /🔽kauṣītakināmapyagniṣṭomabrāhmaṇam 'brahma vā agniṣṭomo brahmaiva tadaharbrahmaṇaiva te brahmopayanti te 'mṛtatvamāpnuvanti ya etadaharupayanti'
analyzed: vājasaneyinām tu upaniṣad ārambhe pravargya brāhmaṇam paṭhyate devāḥ ha vai niṣeduḥ ityādi  kauṣītakinām api agniṣṭoma brāhmaṇam brahma vai agniṣṭomaḥ brahma eva tat ahar brahmaṇā eva te brahma upayanti te mṛta tvam āpnuvanti ye etat ahar upayanti
translated: At the beginning of the Upaniṣads of the Vājasaneyins, the Pravargya Brāhmaṇa is recited, beginning with The gods indeed sat down (Taitt. Āraṇyaka 1.1.1).

analyzed: iti
translated: The Kauṣītakins also have the Agniṣṭoma Brāhmaṇa, beginning with The Agniṣṭoma is indeed Brahman, that day is indeed Brahman. They who perform that day attain Brahman, they attain immortality, those who perform this day (Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad 1.1).

original: kimime sarve pravidhyamādayo mantrāḥ pravargyādīni ca karmāṇi vidyāsūpasaṃhriyerankiṃvā nopasaṃhriyeranniti mīmāṃsāmahe /
analyzed: kim ime sarve pravidhyam ādayaḥ mantrāḥ pravargya ādīni ca karmāṇi vidyāsu upasaṃhriyeran kiṃvā na upasaṃhriyeran iti mīmāṃsāmahe
translated: Should all these mantras beginning with the Praviṇḍa, and the rituals beginning with the Pravargya, be included in the knowledge, or should they not be included? We consider this.

original: kiṃ tāvannaḥ pratibhāti upasaṃhāra evaiṣāṃ vidyāsviti /
analyzed: kim tāvat naḥ pratibhāti upasaṃhāraḥ eva eṣām vidyāsu iti
translated: What appears to us first is that they should indeed be included in the knowledge.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: vidyā pradhānānām upaniṣad granthānām samīpe pāṭhāt
translated: Because they are recited near the Upaniṣad texts, which are primarily about knowledge.

analyzed: nanu eṣām vidyā artha tayā vidhānam na upalabāmahe
translated: But we do not perceive an injunction of them as having the purpose of knowledge.

analyzed: bāḍham
translated: True.

analyzed: an upalabhamānāḥ api tu anumāsyāmahe saṃnidhi sāmārthyāt

analyzed: nahi saṃnidheḥ arthavat tve saṃbhavati akasmāt asau an āśrayitum yuktaḥ
translated: For, if proximity has a meaning, it is not proper to assume a meaninglessness.

translated: And how can we understand that the rites such as the Pravargya, which are employed for other purposes, are also for the purpose of knowledge?

original: naiṣa doṣaḥ /🔽sāmarthyaṃ tāvanmantrāṇāṃ vidyāviṣayamapi kiñcicchakyaṃ kalpayituṃ hṛdayādisaṃkīrtanāt /

translated: This is not a fault.🔽It is possible to imagine some power of the Mantras with regard to knowledge also, because of the mention of the heart etc.

analyzed: hṛdaya ādīni hi prayeṇa upāsaneṣu āyatana ādi bhāvena upadiṣṭāni tad dvāreṇa ca hṛdayam pravidhya iti evañjātīyakānām mantrāṇām upapannam upāsana aṅga tvam  dṛṣṭaḥ ca upāsaneṣu api mantra viniyogaḥ bhūḥ prapadye munā amunā amunā chā
translated: For the heart etc. are generally taught as the abode etc. in the meditations. Through that, it is proper for Mantras of the type 'pierce the heart' to be parts of meditation.

original: ityevamādiḥ /🔽tathā pravargyādīnāṃ karmaṇāmanyatrāpi viniyuktānāṃ satāmaviruddho vidyāsu viniyogo vājapeya iva bṛhaspatisavasyeti /🔽evaṃ prāpte brūmaḥ
analyzed: iti evamādiḥ 🔽tathā pravargya ādīnām karmaṇām anyatra api viniyuktānām satām aviruddhaḥ vidyāsu viniyogaḥ vājapeye iva bṛhaspatisavasya iti 🔽evam prāpte brūmaḥ
translated: And the application of Mantras is seen in meditations also, such as 'I enter the earth with this, with this, with this' (Chā.

analyzed: na eṣām upasaṃhāraḥ vidyāsu iti
translated: They are not to be combined with the vidyās.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: vedha artha bhedāt
translated: Because of the difference in the purpose.

original: hṛdayaṃ pravidhyetyevañjātīyakānāṃ hi mantrāṇāṃ yer'thā hṛdayavedhādayo bhinnā anabhisaṃbaddhāsta upaniṣaduditābhirvidyābhiḥ /
analyzed: hṛdayam pravidhya iti evañjātīyakānām hi mantrāṇām ye ṛthāḥ hṛdaya vedha ādayaḥ bhinnāḥ an abhisaṃbaddhāḥ te upaniṣad uditābhiḥ vidyābhiḥ
translated: For the purposes of the mantras of the kind ‘pierce the heart’ are different, such as piercing the heart, and are not connected with the vidyās taught in the Upaniṣads.

analyzed: na teṣām tābhiḥ saṃgantum sāmarthyam asti
translated: They have no power to be combined with those.

analyzed: nanu hṛdayasya upāsaneṣu api upayogāt tad dvārakaḥ upāsana saṃbandhaḥ upanyastaḥ
translated: But since the heart is useful in the meditations, the connection of the meditation is stated through that door.

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: It is said: No.

original: hṛdayamātrasaṃkīrtanasya hyevamupayogaḥ kathañcidutprekṣyeta naca hṛdayamātramatra mantrārthaḥ /
analyzed: hṛdaya mātra saṃkīrtanasya hi evam upayogaḥ kathañcid utprekṣyeta na ca hṛdaya mātram atra mantra arthaḥ
translated: For the usefulness of merely mentioning the heart could be imagined in some way, but the meaning of the mantra here is not merely the heart.

translated: For the mantra of the kind ‘pierce the heart, cut the arteries’ is not entirely connected with the vidyās.

original: ābhicārikaviṣayo hyeṣor'thastasmādābhicārikeṇa karmaṇā sarvaṃ pravidhyetyetasya mantrasyābhisaṃbandhaḥ /

translated: For this meaning refers to magical rites. Therefore, the connection of this mantra ‘pierce everything’ is with a magical rite.

analyzed: tad viśeṣa saṃbandhaḥ tu pramāṇa antarāt anusartavyaḥ
translated: But the connection with its particularities should be followed from another means of knowledge.

original: evamanyeṣāmapi mantrāṇāṃ keṣācilliṅgena keṣāñcidvacanena keṣāñcitpramāṇāntareṇātyevamarthāntareṣu viniyuktānāṃ rahasyapaṭhitānāmapi satāṃ na

translated: In the same way, some other Mantras also, some by their indicative power, some by their words, some by other means of knowledge, are employed in other matters, and though they are recited in the Upaniṣads,

analyzed: saṃnidhi mātreṇa vidyā śeṣa tva upapattiḥ
translated: they cannot be taken as supplementary to the knowledge merely on the ground of proximity.

original: durbalo hi saṃnidhiḥ śrutyādibhya ityuktaṃ prathame tantre 'śrutiliṅgavākyaprakaraṇasthānasamākhyānāṃ samavāye pāradaurbalyamarthaviprakarṣāt'
analyzed: durbalaḥ hi saṃnidhiḥ śruti ādibhyaḥ iti uktam prathame tantre śruti liṅga vākya prakaraṇa sthāna samākhyānām samavāye pāra daurbalyam artha viprakarṣāt
translated: For proximity is weak compared to Śruti and other means of knowledge. This has been said in the first book: When Śruti, indicative power, sentence, context, position, and name are in conflict, the later is weaker than the earlier, because of remoteness from the meaning.

analyzed: iti atra
translated: In the Jaimini Sūtra.

analyzed: tathā akarmaṇām api pravargya ādīnām anyatra viniyuktānām na vidyā śeṣa tva upapattiḥ
translated: Similarly, the rites like the Pravargya, which are employed elsewhere, cannot be taken as supplementary to the knowledge.

analyzed: nahi eṣām vidyābhiḥ saha aikārthyam kiñcid asti
translated: For they have no connection with the knowledge at all.

translated: But in the Vājapeya sacrifice, the Brhaspatisava has a clear different employment: Having performed the Vājapeya, one should perform the Brhaspatisava.

original: api caiko 'yaṃ pravargyaḥ sakṛdutpanno balīyasā pramāṇenānyatra viniyukto na durbalena pramāṇenānyatrāpi viniyogamarhati /
analyzed: api ca ekaḥ yam pravargyaḥ sakṛt utpannaḥ balīyasā pramāṇena anyatra viniyuktaḥ na durbalena pramāṇena anyatra api viniyogam arhati
translated: Moreover, this one Pravargya, once produced, being employed elsewhere by a stronger means of knowledge, cannot be employed elsewhere again by a weaker means of knowledge.

original: agṛhyamāṇaviśeṣatve hi pramāṇayoretadevaṃ syānnatu balavadabalavatoḥ pramāṇayoragṛhyamāṇaviśeṣatā saṃbhavati balavadabalavattvaviśeṣādeva /
analyzed: agṛhyamāṇa viśeṣa tve hi pramāṇayoḥ etat evam syāt na tu balavat abalavatoḥ pramāṇayoḥ agṛhyamāṇa viśeṣa tā saṃbhavati balavat abalavat tva viśeṣāt eva
translated: For if the two means of knowledge were not apprehended as distinct, this might be so. But it is not possible for two means of knowledge, one strong and one weak, to be not apprehended as distinct, because of the distinction of strength and weakness itself.

original: tasmādevañjātīyakānāṃ mantrāṇāṃ karmaṇāṃ vā na saṃnidhipāṭhamātreṇa vidyāśeṣatvamāśaṅkitavyam /
analyzed: tasmāt evañjātīyakānām mantrāṇām karmaṇām vā na saṃnidhi pāṭha mātreṇa vidyā śeṣa tvam āśaṅkitavyam
translated: Therefore, in the case of mantras or actions of this kind, their being a part of the vidyā should not be suspected merely on the basis of their proximity in the text.

analyzed: araṇya anuvacana ādi dharma sāmānyāt tu saṃnidhi pāṭhaḥ iti saṃtoṣṭavyam
translated: But it should be accepted that their proximity in the text is due to the similarity of properties such as being recited in the forest.

analyzed: vedha ādi artha bhedāt
translated: Due to the difference in purpose, such as piercing, etc.

analyzed: devatām abhicāra kartā prārthayate sarvam iti
translated: The one who performs the rite of exorcism requests the deity, saying all.

original: he devate / madripoḥ sarvamaṅgaṃ pravidhya vidāraya viśeṣataśca hṛdayaṃ bhindhi dhamanīḥ śirāḥ pravṛñjaya troṭaya śiraścābhito nāśaya /
analyzed: he devate mad ripoḥ sarvam aṅgam pravidhya vidāraya viśeṣataḥ ca hṛdayam bhindhi dhamanīḥ śirāḥ pravṛñjaya troṭaya śiraḥ ca abhitas nāśaya
translated: O deity, pierce, i.e., tear apart, all the limbs of my enemy, and especially pierce his heart. Burst open his arteries and veins. Destroy his head on all sides.

original: evaṃ tridhā vipṛkto viśliṣṭo bhavatu me śatrurityarthaḥ /
analyzed: evam tridhā vipṛktaḥ viśliṣṭaḥ bhavatu me śatruḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus let my enemy be torn apart, i.e., separated in three places, is the meaning.

analyzed: he deva savitar
translated: O deity Savita.

analyzed: yajñam tad patim ca prasuva nirvartaya iti arthaḥ
translated: Impel, i.e., bring about, the sacrifice and its lord.

original: uccaiḥ śravāḥ śveto 'śvo yasyendrasya sa tvaṃ haritamaṇivannīlo 'sītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: uccais śravāḥ śvetaḥ śvas yasya indrasya sa tvam harita maṇi vat nīlaḥ si iti arthaḥ
translated: You are the Indra whose horse is Ucchaihshrava, white. You are blue like an emerald, is the meaning.

analyzed: no smākam śam sukha karaḥ bhavatu iti arthaḥ
translated: May it be well with us, i.e., may it be the cause of our happiness.

original: agniṣṭomo brahmaiva sa yasminnahani kriyate tadapi brahma tasmādya etadahaḥ sādhyaṃ
analyzed: agniṣṭomaḥ brahma eva sa yasmin ahani kriyate tat api brahma tasmāt yaḥ etat ahar sādhyam
translated: The Agniṣṭoma is Brahman itself. The day on which it is performed is also Brahman. Therefore, those who undertake this day's ritual

original: karmopayantyanutiṣṭhinti te brahmaṇaiva sādhanena brahmopayanti te ca krameṇāmṛtatvamāpnuvantīti yojanā /
analyzed: karma upayanti anutiṣṭhinti te brahmaṇā eva sādhanena brahma upayanti te ca krameṇa amṛta tvam āpnuvanti iti yojanā
translated: and perform it, they attain Brahman by means of Brahman itself as the means. And they gradually attain immortality. This is the construction.

analyzed: mantra ādiṣu tad tad upaniṣad vidyā śeṣa tve pramāṇa bhāvābhyām saṃśayam āha kim iti
translated: With regard to the Mantras etc. being the subsidiaries of the Upaniṣad knowledge of that and that, he states the doubt: What is the prima facie view?

analyzed: phalam pūrvavat
translated: The conclusion is as before.

original: nanu teṣāṃ śeṣatve mānābhāvānnopasaṃhāra iti śaṅkatenanveṣāmiti /
analyzed: nanu teṣām śeṣa tve māna abhāvāt na upasaṃhāraḥ iti śaṅkate nanu eṣām iti
translated: Now, if they are subsidiaries, there is no basis, so there is no inclusion. This is the doubt expressed by But if these...

analyzed: mantra ādayaḥ tad tad vidyā śeṣāḥ phalavat vidyā saṃnihita tvāt taittirīyaka gata puruṣa yajña vat iti samādhatte bāḍham iti
translated: The Mantras etc. are the subsidiaries of the knowledge of that and that, because of being present near the knowledge that has a result, like the Puruṣayajña in the Taittirīyaka. This is the reply given by Indeed...

analyzed: tathā ca dṛṣṭānta saṃgatiḥ
translated: And thus there is a connection with the example.

analyzed: siddhānti pakṣe saṃnidhi vaiyarthyam bādhakam āha nahi iti
translated: In the Siddhānta view, the uselessness of proximity is the objection. This is stated by But...

original: aphalamantrādīnāṃ phalavaccheṣatvabodhanaṃ saṃnidherarthavattvaṃ tatsaṃbhave satyakasmādarthaśūnyatvenāsau saṃnidhirāśrayituṃ nahi yukta ityarthaḥ
analyzed: aphala mantra ādīnām phalavat śeṣatva bodhanam saṃnidheḥ arthavattvam tad saṃbhave sati akasmāt artha śūnyatvena asau saṃnidhiḥ āśrayitum nahi yuktaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the purpose of proximity is to indicate that the fruitless mantras etc. are subsidiary to those with fruits, and when that is possible, it is not proper to rely on that proximity as being meaningless.

original: nañpāṭhetvakasmāddhetuṃ vināsāvartho nāśrayituṃ nahi yukta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: nañ pāṭha itu akasmāt hetum vinā asau arthaḥ na āśrayitum nahi yuktaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In the reading with the negative particle, the meaning is that it is not proper to rely on that meaning without a reason.

analyzed: nanu mantrāṇām vidyā samaveta artha prakāśana sāmarthya abhāvāt na vidyā śeṣa tvam iti śaṅkate nanu iti
translated: Now, since mantras do not have the ability to reveal the meaning connected with the vidya, they are not subsidiary to the vidya, this is doubted by saying but.

original: purastādupasadāṃ pravargyeṇa pracarantīti vākyena pravargyasya kratuśeṣatvaṃ śrutaṃ /
analyzed: purastāt upasadām pravargyeṇa pracaranti iti vākyena pravargyasya kratu śeṣa tvam śrutam
translated: By the sentence they perform the pravargya ritual before the upasads, the pravargya ritual is heard to be subsidiary to the sacrifice.

original: agniṣṭomādeśca tattadvākyena svargādyarthatvamato na vidyārthatvamityāhakathaṃ ceti /
analyzed: agniṣṭoma ādeḥ ca tad tad vākyena svarga ādi artha tvam atas na vidyā artha tvam iti āha katham ca iti
translated: And by the respective sentences of the agnihotra etc., their purpose is heaven etc., therefore they are not for the vidya, this is said by how then.

analyzed: mantrāṇām vidyā samaveta hṛdaya nāḍī ādi prakāśaka tvam asti iti āha na eṣaḥ iti
translated: There is the revealing of the heart-channels etc. connected with the vidya by the mantras, this is said by no.

original: upāstiṣu mantraprayogaḥ kvāpi na dṛṣṭa ityata āhadṛṣṭaśceti /
analyzed: upāstiṣu mantra prayogaḥ kvāpi na dṛṣṭaḥ iti atas āha dṛṣṭaḥ ca iti
translated: The application of mantras in the upasanas is not seen anywhere, therefore it is said and it is seen.

original: putrasya dīrghāyuṣyārthaṃ chāndogye trailokyasya keśātvenopāstiruktā tatra piturayaṃ prārthanāmantraḥ /
analyzed: putrasya dīrgha āyuṣya artham chāndogye trailokyasya keśā tvena upāstiḥ uktā tatra pituḥ ayam prārthanā mantraḥ
translated: For the long life of the son, in the Chāndogya, the worship of the three worlds as the hair of the son is mentioned. This is the prayer of the father there.

original: tatrāmuneti putrasya trirṇāma gṛhṇāti amunā putreṇa saha bhūritīmaṃ lokamamuṃ ca prapadye na me putraviyogaḥ syādityarthaḥ /

translated: There, he takes the three names of the son with 'amune'. The meaning is that he enters this world and the other world with this son, that he should not be separated from his son.

original: tattadvākyenānyatra viniyuktānāmapi karmaṇāṃ saṃnidhinā vidyāsu viniyogo na virudhyata ityatra dṛṣṭāntamāhavājapeya iti /
analyzed: tad tad vākyena anyatra viniyuktānām api karmaṇām saṃnidhinā vidyāsu viniyogaḥ na virudhyate iti atra dṛṣṭāntam āha vājapeyaḥ iti
translated: Here is the example that the application of the rites, even though employed elsewhere by those statements, is not contradicted by the proximity in the vidyās. He says 'Vājapeya'.

analyzed: brahmavarcasa kāmaḥ bṛhaspatisavena yajeta eti vākyena brahmavarcasa phale viniyuktasya api
translated: Even though the Bṛhaspatisava, which is employed in the statement 'One desiring Brahmic glory should sacrifice with the Bṛhaspatisava' with the result of Brahmic glory,

translated: the meaning is that there is no contradiction in the application as a subsequent part of the Vājapeya.

analyzed: yadi api ekena vākyena prakaraṇa antara stha bṛhaspatisavasya pratyabhijñānam aṅga tva vidhānam
translated: Although by one statement the recognition of the Bṛhaspatisava located in another context and the injunction of the subsidiary nature,

analyzed: ca kartum ayuktam vākya bheda prasaṅgāt atas māsa agnihotra vat karma antaram eva bṛhaspatisava ākhyam aṅga tayā
translated: And it is not proper to make it so, because of the undesirable consequence of split-of-the-sentence. Therefore, like the monthly Agnihotra, only another ritual called the Brihaspatisava is enjoined as a subsidiary.

original: vidhīyata iti na viniyuktasya viniyoga iti bhaṭṭagurutantradvayasiddhaṃ /
analyzed: vidhīyate iti na viniyuktasya viniyogaḥ iti bhaṭṭa guru tantra dvaya siddham
translated: Thus, there is no re-application of what has already been applied. This is established in the two systems of Bhatta and Guru.

original: yathāpi yathā nityāgnihotrasyāśvamedhaprakaraṇe vāgyatasyaitāṃ rātrimagnihotraṃ juhotīti nāmnā pratyabhijñā /
analyzed: yathā api yathā nitya agnihotrasya aśvamedha prakaraṇe vāgyatasya etām rātrim agnihotram juhoti iti nāmnā pratyabhijñā
translated: Just as in the context of the horse sacrifice, the eternal Agnihotra is recognized by name in the statement He offers the Agnihotra silently during that night,

original: yathāvā darśapūrṇamāsavikṛtīṣṭāvājyabhāgau yajatītyekasminvākye prakṛtisthājyabhāgayoḥ🔽padena pratyabhijñānaṃ vākyena vidhānaṃ tathātrāpi bṛhaspatisavapadena pratyabhijñānaṃ
analyzed: yathā vā darśa pūrṇamāsa vikṛti iṣṭau ājyabhāgau yajati iti ekasmin vākye prakṛti stha ājyabhāgayoḥ  padena pratyabhijñānam vākyena vidhānam tathā atra api bṛhaspatisava padena pratyabhijñānam
translated: or just as in the modification of the new and full moon sacrifices, the two Ajyabhagas are offered in a single sentence, and the two Ajyabhagas that are in the archetype🔽are recognized by the word, and enjoined by the sentence, why should not recognition by the word Brihaspatisava

analyzed: vākyena aṅga tā vidhānam kim na syāt
translated: and injunction of subsidiary status by the sentence occur in the same way here?

original: naca sādhyabhāvārthavidhāyakākhyātaparatantraṃ nāmapadaṃ na siddhakarmapratyabhijñākṣamamiti vācyaṃ /

translated: Because even for what is well-known, if it is possible to be to be accomplished again as a subsidiary, it is proper that the verb that is otherwise unestablished should be dependent on the nominal word that has a well-known meaning.

original: nacaivaṃ sati kuṇḍapāyisatre 'pyaṅgatvena nityāgnihotrasyaiva vidhiḥ syāditi vācyaṃ / iṣṭatvāt /

translated: And in that case, it should not be said that even in the Kuṇḍapāyināmayana, the injunction of the daily Agnihotra itself would be as a subsidiary rite, because that has already been enjoined.

analyzed: na ca pūrva tantra virodhaḥ uttara tantrasya balīyaḥ tvāt
translated: And there is no contradiction with the earlier section, because the later section is stronger.

analyzed: pūrva tantrasya svatantra paratantra bhāvanā bhede tātparyāt ca
translated: And because the earlier section is intended to distinguish the independent and dependent rites.

original: tasmādekasyaiva bṛhaspatināmakasya dhātvarthasya brahmavarcase viniyuktasyāpi vājapeyāṅgatayā viniyoga iti bhagavatpādatātparyam /
analyzed: tasmāt ekasya eva bṛhaspati nāmakasya dhātvarthasya brahmavarcase viniyuktasya api vājapeya aṅga tayā viniyogaḥ iti bhagavat pāda tātparyam
translated: Therefore, the purport of the revered teacher is that the meaning of the root, which is the same as that of the word Bṛhaspati, though employed in the injunction of Brahmavṛṣa, is employed as a part of the Vājapeya.

original: astica viniyuktasya viniyoge sarvasaṃmatamudāharaṇaṃ khādiratvādikaṃ tasya kratau viniyuktasya vīryādiphale 'pi viniyogāt /

translated: Even though the mantras are connected with the heart etc. in the vidyas, since the meanings of the mantras such as piercing etc. are not connected, and since the connection of the entire mantra meanings with the purpose of black magic etc. is indicated by the stronger proximity, the mantras are employed only in black magic etc.

analyzed: viniyogaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: deva savitar prasuva eti pradakṣiṇatas gnim paryukṣet iti vākyāt agni paryukṣaṇe sāvitram
translated: One should sprinkle around the fire clockwise with the Savitri mantra, O god Savita, impel - from this sentence, the Savitri mantra is connected with sprinkling around the fire.

original: juhoti karmaṇaḥ purastātsavane savane juhoti'iti vākyādvājapeye karmaviśeṣe saṃbandho🔽'sya mantrasyetyāhatadviśeṣeti /
analyzed: juhoti karmaṇaḥ purastāt savane savane juhoti iti vākyāt vājapeye karma viśeṣe saṃbandhaḥ  mantrasya iti āha tad viśeṣa iti
translated: One offers at the beginning of the rite, one offers at each pressing - from this sentence, this mantra is connected with the specific rite of the Vajapeya sacrifice.🔽This is what is said by in that specific rite.

analyzed: ukta nyāyam śvetāśvaḥ ityādiṣu atidiśati evam anyeṣām iti
translated: He extends the same principle to the mantras beginning with 'white horse' etc. with the words 'in the same way for others'.
'Other means of knowledge' refers to context etc.

translated: To that he says 'for, the weaker...'

analyzed: svārtha bodhane parasya pūrva vyavadhānena pravṛtteḥ iti arthaḥ  ayam āśayaḥ ekatra viniyuktasya nirākāṅkṣa tvāt anyatra viniyogaḥ viruddhaḥ eva parantu
translated: The meaning is: because the other is engaged in the communication of its own meaning through the intervention of the former.🔽The idea is this: because what is employed in one thing is not wanting in another, the employment in another is indeed contradictory. But

analyzed: viniyojaka pramāṇayoḥ sama bala tve nyatara viniyoga tyāga ayogāt agati ākāṅkṣā utpādanena  viniyukta viniyogaḥ svīkriyate yathā khādiraḥ yūpaḥ bhavati khādiram vīrya kāmasya
translated: when the authoritative texts of employment are of equal strength, it is not possible to abandon the employment by one of them. Therefore, out of necessity,🔽the employment of what is already employed is accepted by producing a want, just as in the case of the Khadira wood. The text 'The sacrificial post should be of Khadira wood' and 'One desiring vigour should make the sacrificial post of Khadira wood'

analyzed: yathā kadācana starīrasi iti asyāḥ ṛcaḥ aindryā gārhapatyam upatiṣṭhate iti tṛtīyā vibhakti śrutyā anya nirapekṣa tayā

translated: The context in the form of the principal's desire for auxiliaries is imagined by the capability of the sentence which makes the principal and auxiliary a single sentence, and the Vedic text,
