analyzed: apica iti ukta artham
translated: Moreover, api ca (in addition) states the meaning already mentioned.

original: nanu tarhi vedhādivākyānāmupaniṣadbhiḥ saha pāṭhasya kā gatistāmāhaaraṇyeti /
analyzed: nanu tarhi vedha ādi vākyānām upaniṣadbhiḥ saha pāṭhasya kā gatiḥ tām āha araṇyā iti
translated: But then, what is the status of the recitation of the Vedic injunctions etc. along with the Upanishads? He says in the forest.

analyzed: tasmāt vedha ādi mantra karmaṇām vidyāsu anupasaṃhāraḥ iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that the ritual actions of the Vedic injunctions etc. are not included in the vidyas.🔽End.

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: Start.

analyzed: hāni adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on negation. Sutra.

original: hānau tūpāyanaśabdaśeṣatvāt kuśāc chandaḥstutyupagānavat tad uktam / / / /
analyzed: hānau tu upāyana śabda śeṣa tvāt kuśāt chandaḥ stuti upagāna vat tat uktam  /
translated: But in the case of destruction, because of being a remainder of the word 'upa-yana', like the chanting of the Sāman verses after the Kusha grass, it is said.

original: asti tāṇḍānāṃ śrutiḥ 'aśva iva romāṇi vidhūya pāpaṃ candra iva rāhormukhātpramucya dhūtvā śarīramakṛtaṃ kṛtātmā brahmalokamabhisaṃbhavāmi' 🔽chā / / / iti /
analyzed: asti tāṇḍānām śrutiḥ aśvaḥ iva romāṇi vidhūya pāpam candraḥ iva rāhoḥ mukhāt pramucya dhūtvā śarīram akṛtam kṛtātmā brahma lokam abhisaṃbhavāmi  / chā iti
translated: There is a Vedic text of the Tāṇḍins: 'Shaking off evil like a horse its hairs, and being released from the mouth of Rāhu like the moon, shaking off the uncreated body, the soul, having become created, enters the world of Brahman.'

original: tathātharṇikānāma 'tathā vidvānnāmarūpādvimuktaḥ parātparaṃ puruṣamupaiti divyam' muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: tathā atha ṛṇikāḥ nāma tathā vidvān nāma rūpāt vimuktaḥ parātparam puruṣam upaiti divyam muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, the Atharṇins: 'The knower of Brahman, being released from name and form, attains the divine Puruṣa, greater than the great.'

original: tathā śāṭyāyaninaḥ paṭhanti 'tasya putrā dāyamupayanti sihṛdaḥ sādhukṛtyāṃ dviṣantaḥ pāpakṛtyām' iti /
analyzed: tathā śāṭyāyaninaḥ paṭhanti tasya putrāḥ dāyam upayanti sihṛdaḥ sādhu kṛtyām dviṣantaḥ pāpa kṛtyām iti
translated: Similarly, the Śāṭyāyanins recite: 'His sons take his wealth, the well-wishers his good deeds, the enemies his bad deeds.'

original: tathaiva kauṣītakinaḥ 'tatsukṛtaduṣkṛte vidhūnute tasya priyā jñātayaḥ sukṛtamupantyapriyā duṣkṛtam' kau / / iti /
analyzed: tathā eva kauṣītakinaḥ tat sukṛta duṣkṛte vidhūnute tasya priyāḥ jñātayaḥ sukṛtam upanti apriyāḥ duṣkṛtam kau iti
translated: Similarly, the Kauṣītakins: 'It shakes off good and bad deeds. His dear relatives take his good deeds, the hateful his bad deeds.'

original: tadiha kvacitsukṛtaduṣkṛtayorhānaṃ śrūyate kvacittayoreva vibhāgena priyairapriyaiścopāyanaṃ
analyzed: tat iha kvacid sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ hānam śrūyate kvacid tayoḥ eva vibhāgena priyaiḥ apriyaiḥ ca upāyanam
translated: So here, in some places, the destruction of good and bad deeds is heard, in some places, the taking away of those two themselves by the dear ones and the hateful ones by dividing them.

original: kvacittūbhayamapi hānamupāyanaṃ ca tadyatrobhayaṃ śrūyate tatra tāvanna kiñcidvaktavyamasti /
analyzed: kvacid tu ubhayam api hānam upāyanam ca tat yatra ubhayam śrūyate tatra tāvat na kiñcid vaktavyam asti
translated: In some places, both, the giving up and the taking up, are mentioned; and in such cases there is no need of any discussion.

original: yatrāpyupāyanameva śrūyate na hānaṃ tatrāpyarthādeva hānaṃ saṃnipatati /
analyzed: yatra api upāyanam eva śrūyate na hānam tatra api arthāt eva hānam saṃnipatati
translated: In some places, the taking up is mentioned, but not the giving up; even so, the giving up is implied by the very nature of the case.

analyzed: anyaiḥ ātmīyayoḥ sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ upeyamānayoḥ āvaśyaka tvāt tad hānasya
translated: For, when the good and evil deeds of one are taken up by others, it is necessary that they should be given up by the former.

original: yatra tu hānameva śrūyate nopāyanaṃ tatropāyanaṃ sanipatedvā na veti vicikitsāyāmaśravaṇādasaṃnipātaḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu hānam eva śrūyate na upāyanam tatra upāyanam sanipatet vā na vā iti vicikitsāyām aśravaṇāt asaṃnipātaḥ
translated: In those cases, however, where the giving up is mentioned, but not the taking up, we are in doubt whether the taking up is implied or not; and on account of the absence of any direct statement of the taking up, we conclude that it is not implied.

analyzed: vidyā antara gocara tvāt ca śākhā antarīyasya śravaṇasya
translated: And, moreover, the taking up mentioned in another Śākhā cannot be considered as implied, because it belongs to a different vidyā.

original: apicātmakartṛkaṃ sukṛtaduṣkṛtayorhānaṃ parakartṛkaṃ tūpāyanaṃ tayorasatyāvaśyakabhāve kathaṃ hānenopāyamākṣipyeta /
analyzed: api ca ātma kartṛkam sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ hānam para kartṛkam tu upāyanam tayoḥ asati āvaśyaka bhāve katham hānena upāyam ākṣipyeta
translated: Moreover, the giving up of good and evil deeds is an act of the soul itself, while the taking up is an act of another; and how can the latter be implied by the former, if there is no necessary connection between them?

original: tasmādasaṃnipāto hānāvupāyanasyeti /🔽asyāṃ prāptau paṭhati hānau tviti /🔽hānau tvetasyāṃ kevalāyāmapi śrūyamāṇāyāmupāyanaṃ saṃnipatitumarapahati /
analyzed: tasmāt asaṃnipātaḥ hānau upāyanasya iti  asyām prāptau paṭhati hānau tu iti  hānau tu etasyām kevalāyām api śrūyamāṇāyām upāyanam saṃnipatitum a rapahati
translated: Hence the taking up is not implied by the giving up.🔽In this way the pūrvapakṣin maintains that the taking up is not implied by the giving up, and that therefore the passage about the taking up of the good and evil deeds of others is to be explained as referring to the good and evil deeds of the soul itself🔽To this reasoning the Sūtrakāra replies, in the passage under discussion, But in the case of the giving up, etc

analyzed: tad śeṣa tvāt
translated: In the case of the giving up, even if that only is mentioned, the taking up is implied, because it is a complementary act

analyzed: hāna śabda śeṣaḥ hi upāyana śabdaḥ samadhigataḥ kauṣītaki rahasye
translated: For the word 'upa-yāna' is understood as a remainder of the word 'hāna' in the Kauṣītakins' Esoteric Doctrine.

analyzed: tasmāt anyatra kevala hāna śabda śravaṇe pi upāyana anuvṛttiḥ
translated: Therefore, even when only the word 'hāna' is heard elsewhere, 'upa-yāna' is to be supplied.

analyzed: yat uktam aśravaṇāt vidi antara gocara tvāt anāvaśyaka tvāt ca asaṃnipātaḥ iti
translated: What has been said, that there is no combination because it is not heard, because it belongs to a different knowledge, and because it is not necessary,

analyzed: tat ucyate
translated: that is replied.

analyzed: bhavet eṣā vyavasthā uktiḥ yadi anuṣṭheya tvena saṃkīrtyate
translated: This arrangement would be correct if it were mentioned as something to be performed.

analyzed: vidyā stuti artham tu anayoḥ saṃkīrtanam
translated: But the mention of these two is for the praise of knowledge.

original: itthaṃ mahābhāgā vidyā yatsāmarthyādasya viduṣaḥ sukṛtaduṣkṛte saṃsārakāraṇabhūte vidhūyate te cāsya suhṛdviṣatsu niviśete itai /🔽stutyarthe cāsminsaṃkīrtane hānānantarabhāvitvenopāyasya kvacicchrutatvādanyatrāpi hānaśrutāvupāyanānuvṛttiṃ manyate stutiprakarṣalābhāya /
analyzed: ittham mahābhāgā vidyā yad sāmarthyāt asya viduṣaḥ sukṛta duṣkṛte saṃsāra kāraṇa bhūte vidhūyate te ca asya suhṛd viṣatsu niviśete itai  stuti arthe ca asmin saṃkīrtane hāna anantara bhāvi tvena upāyasya kvacid śruta tvāt anyatra api hāna śrutau upāyana anuvṛttim manyate stuti prakarṣa lābhāya
translated: Thus, the knowledge is highly meritorious, by the power of which the good and bad deeds of this knower, which are the cause of worldly existence, are shaken off, and they are transferred to his friends and enemies.🔽And in this mention for the sake of praise, because the means is heard somewhere as following immediately after the giving up, he thinks that even where the giving up is heard elsewhere, the bringing should be supplied, for the sake of gaining the highest praise.

analyzed: prasiddhā ca arthavāda antara apekṣā arthavāda antara ppavṛttiḥ ekaviṃśaḥ vai sau ādityaḥ chā
translated: And it is well known that a praise refers to another meaning, as in the following: 'The sun is indeed the twenty-first', and so on.

analyzed: iti evamādiṣu
translated: In such passages.

original: kathaṃ hīhaikaviṃśatādityasyābhidhīyatānapekṣyamāṇer'thavādāntare dvādaśa māsāḥpañcartavastraya ime lokā asāvāditya ekaviṃśaḥ ityetasmin /
analyzed: katham hi iha ekaviṃśatā ādityasya abhidhīyata an apekṣyamāṇa irthavāda antare dvādaśa māsāḥ pañca ṛtavaḥ trayaḥ ime lokāḥ asau ādityaḥ ekaviṃśaḥ iti etasmin
translated: How can it be said that there are twenty-one, without reference to another explanatory passage, which says, 'The twelve months, the five seasons, these three worlds, and the sun is the twenty-first'?

original: tathā triṣṭubhau bhavataḥ sendriyatvāya ityevamādiṣu indriyaṃ vai triṣṭup ityevamādyarthavādāntarāpekṣā dṛśyate /
analyzed: tathā triṣṭubhau bhavataḥ sa indriya tvāya iti evamādiṣu indriyam vai triṣṭubh iti evamādi arthavāda antara apekṣā dṛśyate
translated: Similarly, in passages like 'There are two Tristubh meters for the sake of having sense organs', it is seen that reference is made to other explanatory passages like 'The Tristubh meter is the sense organs'.

original: vidyāstutyarthatvāccāsyopāyanavādasya kathamanyadīye sukṛtaduṣkṛte anyairupeyete iti nātīvābhiniveṣṭavyam /
analyzed: vidyā stuti artha tvāt ca asya upāyana vādasya katham anyadīye sukṛta duṣkṛte anyaiḥ upeyete iti na atīva abhiniveṣṭavyam
translated: And since this statement about taking is for the praise of knowledge, one should not be too attached to the idea that the good and bad deeds belonging to one person are taken by others.

original: upāyanaśabdaśeṣatvāditi tu śabdaśabdaṃ samuccārayanstutyarthameva hānāvupāyanānuvṛttiṃ sūcayati /
analyzed: upāyana śabda śeṣa tvāt iti tu śabda śabdam samuccārayan stuti artham eva hānau upāyana anuvṛttim sūcayati
translated: But by uttering the word 'taking' as a remainder of the word 'taking', it indicates the continuation of taking for the sake of praise.

analyzed: guṇa upasaṃhāra vivakṣāyām hi upāyana arthasya eva hāna āvṛttim brūyāt
translated: For if the intention were to combine the qualities, he would say that the taking itself is repeated in the loss.

analyzed: tasmāt guṇa upasaṃhāra vicāra prasaṅgena stuti upasaṃhāra pradarśana artham idam sūtram
translated: Therefore, this sutra is for the purpose of showing the continuation of praise as a consideration of the combination of qualities.

analyzed: kuśācchanda stuti upagāna vat iti upamā upādānam
translated: The use of the simile 'like the chanting of the Kusha grass' is for the purpose of praise.

original: tadyathā bhāllavinām 'kuśā vānaspatyāḥ stha tā mā pāta' ityetasminnigame kuśānāmaviśeṣeṇa
analyzed: tat yathā bhāllavinām kuśāḥ vānaspatyāḥ stha tāḥ mā pāta iti etasmin nigame kuśānām aviśeṣeṇa
translated: For instance, in the Nigama of the Bhallāvi Brāhmaṇas, the Kuśa grass is mentioned in the mantra, ‘Kuśas, you are the offspring of trees; protect me,’ without any distinction.

original: vanaspatiyonitvena śravaṇe śāṭyāyanināmaudumbarāḥ kuśā iti viśeṣavacanādaudumbaryaḥ kuśā āśrīyante /
analyzed: vanaspati yoni tvena śravaṇe śāṭyāyaninām audumbarāḥ kuśāḥ iti viśeṣa vacanāt audumbaryaḥ kuśāḥ āśrīyante
translated: But in the Śāṭyāyaṇi Brāhmaṇas, the Kuśas are specified as udumbara (grown on the udumbara tree).

original: yathāca kvaciddevāsuracchandasāmaviśeṣeṇa paurvāparyaprasaṅge 'devacchandāṃsi pūrvāṇi' iti paiṅgyāmnānātpratīyante /
analyzed: yathā ca kvacid deva asura chandasām aviśeṣeṇa paurvāparya prasaṅge deva chandāṃsi pūrvāṇi iti paiṅgya āmnānāt pratīyante
translated: Again, in some places, the order of the Vedic hymns of the gods and Asuras is not specified; but from the Paiṅgya Brāhmaṇa, it is understood that the hymns of the gods come first.

original: yathāca ṣoḍaśustotre keṣāñcitkālāviśeṣaprāptau 'samayādhyuṣite sūrye' ityārcaśruteḥ kālaviśeṣapratipattiḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca ṣoḍaśu stotre keṣāñcid kāla aviśeṣa prāptau samaya adhyuṣite sūrye iti ārca śruteḥ kāla viśeṣa pratipattiḥ
translated: Again, in the Ṣoḍaśincup, the time is not specified for some; but from the Ārca Brāhmaṇa, ‘When the sun has set,’ the particular time is understood.

analyzed: yathā eva ca aviśeṣeṇa upagānam kecid samāmananti viśeṣeṇa bhāllavinaḥ
translated: Again, some recite the Upa-gāna without any distinction, while the Bhallāvi Brāhmaṇas recite it with distinction.

original: yathaiteṣu kuśādiṣu śrutyantaragataviśeṣairanvaya evaṃ hānāvapyupāyanānvaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā eteṣu kuśa ādiṣu śruti antara gata viśeṣaiḥ anvayaḥ evam hānau api upāyana anvayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as the Kuśa grass and other things mentioned in the text are connected with the particular details found in other Vedic texts, in the same way, the Hāva is to be connected with the Upa-nāman. This is the meaning.

original: śrutyantarakṛtaṃ hi viśeṣaṃ śrutyantare 'nabhyupagacchataḥ sarvatraiva vikalpaḥ syāt /
analyzed: śruti antara kṛtam hi viśeṣam śruti antare na abhyupagacchataḥ sarvatra eva vikalpaḥ syāt
translated: For one who does not accept the details found in one Vedic text in another text, there would be option everywhere.

analyzed: sa ca anyāyyaḥ satyām gatau
translated: And that is improper when there is a better course.

original: taduktaṃ dvādaśalakṣaṇāyām 'api tu vākyaśeṣatvāditaraparyudāsaḥ syātpratiṣedhe vikalpaḥ syāt' iti /
analyzed: tat uktam dvādaśalakṣaṇāyām api tu vākya śeṣa tvāt itara paryudāsaḥ syāt pratiṣedhe vikalpaḥ syāt iti
translated: This has been said in the Dvādaśalakṣaṇā: ‘But, on the other hand, on account of being a supplementary passage, there would be exclusion of the other; in the prohibition there would be an option.’

analyzed: athavā etāsu eva vidhūnava śrutiṣu etena sūtreṇa etat cintayitavyam
translated: Or, in these very passages about shaking off, this matter should be considered by this aphorism.

analyzed: kim anena vidhūnana vacanena sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ hānam abhidhīyate kiṃvā artha antaram iti
translated: Is the shaking off mentioned by this passage spoken of as the destruction of good and evil deeds, or is it something else?

analyzed: tatra ca evam prāpayitavyam
translated: And there it should be brought to this conclusion:

original: na hānaṃ vidhūnanamabhidhīyate 'dhañ kampane' iti smaraṇāt /
analyzed: na hānam vidhūnanam abhidhīyate dham kampane iti smaraṇāt
translated: Shaking off is not spoken of as destruction, because of the recollection ‘dhañ, to shake’.

original: dodhūyante dhvajāgrāṇīti ca vāyunā cālyamāneṣu dhvajāgreṣu prayogadarśanāt /
analyzed: dodhūyante dhvaja agrāṇi iti ca vāyunā cālyamāneṣu dhvaja agreṣu prayoga darśanāt
translated: And because the usage is seen in ‘The tops of the flags are shaken’ when the tops of the flags are being moved by the wind.

analyzed: tasmāt cālanam vidhūnanam abhidhīyate
translated: Therefore, shaking off is spoken of as moving.

original: cālanaṃ tu suṣkṛtaduṣkṛtayoḥ kañcitkālaṃ phalapratibandhanādityevaṃ prāpayya prativaktavyam /
analyzed: cālanam tu suṣkṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ kañcid kālam phala pratibandhanāt iti evam prāpayya prativaktavyam
translated: But moving is the prevention of the fruit of good and evil deeds for some time. Having brought it to this conclusion, it should be answered:

analyzed: hānau eva eṣa vidhūyanana śabdaḥ vartitum arhati
translated: This word ‘shaking off’ can only be used for destruction.

analyzed: upāyana śabda śeṣa tvāt
translated: Because it is a supplementary passage to the word ‘taking’.

analyzed: nahi para parigraha bhūtayoḥ sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ aprahīṇayoḥ paraiḥ upāyanam saṃbhavati
translated: For as long as good and evil deeds, which are in the possession of another, are not abandoned, it is not possible for others to take them.

original: yadyapīdaṃ parakīyayoḥ sukṛtaduṣkṛtayoḥ parairupāyanaṃ nāñjasaṃ saṃbhāvyate tathāpi tatsarntanāttāvattadānuguṇyena hānameva vidhūnanaṃ nāmeti 🔽nirṇetuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: yadi api idam parakīyayoḥ sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ paraiḥ upāyanam na añjasam saṃbhāvyate tathā api tad sarntanāt tāvat tad ānuguṇyena hānam eva vidhūnanam nāma iti  nirṇetum śakyate
translated: Although it is not possible to imagine that the good and evil deeds of others can be transferred to others by any natural means, still, on account of the similarity of the two cases, it is possible to determine that the shaking off of the good and evil deeds of others is the same as the shaking off of one's own good and evil deeds.

original: kvacidapi cedaṃ vidhūnanasaṃnidhāvupāyanaṃ śrūyamāṇaṃ kuśāchandastutyupagānavadvidhanūnaśrutyā sarvatrāpekṣāmāṇaṃ sārvatrikaṃ nirṇayakāraṇaṃ 🔽saṃpadyate /
analyzed: kvacid api ca idam vidhūnana saṃnidhau upāyanam śrūyamāṇam kuśā chanda stuti upagāna vat vidha nūna śrutyā sarvatra apekṣāmāṇam sārvatrikam nirṇaya kāraṇam  saṃpadyate
translated: And this shaking off, which is mentioned in some places in the vicinity of the shaking off of one's own good and evil deeds, being required everywhere by the Vedic injunction of shaking off, becomes a universal cause of determination, like the Kusha grass, the Chanda verse, and the Upasana hymn.

analyzed: na ca cālanam dhvaja agra vat sukṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ mukhyam saṃbhavati
translated: And the shaking off of the good and evil deeds of others cannot be the primary meaning of the word 'shaking off', like the top of a flag.

original: adravyatvāt /🔽aśvaśca romāṇi vidhūnvānastyajanrajaḥ sahaiva tena romāṇyapi jīrṇāni śātayati 'aśva iva romāṇi vidhūya pāpam' chā / / /
analyzed: a dravya tvāt  aśvaḥ ca romāṇi vidhūnvānaḥ tyajan rajaḥ saha eva tena romāṇi api jīrṇāni śātayati aśvaḥ iva romāṇi vidhūya pāpam
translated: Because they are not substances.

analyzed: iti ca brāhmaṇam
translated: And the Brahmana text says: 'Just as a horse, shaking off the dust, casts off the old hairs along with the dust, so also I, shaking off evil,

analyzed: aneka artha tva abhyupagamāt ca dhātūnām na smaraṇa virodhaḥ
translated: And because roots have many meanings, there is no contradiction with the Smriti.

analyzed: tat uktam iti vyākhyātam
translated: This has been explained as stated.

analyzed: hānau tu uktam
translated: But in the case of shaking off, it has been said:

original: yathāśvo rajoyuktāni jīrṇaromāṇi tyaktvā nirmalo bhavati tathāhamapi pāpaṃ vidhūya
analyzed: yathā aśvaḥ rajaḥ yuktāni jīrṇa romāṇi tyaktvā nirmalaḥ bhavati tathā aham api pāpam vidhūya
translated: Just as a horse, casting off the old hairs covered with dust, becomes spotless, so also I, shaking off evil,

original: kṛtātmā nirmalīkṛtacittaḥ san yathā vā rāhugrastaścandro rāhumukhātpramucya spaṣṭo
analyzed: kṛtātmā nirmalīkṛta cittaḥ san yathā vā rāhu grastaḥ candraḥ rāhu mukhāt pramucya spaṣṭaḥ
translated: Having become one whose self is purified, whose mind is cleansed, just as the moon, when seized by Rāhu, being released from Rāhu's mouth, becomes clear,

original: bhavati tathā śarīraṃ dhūtvā tyaktvā dehābhimānānmuktaḥ sannakṛtaṃ kūṭasthaṃ brahmātmakaṃ
analyzed: bhavati tathā śarīram dhūtvā tyaktvā deha abhimānāt muktaḥ san akṛtam kūṭastham brahma ātmakam
translated: so also, having cast off, having abandoned the body, being released from the notion of the body, I become the unborn, the immutable, the Brahman-like world,

analyzed: lokam abhi pratyaktvena saṃbhavāmi iti arthaḥ
translated: in the form of the individual self. This is the meaning.

original: yathā nadyaḥ samudraṃ prāpya nāmarūpe tyajanti tathā vidvānityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā nadyaḥ samudram prāpya nāma rūpe tyajanti tathā vidvān iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as rivers, on reaching the ocean, abandon their names and forms, so also the knower. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tasya mṛtasya viduṣaḥ
translated: Of that dead wise man.

analyzed: dāyam dhanam
translated: The inheritance, the wealth.

analyzed: tat tena vidyā balena sukṛta duṣkṛte tyajati iti arthaḥ
translated: By that power of knowledge, he abandons good and bad deeds. This is the meaning.

analyzed: upāyanam grahaṇam tasya tyāga pūrvaka tvāt
translated: The taking up is the grasping. Because that is preceded by abandonment,

analyzed: a tyaktayoḥ grahaṇa ayogāt
translated: because it is impossible to grasp what has not been abandoned, abandonment is implied.

original: yatra tu tyāga eva śrutaḥ tatra hānopāyanayoḥ sahabhāvasyāvaśyakatvānāvaśyakatvābhyāṃ saṃśayamāhayatra tviti /
analyzed: yatra tu tyāgaḥ eva śrutaḥ tatra hāna upāyanayoḥ sahabhāvasya āvaśyaka tva anāvaśyaka tvābhyām saṃśayam āha yatra tu iti
translated: But where only abandonment is stated, there is doubt about the necessity or non-necessity of the coexistence of loss and taking up. He says: But where, etc.

original: atra pūrvapakṣe stutiprakarṣāsiddhiḥ siddhānte tatsiddhiriti phalam /
analyzed: atra pūrvapakṣe stuti prakarṣa asiddhiḥ siddhānte tad siddhiḥ iti phalam
translated: Here, in the prima facie view, the excellence of praise is not established; in the established view, that is established. This is the result.

original: yadyapi tāṇḍyātharvaṇaśrutyornirguṇavidyārthayoḥ karmahānameva śrutaṃ nopāyanaṃ tathāpi
analyzed: yadi api tāṇḍya ātharvaṇa śrutyoḥ nirguṇa vidyā arthayoḥ karma hānam eva śrutam na upāyanam tathā api
translated: Although in the Tāṇḍin and Atharvaṇa scriptures, the renunciation of actions alone is stated for the sake of the knowledge of the attributeless, not the transference,

analyzed: kauṣītaki śrutau paryaṅka stha saguṇa brahma vidyāyām upāyanam śrutam atra upasaṃhartavyam iti āśaṅkya
translated: nevertheless, in the Kauṣītaki scripture, the transference is stated in the knowledge of Brahman with attributes seated on the couch, and it is to be included here. Fearing this,

original: vidyābhedānnopasaṃhāra ityāhavidyāntareti /🔽kiñca yathā mantrakarmaṇāmanāvaśyakatvādvidyāsvanupasaṃhāra uktaḥ tathā parairupādānaṃ
analyzed: vidyā bhedāt na upasaṃhāraḥ iti āha vidyā antara iti  kiñca yathā mantra karmaṇām anāvaśyaka tvāt vidyāsu anupasaṃhāraḥ uktaḥ tathā paraiḥ upādānam
translated: he says that due to the difference in knowledge, there is no inclusion.

analyzed: vinā api hāna saṃbhavena upādanasya anāvaśyaka tvāt na prāptiḥ iti dṛṣṭānta saṃgatyā prāpte
translated: Moreover, just as it is said that the mantras and rituals are not included in the knowledge because they are not essential, so too, since transference is not essential because loss is possible without being taken up by others, there is no attainment. When this is the prima facie view,

analyzed: siddhānta yati hānau tu iyādinā
translated: he concludes with but in the case of loss, etc.

original: upāyanaśabdasya śeṣatvāddhānaśabdenāpekṣitatvāditi sūtrārthaḥ /🔽aśvaromadṛṣṭāntena vidhūtayoḥ puṇyapāpayoḥ paratrāvasthānasāpekṣatvātparairūpādānaṃ vācyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: upāyana śabdasya śeṣa tvāt hāna śabdena apekṣita tvāt iti sūtra arthaḥ  aśva roma dṛṣṭāntena vidhūtayoḥ puṇya pāpayoḥ paratra avasthāna sāpekṣa tvāt paraiḥ upādānam vācyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning of the sutra is that because the word transference is subordinate, and because it is required by the word loss.🔽The idea is that due to the example of the horse's hair, since merit and demerit that have been shaken off need to be placed elsewhere, their transference by others must be stated.

original: vidyābhede guṇānupasaṃhāra iti vyavasthānuṣṭhānaviṣayā na stutiviṣayetyāhayaducyata iti /
analyzed: vidyā bhede guṇa anupasaṃhāraḥ iti vyavasthā anuṣṭhāna viṣayā na stuti viṣayā iti āha yat ucyate iti
translated: When there is a difference in knowledge, there is no inclusion of attributes. This rule pertains to the sphere of performance, not to the sphere of praise. He says what is said, etc.

analyzed: manyate sūtrakāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the author of the Sutra thinks so.

analyzed: nanu śruta hāna arthavādena api stuti siddhau kimartham upāyana arthavādaḥ ānīyate
translated: But if praise is accomplished even by the Arthavada that rejects what is heard, why is the Arthavada on Upayama brought in?

analyzed: tatra aha stuti prakarṣa lābhāya iti
translated: To that he says for the sake of attaining the highest praise.

original: nanvarthavādasya vidhinā saṃbandhaḥ prasiddho nārthavādāntareṇetyata āhaprasiddhā ceti /
analyzed: nanu arthavādasya vidhinā saṃbandhaḥ prasiddhaḥ na arthavāda antareṇa iti atas āha prasiddhā ca iti
translated: But the connection of the Arthavada with the injunction is well-known, not with another Arthavada. To that he says and it is well-known.

analyzed: itas bhū lokāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is from this earth.

analyzed: hemanta śiśirayoḥ aikyāt pañca ṛtavaḥ
translated: Since Hemanta and Shishira are one, there are five seasons.

original: yajñasya puruṣarūpakalpanāyāṃ sendriyatvāya triṣṭubhau bhavata ityuktaṃ bahvṛcabrāhmaṇe /
analyzed: yajñasya puruṣa rūpa kalpanāyām sa indriya tvāya triṣṭubhau bhavataḥ iti uktam bahvṛca brāhmaṇe
translated: In the conception of the sacrifice in the form of a person, the two Tristubh verses are said to be for the sake of having sense organs in the Bahvric Brahmana.

analyzed: tatra triṣṭubhaḥ chandaḥ mātra tvāt katham indriya tva kalpanā iti ākāṅkṣāyām yajurvākyam saṃvādyate iti arthaḥ
translated: There, due to the Tristubh meter being mere meter, how is the conception of sense organs possible? When there is expectation, the Yajur mantra is brought into agreement. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu amūrtayoḥ puṇya pāpayoḥ upādānasya asaṃbhavāt anupasaṃhāraḥ iti atas āha vidyā stuti artha tvāt ca iti
translated: But since it is impossible to take up merit and sin which are incorporeal, there is no inclusion. To that he says and because it is for the sake of praising knowledge.

original: vidvanniṣṭhayoreva tayoḥ phalaṃ pare prāpnuvanti vidyāsāmarthyādityupayantipadenocyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vidvas niṣṭhayoḥ eva tayoḥ phalam pare prāpnuvanti vidyā sāmarthyāt iti upayanti padena ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The result of those two which belong to the knower is obtained by others through the power of knowledge. This is said by the word Upayama. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu anya aniṣṭa karmaṇoḥ anyatra phala saṃcāraḥ katham
translated: But how can the result of two acts, one desired and one not desired by another, be transferred to something else?

analyzed: nanu vacana balāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is on the strength of the text, we say no.

analyzed: phalam upayanti iti a śruteḥ
translated: Because it is not heard that they enjoy the fruit.

original: naca yathā putrakṛtaśrāddhasya pitṛṣu phalaṃ tathātreti vācyaṃ /
analyzed: na ca yathā putra kṛta śrāddhasya pitṛṣu phalam tathā atra iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that just as the fruit of the śrāddha performed by the son accrues to the ancestors, so it is here.

original: yasya phalamuddiśya yatkarma vihitaṃ tasya tatphalamiti nyāyena pitṛṇāṃ tṛptyuddeśena kṛtakarmaṇo vyadhikaraṇaphalatve 'pi viduṣaḥ karmakāle
analyzed: yasya phalam uddiśya yat karma vihitam tasya tat phalam iti nyāyena pitṛṇām tṛpti uddeśena kṛta karmaṇaḥ vyadhikaraṇa phala tve viduṣaḥ karma kāle
translated: Because of the principle that the fruit of an act enjoined for the sake of a certain fruit belongs to that for whose sake it is enjoined, even though the fruit of the act done with the object of satisfying the ancestors is in a different substratum, for the wise man, at the time of the act,

analyzed: n uddiṣṭa vyadhikaraṇa phala ayogāt
translated: because it is not proper that the fruit in a different substratum should not be intended.

original: kiñca viduṣo dehapāte karmaṇo 'sattvādyāvajjīvaṃ vidvatsevakasya taddveṣiṇo vā phalaṃ syādityata āhanātīvābhiniveṣṭavyamiti /
analyzed: kiñca viduṣaḥ dehapāte sattvāt yāvajjīvam vidvas sevakasya tad dveṣiṇaḥ vā phalam syāt iti atas āha na atīva abhiniveṣṭavyam iti
translated: Moreover, since the act of the wise man ceases to exist with the dissolution of the body, the fruit would accrue to the servant of the wise man or to his enemy, as long as he lives. To this he says: One should not be too much attached.

original: vidvatsevādveṣābhyāṃ vidvanniṣṭhapuṇyapāpatulye puṇyapāpe sevakadveṣiṇorjāyete jātayoḥ phalataḥ svīkāra upāyanamiti parihārasya sulabhatvādanāgraha
analyzed: vidvas sevā dveṣābhyām vidvas niṣṭha puṇya pāpa tulye puṇya pāpe sevaka dveṣiṇoḥ jāyete jātayoḥ phalataḥ svīkāraḥ upāyanam iti parihārasya sulabha tvāt anāgraha
translated: Equal merit and demerit in the wise man arise from the service and hatred of the wise man. From those merits and demerits, fruits are born. The acceptance of those fruits is called upāyana. Because the means of accepting them is easy, there is no attachment.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: upāyana ādeḥ stuti tve liṅgam āha opāyana iti
translated: He gives a reason for upāyana etc. being praise in the verse beginning with upāyanena.

original: upāyanavivakṣāyāmupāyanasyaivopasaṃhāraṃ sūtrakāro brūyādataḥ śabdasya taṃ brūvanstutiṃ sūcayatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: upāyana vivakṣāyām upāyanasya eva upasaṃhāram sūtra kāraḥ brūyāt atas śabdasya tam brūvan stutim sūcayati iti arthaḥ
translated: When the intention is to take the word as a gift, the author of the aphorisms would speak of the gift itself being concluded. Therefore, by speaking of that of the word, he indicates praise.

original: vidyāvicārātmake pāde stutivicārasya kā saṃgatirityata āhatasmāditi /
analyzed: vidyā vicāra ātmake pāde stuti vicārasya kā saṃgatiḥ iti atas āha tasmāt iti
translated: In a section dealing with the consideration of knowledge, what connection is there with the consideration of praise? To this he says 'therefore'.

original: śākhāntarastho viśeṣaḥ śākhāntare 'pi grāhya ityatra dṛṣṭāntamāhakuśeti /
analyzed: śākhā antara sthaḥ viśeṣaḥ śākhā antare pi grāhyaḥ iti atra dṛṣṭāntam āha kuśa iti
translated: The example for the idea that a particular mentioned in one branch should be accepted in another branch also is stated by 'kusha'.

analyzed: kuśāḥ udgātṛṇām stotra gaṇanā arthāḥ śalākāḥ dāru mayyaḥ
translated: Kusha is a wooden stick for counting the hymns by the Udgātṛ priests.

analyzed: bho kuśāḥ
translated: O Kusha plants!

original: yūyaṃ vānaspatyāḥ vanasthamahāvṛkṣo vanaspatiḥ tatprabhavāḥ stha tā itthaṃbhūtā yūyaṃ mā pāta māṃ rakṣateti yajamānaprārthanā /
analyzed: yūyam vānaspatyāḥ vana stha mahā vṛkṣaḥ vanaspatiḥ tad prabhavāḥ stha tāḥ itthaṃbhūtāḥ yūyam mā pāta mām rakṣata iti yajamāna prārthanā
translated: You are born from the great forest tree, the Vanaspati, you who are like this, protect me, guard me - this is the supplication of the sacrificer.

original: atra tā iti strīliṅganirdeśādaudumbarya iti bhāṣyācca śalākāsu kuśaśabdasya strītvaṃ mantavyaṃ darbhaviṣayasya na strītvaṃ /
analyzed: atra tāḥ iti strī liṅga nirdeśāt audumbaryaḥ iti bhāṣyāt ca śalākāsu kuśa śabdasya strī tvam mantavyam darbha viṣayasya na strī tvam
translated: Here, because of the feminine form 'tāḥ' and because of the commentary 'audumbaryah', the word 'kusha' should be understood as feminine in the sticks, not as masculine in the case of darbha grass.

analyzed: astrī kuśam iti anuśāsanāt
translated: Because of the rule 'kusha is not feminine'.

analyzed: chandaḥ dṛṣṭāntam vyācaṣṭe yathā ca iti
translated: He explains the example of the Vedic meter by 'yathā ca'.

original: navākṣarāṇi chandāṃsi āsurāṇyanyāni daivāni teṣāṃ kvacchindobhiḥ stuvata ityatrāviśeṣaprāptau paiṅgivākyādviśeṣagraha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: nava akṣarāṇi chandāṃsi āsurāṇi anyāni daivāni teṣām kvacchindobhiḥ stuvate iti atra aviśeṣa prāptau paiṅgi vākyāt viśeṣa grahaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The metres consisting of nine syllables are Asura metres, the others are Deva metres. When it is found that the metres are not specified in the text 'They chant with the metres', the specification is made on the basis of the statement of Paiṅgi.

analyzed: stutim vivṛṇoti yathā iti
translated: He explains the praise: 'Just as'.

original: ātirātre ṣoḍaśino grahasyāṅgabhūtaṃ stotraṃ kadeti chandogādīnāmākāṅkṣāyāmudayasamayāviṣṭe sūrye ṣoḍaśinaḥ stotramityārcaśruteḥ kālaviśeṣagraha
analyzed: ā atirātre ṣoḍaśinaḥ grahasya aṅga bhūtam stotram kadā iti chandoga ādīnām ākāṅkṣāyām udaya samaya āviṣṭe sūrye ṣoḍaśinaḥ stotram iti ārca śruteḥ kāla viśeṣa graha
translated: When there is a desire of the Chandogas and others as to when the praise which is a part of the Ṣoḍaśin cup at the Ātiratra should be done, the time is specified as 'The praise of the Ṣoḍaśin is when the sun is in the ascendant' on the basis of the Vedic text.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the time is specified.

analyzed: ṛcaḥ dhīyate iti ārcāḥ
translated: The Ṛc verses are called ārca because they are studied.

analyzed: upagānam vibhajate yathā iti
translated: He divides the Upāṁśu chant: 'Just as'.

original: 'ṛtvija upagāyanti'ityaviśeṣaśruteḥ 'nādhvaryurūpagāyati'iti śrutyantarādadhvaryubhinnā ṛtvija upagāyantīti viśeṣagraha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ṛtvijaḥ upagāyanti iti aviśeṣa śruteḥ na adhvaryuḥ ūpagāyati iti śruti antarāt adhvaryu bhinnāḥ ṛtvijaḥ upagāyanti iti viśeṣa grahaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Since the text 'The priests chant the Upāṁśu' does not specify, the specification is made on the basis of another Vedic text 'The Adhvaryu does not chant the Upāṁśu' that the priests other than the Adhvaryu chant the Upāṁśu. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu kuśa ādi vākyānām api kim iti viśeṣa śruti antara eka vākya tā abhyupagamyate
translated: Why are the statements about kuśa grass etc. also accepted as forming a single sentence with another specific Vedic text?

analyzed: tatra āha śruti antara kṛtam hi iti
translated: In this regard, he says: 'For, the connection with another Vedic text is not contradicted'.

original: sāmānyaviśeṣayorekavākyatārūpāyāṃ gatau satyāṃ vākyabhedaṃ kṛtvā nādhvaryuriti niṣedhādaviśeṣaśruteścādhvaryurupagāyati nopagāyati cetyevaṃ
analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ eka vākya tā rūpāyām gatau satyām vākya bhedam kṛtvā na adhvaryuḥ iti niṣedhāt aviśeṣa śruteḥ ca adhvaryuḥ upagāyati na upagāyati ca iti evam
translated: When there is a single sentence in the form of a general rule and a specific exception, having made a split of the sentence, due to the prohibition the Adhvaryu does not and due to the statement of the general rule, the Adhvaryu chants and does not chant.

analyzed: sarvatra vikalpaḥ na yuktaḥ
translated: When there is a combination in the form of a single sentence between the general and the particular, then, having made a split in the sentence, because of the prohibition 'the Adhvaryu does not', and because of the non-distinction stated in the text, it is not proper to have an option in every case as to whether the Adhvaryu sings or does not sing.

analyzed: vrīhi yavayoḥ tu agatyā vikalpaḥ āśritaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that an option is resorted to in the case of vrīhi and yava only out of necessity.

analyzed: vikalpasya anyāyya tvam aṣṭa doṣa duṣṭa tvāt
translated: An option is improper because it is tainted with eight faults.

analyzed: tathā hi yadi vrīhi vākyam āśrīyate tadā yava vākyasya iṣṭa prāmāṇya tyāgaḥ
translated: Thus, if the statement about vrīhi is accepted, then there is abandonment of the accepted validity of the statement about yava.
There is acceptance of the undesired invalidity.

analyzed: kadācid yava vākya āśrayaṇe tyakta prāmāṇya svīkāraḥ
translated: Sometimes, when the statement about yava is accepted, there is abandonment of the accepted validity.

analyzed: svīkṛta aprāmāṇya tyāgaḥ ca iti ekasmin yava vākye catvāraḥ doṣāḥ bhavanti
translated: There is abandonment of the accepted invalidity. Thus, in the single statement about yava, there are four faults.

original: evaṃ vrīhivākyepi catvāro doṣā ityevaṃ duṣṭavikalpaparihārāya bhinnaśākhaśrutyorapyekavākyatā jaiminisaṃmatetyāhataduktamiti /
analyzed: evam vrīhi vākye api catvāraḥ doṣāḥ iti evam duṣṭa vikalpa parihārāya bhinna śākhā śrutyoḥ api ekavākya tā jaimini saṃmatā iti āha tat uktam iti
translated: Similarly, there are four faults in the statement about vrīhi. Thus, in order to avoid the tainted option, Jaimini accepts that even the statements from different branches form a single sentence. He says that it is stated thus.

analyzed: jyotiṣṭoma prakaraṇe dīkṣitaḥ na juhoti
translated: In the context of the Jyotiṣṭoma, 'The uninitiated does not offer oblations.'

original: iti śrutaṃ 'yāvajjīvamagnihotraṃ juhuyāt'iti cānyatra śrutaṃ tatra yadi nadīkṣitavākyaṃ homapratiṣedhakaṃ syāttadā kratvarthatvānniṣedho 'nuṣṭheyaḥ /
analyzed: iti śrutam yāvajjīvam agnihotram juhuyāt iti ca anyatra śrutam tatra yadi na dīkṣita vākyam homa pratiṣedhakam syāt tadā kratu artha tvāt niṣedhaḥ nuṣṭheyaḥ
translated: Thus, having heard the statement of the initiated person, and also having heard elsewhere the statement 'One should offer the Agnihotra as long as he lives', if the statement of the initiated person were to prohibit the Homa, then the prohibition would have to be performed because it is for the purpose of the sacrifice.

original: yāvajjīvavidhinā homo vānuṣṭheya iti vikalpaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yāvat jīva vidhinā homaḥ vā anuṣṭheyaḥ iti vikalpaḥ syāt
translated: Or the Homa would have to be performed by the injunction 'as long as one lives'. Thus there would be an option.

analyzed: sa ca anyāyyaḥ
translated: And that is improper.

original: api tu yāvajjīvavākyaṃ prati nadīkṣitavākyasya śeṣatvānnakāra itaraparyudāsārthakaḥ syāddīkṣitānyalakṣakaḥ syāt /
analyzed: api tu yāvajjīva vākyam prati na dīkṣita vākyasya śeṣa tvāt nakāraḥ itara paryudāsa arthakaḥ syāt dīkṣita anya lakṣakaḥ syāt
translated: Rather, because the statement of the initiated person is a supplement to the statement 'as long as one lives', the word 'na' would have the meaning of exclusion of the other, it would indicate someone other than the initiated person.

analyzed: na homa pratiṣedhakaḥ
translated: It is not a prohibition of the Homa.

analyzed: tasmāt adīkṣitaḥ yāvajjīvam juhuyāt iti eka vākya tā iti na dīkṣita adhikaraṇa siddhānta sūtra arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the Siddhānta Sūtra of the Adhikaraṇa on the initiated person is that it forms a single sentence with 'The uninitiated person should offer the Homa as long as he lives'.

analyzed: atra bhagavat pādaiḥ sūtram eva paṭhitam
translated: Here, the revered Pādas have recited the Sūtra itself.

original: miśraistu paryudāsādhikaraṇasiddhāntasūtraṃ 'api tu vākyaśeṣaḥ syādanyāyyatvādvikalpasya vidhīnāmekadeśaḥ syāt'iti sthitamatrārthataḥ paṭhitamityuktaṃ
analyzed: miśraiḥ tu paryudāsa adhikaraṇa siddhānta sūtram api tu vākyaśeṣaḥ syāt anyāyya tvāt vikalpasya vidhīnām eka deśaḥ syāt iti sthitam atra arthataḥ paṭhitam iti uktam
translated: But the Mīśras have said that the Siddhānta Sūtra of the Paryudāsa Adhikaraṇa, 'But it would be a supplement, because an option is improper. It would be a part of the injunctions', has been recited here in substance.

analyzed: tat cintyam
translated: And that should be considered.

original: sūtrārthastu yajñamātre yeyajāmahe iti prayoktavyamiti śrutaṃ /
analyzed: sūtra arthaḥ tu yajña mātre ye yajāmahe iti prayoktavyam iti śrutam
translated: The meaning of the sutra is that it has been heard that the mantra yeyajāmahe should be used only in the main sacrifice.

analyzed: na anuyājeṣu yeyajāmaham karoti iti api śrutam
translated: It has also been heard that one does not use yeyajāmahe in the after-sacrifices.

analyzed: anyathā hi aviśeṣeṇa eva etasyām gatau aṅgīkriyamāṇāyām virodhaḥ syāt

analyzed: katham hi nirañjanaḥ gantā deśa antaram gacchet

original: gaterarthavattvaṅkvacitsaguṇavidyāyāṃ mārgaḥ śrūyate nirguṇavidyāyāṃ na śrūyate /🔽tatra hānasaṃnidhau mārgasya śrutatvādanapekṣitatvācca saṃśaye dṛṣṭāntasaṃgatyā pūrvapakṣamāhayathā tāvaditi /
analyzed: gateḥ arthavat tvam kvacid saguṇa vidyāyām mārgaḥ śrūyate nirguṇa vidyāyām na śrūyate  tatra hāna saṃnidhau mārgasya śruta tvāt anapekṣita tvāt ca saṃśaye dṛṣṭānta saṃgatyā pūrvapakṣam āha yathā tāvat iti
translated: In some places, in the knowledge of the qualified Brahman, the path is heard, in the knowledge of the unqualified Brahman it is not heard.🔽There, due to the path being heard in the proximity of destruction and due to its not being required, in doubt, he states the prima facie view with the connection of an example - just as, for example.

analyzed: upāyana vat margasya api kvacid śruta tvāt sarvatra upasaṃhāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as the path is heard somewhere, so there should be inclusion everywhere.

analyzed: atra mukti artham mārga apekṣā pūrvapakṣe
translated: Here, in the prima facie view, even those who know the unqualified Brahman need a path for liberation.

analyzed: siddhānte tu anapekṣā iti phalam

translated: The conclusion is that there is no inclusion because it contradicts the Vedic text supported by the reasoning that the path is needed for reaching things obstructed by space etc.

analyzed: nirañjanaḥ saṅgaḥ

analyzed: sāmyam brahma

analyzed: tasmāt sarva upāsanāsu pratīka bhinnāsu arciḥ ādi prāptiḥ iti siddham
translated: Therefore it is established that in all meditations, even when the symbols are different, there is attainment through light etc.

analyzed: e ns  start

analyzed: yāvat adhikāra adhikaraṇam sū

analyzed: yāvadadhikāram avasthitiḥ ādhikārikāṇām

original: viduṣo vartamānadehapātānantaraṃ dehāntaramutpadyate na veti cintyate /

translated: This consideration is not proper.🔽For the consideration whether cooked rice will be or will not be when the cooking vessel is accomplished is not possible.

original: nāpi bhuñjānastṛpyenna veti cintyate /🔽upapannā tviyaṃ cintā brahmavidāmapi keṣāñciditihāsapurāṇayordehāntarotpattidarśanāt /

original: tathāhyapāntaratamā nāma vedācāryaḥ purāṇarṣirviṣṇuniyogātkalidvāparayoḥ saṃdhau kṛṣṇadvaipāyanaḥ saṃbabhūveti smaranti /

translated: For thus they remember that in ancient times, a teacher of the Vedas named Apantaratama, by the order of Vishnu, was born as Krishna Dvaipayana at the junction of Kali and Dvapara.

original: vasiṣṭhaśca brahmaṇo mānasaḥ putraḥ sannimiśāpādapagatapūrvadehaḥ punarbrahmādeśānmitrāvaruṇābhyāṃ saṃbabhūveti /

translated: And Vasiṣṭha, the son of Brahmā born of his mind, having lost his former body by the curse of Vasiṣṭha, was again born by the command of Brahmā from Mitra and Varuṇa.

original: bhṛgvādināmapi brahmaṇa eva mānasaputrāṇāṃ vāruṇe yajñe punarutpattiḥ śrūyate /

analyzed: śrutau api mantra arthavādayoḥ prāyeṇa upalabhyate
translated: And in the Śruti also, it is generally found in the Mantras and Arthavādas.

original: te ca kecitpatite pūrvadehe dehāntaramādadatte kecittu sthita eva tasminyogaiśvaryavaśādanekadehādānanyāyena /

translated: And some of them, when their former bodies fell, took other bodies, while some, remaining in that (body), by the power of Yoga, took many bodies according to the principle of taking many bodies.

analyzed: sarve ca ete samadhigata sakala veda arthāḥ smaryante

original: tadeteṣāṃ dehāntarotpattidarśanātprāptaṃ brahmavidyāyāḥ pākṣikaṃ mokṣahetutvamahetutvaṃ veti /

analyzed: atas uttaram ucyate na

analyzed: yathā asau bhagavān savitā sahsra yuga paryantam jagataḥ dhikāram caritvā tad avasāne udaya astamaya varjitam  kaivalyam anubhavati atha tatas ūrdhvam udetya na eva udetā na astametā ekalaḥ eva madhye
translated: Just as that Lord Savita, having performed his office for the world for a thousand yugas, at its end experiences liberation, free from rising and setting,

analyzed: yathā ca vartamānāḥ brahma vidaḥ ārabdha bhoga kṣaye kaivalyam anubhavanti

original: evamapāntaramaprabhṛtayo 'pīśvarāḥ parameśvareṇa teṣu teṣvadhikāreṣu niyuktāḥ santaḥ satyapi samyagdarśane kaivalyahetāvakṣīṇakarmāṇo yāvadadhaikāramavatiṣṭhante /
analyzed: evam apāntarama prabhṛtayaḥ pi īśvarāḥ parameśvareṇa teṣu teṣu adhikāreṣu niyuktāḥ santaḥ sati api samyagdarśane kaivalya hetau akṣīṇa karmāṇaḥ yāvat adhaikāram avatiṣṭhante

analyzed: tad avasāne ca apavṛjyante iti aviruddham

analyzed: na ca jñāna phalasya anaikāntika tā

translated: The Bhāṣya shows the observation of rebirth of the wise as the seed of doubt.

original: pūrvapakṣe jñānānmuktiśrutīnāṃ jñānastutimātratvena jñānasya muktiphalatvābhāve sati brahmalokaphalatvāviśeṣādarcirādimārgopasaṃhāraḥ phalaṃ /

original: yadi jñānināṃ prārabdhātiriktakarmādhīnāṃ janmāntaraṃ syāttadā jñānānmuktyabhāvaḥ syāt /

analyzed: na etat asti

analyzed: jñāninām janmāntarasya pūrva janma hetu prārabdha adhīna tāyām alupta smṛti tvam hetuḥ
translated: For the knowers of Brahman, the cause of having another birth dependent on the prārabdha caused by previous births is the quality of not losing memory.

analyzed: yaḥ hi ajātismara tve sati karmāntara adhīna janmāntaravān
translated: For one who, having the memory of past births, has another birth dependent on another action,

analyzed: sa lupta smṛtiḥ iti vyāpteḥ

translated: The meaning is that thus, when they have the qualification of not remembering past births, the absence of the qualified is established by the absence of the qualified itself.🔽Those who are without recognition of the name in a previous body, who are dependent, who are conceited, remember their past births.

original: ādhikārikāstu pūrvanāmānaḥ svatantrā nirabhimānā iti vaiṣamyam /

translated: The originative injunction is secondary, because it depends on the result. The injunction of application of what is produced to the result is primary, because it has a result.

analyzed: tathā ca mantraṇām udgātṛ veda id panna tvāt udegātrā prayogaḥ

translated: When there is a conflict due to the reversal of the secondary and primary in the injunction of application, the performance is by the Adhvaryu priest. This is the meaning of Jaimini's aphorism.

original: madhyasthamakṣaramanṛtamubhayataḥ satyena saṃpuṭitatvātsattyaprāyameva bhavatīti nāmākṣaropāsanā satyavidyāṅgatvenoktā /

original: yattatpūrvaprakṛtaṃ hṛdayākhyaṃ tatsaṃpratyuktayakṣatvādiguṇakaṃ /🔽so 'sāvādityamaṇḍale 'kṣiṇi ca puruṣastasyāharityahamiti ca nāmadvayajñānātpāpakṣayaḥ phalamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yat tat pūrva prakṛtam hṛdaya ākhyam tat saṃprati ukta yakṣa tva ādi guṇakam  saḥ saḥ āditya maṇḍale kṣiṇi ca puruṣaḥ tasya ahar iti aham iti ca nāma dvaya jñānāt pāpa kṣayaḥ phalam iti arthaḥ
translated: That which was previously referred to as the heart, now has the qualities of being a Yaksha, etc.🔽That person in the sun's orb and in the eye, by knowing the two names aha and aham, the result is the destruction of sin. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atra pūrva uttara vākyayoḥ phala bheda śruteḥ prakṛta ākarṣaṇāt ca saṃśayam āha tatra iti

analyzed: pūrvapakṣe guṇānām vyavasthayā anuṣṭhānam

analyzed: siddhānte tu anuṣṭhāna aikyam iti phalam

translated: That Brahman which is qualified by the attributes mentioned before by the pronoun 'tat' (that), is drawn in, because the attributes of being in the sun, in the eye, etc. are enjoined.

analyzed: tathā ca vākyāt eva vidyā aikya siddhiḥ iti siddhāntayati ekā eva iti

translated: Thus, even in the case of difference of vidya, there would be the knowledge of the oneness of the object of upasana. This is the meaning of the aphorism.

analyzed: asati apavāda kāraṇe rūpa aikyāt vidyā aikya utsarga siddhiḥ na ca phala bhedāt apavādaḥ

translated: This being the prima facie view, we say: The restriction is on the determination of that.

original: yānyetānyudgīthādikarmaguṇayāthātmyanirdhāraṇāni rasatama āptiḥ samṛddhirmukhyaprāṇa āditya ityevamādīni naitāni nityavatkarmasu niyamyeran
analyzed: yāni etāni udgītha ādi karma guṇa yāthātmya nirdhāraṇāni rasatamaḥ āptiḥ samṛddhiḥ mukhya prāṇaḥ ādityaḥ iti evamādīni na etāni nitya vat karmasu niyamyeran
translated: The statements about the nature of the qualities of the acts beginning with the Udgītha, such as ‘the attainment of the highest flavour’, ‘prosperity’, ‘the chief vital air’, ‘the sun’, and so on, do not refer to the acts as eternal;

analyzed: kutas tad dṛṣṭeḥ
translated: why not? Because that is seen;

original: tathāhyaniyatatvamevañjātīyakānāṃ darśayati śrutiḥ 'tenobhau kuruto yaścaitadevaṃ veda yaśca na veda' chā / /
analyzed: tathā hi aniyata tvam evañjātīyakānām darśayati śrutiḥ tena ubhau kurutaḥ yaḥ ca etat evam veda yaḥ ca na veda chā
translated: for the Śruti declares the noneternality of such acts, ‘By that both of them perform, he who knows it thus and he who does not’ Bṛ Up , , 0

analyzed: iti a viduṣaḥ pi kriyā abhyanujñānāt
translated: For the text permits the performance of the acts even by the ignorant

original: prastāvādidevatāvijñānavihīnānāmapi prastotrādīnāṃ yājanādhyavasānadarsanāt 'prastotaryā devatā prastāvamanvāyattā tāṃ cedavidvānprastoṣyasi' 🔽chā / / /🔽'tāṃ cedavidvānudgāsyasi' chā / / /
analyzed: prastāva ādi devatā vijñāna vihīnānām api prastotṛ ādīnām yājana adhyavasāna darsanāt prastotar yā devatā prastāvam anvāyattā tām ced a vidvān prastoṣyasi  chā  tām ced avidvān udgāsyasi chā
translated: Moreover, we see that the Prastotṛ and other priests who are ignorant of the deities of the Prastāva and other parts of the Sāma, are engaged in the performance of the sacrifice ‘O Prastotṛ, the deity connected with the Prastāva is such and such; if, not knowing this, thou shouldst chant the Prastāva’ Bṛ Up , , 0🔽‘O Udgātṛ, the deity connected with the Udgītha is such and such; if, not knowing this, thou shouldst chant the Udgītha’ Bṛ Up , , 0

original: 'tāṃ cedavidvānpratihariṣyasi' chā / / / iti ca /🔽api caivañjātīyakasya karmavyapāśrayasya vijñānasya pṛthageva karmaṇaḥ phalamupalabhyate
analyzed: tām ced avidvān pratihariṣyasi chā iti ca  api ca evañjātīyakasya karma vyapāśrayasya vijñānasya pṛthak eva karmaṇaḥ phalam upalabhyate
translated: ‘O Pratihartṛ, the deity connected with the Pratihāra is such and such; if, not knowing this, thou shouldst chant the Pratihāra’ Bṛ Up , , 0🔽Moreover, the knowledge of the acts of this kind is seen to have a result of its own, apart from the result of the act itself

analyzed: karma phala siddhi ddya pratibandhaḥ tad samṛddhiḥ atiśaya viśeṣaḥ kaścid tena ubhau kurutaḥ
translated: The prosperity of the act, ie its special excellence, consists in the removal of obstacles to the attainment of the result of the act; by that both of them perform, he who knows it thus and he who does not

analyzed: yaḥ ca etat evam veda yaḥ ca na veda
translated: Whether one knows this or not.

original: nānā tu vidyā cāvidyā ca yadeva vidyayā karoti śraddhayopaniṣadā tadeva vīryavattaraṃ bhavati' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: nānā tu vidyā ca avidyā ca yat eva vidyayā karoti śraddhayā upaniṣadā tat eva vīryavattaram bhavati chā  iti
translated: But knowledge and ignorance are different. Whatever one does with knowledge, with faith, with the Upaniṣads, that becomes most powerful.

original: tatra nānā tviti vidvadavidvatprayogayoḥ pṛthakkaraṇādvīyarvattaramiti ca tarappratyayaprayogādvidyāvihīnamapi karmaviryavaditi gamyate /
analyzed: tatra nānā tu iti vidvat avidvat prayogayoḥ pṛthakkaraṇāt vīyarvattaram iti ca tarap pratyaya prayogāt vidyā vihīnam api gamyate
translated: There, but indicates the separation of the practices of the knower and the non-knower, and most powerful indicates that even an action devoid of knowledge is powerful, from the use of the suffix tarap.

analyzed: tat ca anitya tve vidyāyāḥ upapadyate
translated: And that is possible if knowledge is non-eternal.

analyzed: nitya tve tu katham tad vihīnam
translated: But if it is eternal, how could an action devoid of it be recognized as powerful?

analyzed: sarva aṅga upasaṃhāre hi vīryavat karma iti sthitiḥ
translated: For it is established that an action is powerful only when all its parts are present.

original: tathā lokasāmādiṣu pratiniyatāni pratyupāsanaṃ phalāni śiṣyante 'kalpante hāsmai lokā ūrdhvāścāvṛttāśca' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā loka sāma ādiṣu pratiniyatāni pratyupāsanam phalāni śiṣyante kalpante ha asmai lokāḥ ūrdhvāḥ ca āvṛttāḥ ca chā
translated: Similarly, in the Lokasama and other [Upaniṣads], fruits are taught to be fixed for each meditation: The worlds rise up and turn towards him.

analyzed: iti evamādīni
translated: And so on.

analyzed: na ca idam phala śravaṇam arthavāda mātram yuktam pratipattum
translated: And it is not proper to consider this teaching of fruits as mere arthavāda (explanatory passage).

analyzed: tathā hi guṇa vādaḥ āpadyeta
translated: For then it would be a mere eulogy.

analyzed: phala upadeśe tu mukhya vāda upapattiḥ
translated: But when it is a teaching of fruits, it is a primary statement.

original: prayājādiṣu tvitikartavyatākāṅkṣasya kratoḥ prakṛtatvāttādarthye sati yuktaṃ phalaśruterarthavādatvam /
analyzed: prayāja ādiṣu tu itikartavya tā ākāṅkṣasya kratoḥ prakṛta tvāt tādarthye sati yuktam phala śruteḥ arthavāda tvam
translated: In the case of Prayāja and other subsidiary acts, however, the primary act of sacrifice, which is in need of the details of procedure, is the subject-matter of the context, and hence it is proper that the mention of the result should be taken as a commendatory statement, when the subsidiary acts are taken as subservient to that primary act.

analyzed: tathā an ārabhya adhīteṣu api parṇamayī tva ādiṣu  nahi parṇa mayī tva ādīnām akriyā ātmakānām āśrayam antareṇa phala saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Similarly, in the case of the injunctions of the leaf-cups, etc., which are not connected with any particular ritual.🔽For the leaf-cups, etc., which are not of the nature of acts, cannot be connected with a result without a substratum.

analyzed: godohana ādīnām hi prakṛta ap praṇayana ādi āśraya lābhāt upapannaḥ phala vidhiḥ
translated: In the case of the milking vessel, etc., however, the injunction of the result is proper, because they have the primary act of the Apūrva as their substratum.

analyzed: tathā bailva ādīnām api prakṛta yūpa ādi āśraya lābhāt upapannaḥ phala vidhiḥ
translated: Similarly, in the case of the Palāśa wood, etc., the injunction of the result is proper, because they have the sacrificial post, etc., as their substratum.

analyzed: na tu parṇamayī tva ādiṣu evaṃvidhaḥ kaścid āśrayaḥ sti
translated: But in the case of the leaf-cups, etc., there is no such substratum that is the subject-matter of the context.

original: vākyenaiva tu juhvādyāśrayatāṃ vivakṣitvā phale 'pi vidhiṃ vivakṣato vākyabhedaḥ syāt /
analyzed: vākyena eva tu juhū ādi āśraya tām vivakṣitvā phale vidhim vivakṣataḥ vākya bhedaḥ syāt
translated: If, however, it is intended to make the leaf-cups, etc., the substratum by the sentence itself, and also to enjoin the result, then there would be syntactical split.

original: upāsanānāṃ tu kriyātmatvādviśiṣṭavidhānopapatterudgīthādyāśrayāṇāṃ phale vidānaṃ na virudhyate /
analyzed: upāsanānām tu kriyā ātma tvāt viśiṣṭa vidhāna upapatteḥ udgītha ādi āśrayāṇām phale vidānam na virudhyate
translated: But in the case of the meditations, the injunction of the result in regard to those which have the Udgītha, etc., as their substratum is not inconsistent, because they are of the nature of acts and hence it is proper to enjoin them as qualified acts.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā kratu āśrayāṇi api godohana ādīni phala saṃyogāt anityāni evam udgītha ādi upāsanāni api iti draṣṭavyam
translated: Therefore, just as the milking of the cow and other acts, though based on the sacrifice, are non-eternal due to their connection with results, so also the meditations on the udgītha and other topics should be regarded as non-eternal.

original: ata eva ca kalpasūtrakārā naivañjātīyakānyupāsanāni kratuṣu kalpayāñcakruḥ // //
analyzed: atas eva ca kalpasūtra kārāḥ na evañjātīyakāni upāsanāni kratuṣu kalpayāñcakruḥ  /
translated: For this very reason, the authors of the Kalpasūtras did not consider such meditations to be performed in the sacrifices.

analyzed: tad nirdhāraṇā
translated: The determination of that.

analyzed: ubhayathā dṛṣṭānta darśanāt saṃśayam āha kim tāni iti
translated: Seeing examples in both ways, he doubts - are those?

original: yathānārābhyādhītaparṇamayītvaṃ juhūdvārā kratvaṅgatayā karmasu nityaṃ prayujyate /
analyzed: yathā anāra abhyādhīta parṇa mayī tvam juhū dvārā kratu aṅga tayā karmasu nityam prayujyate
translated: Just as the quality of being made of parna leaves, which is mentioned separately, is used in the rites as eternal through the juhu ladle, which is connected with the sacrifice,

analyzed: tathā aṅga āśrita upāsanāni udrītha ādi dvāra aṅga tayā nityāni  uta kratu aṅga ap praṇayana śrayaḥ godohana saṃyogaḥ paśu phala artha tvāt anitya tvena yathā
translated: similarly, the meditations based on the limbs are eternal through the udgītha and other topics, which are connected with the sacrifice.🔽Or, like the connection of milking the cow, which is based on the bringing in of the limbs of the sacrifice, is used as non-eternal due to being for the result of an animal,

original: prayujyate yathā vā paśvaṅgayūpāśrayaṃ bailvatvamannādyaphalatvādanityaṃ tathā karmasamṛdyādiphalakatvādupāsanānyanaṅgatvenānityānīti saṃśayārthaḥ
analyzed: prayujyate yathā vā paśu aṅga yūpa āśrayam bailva tvam annādya phala tvāt anityam tathā karma samṛdi ādi phalaka tvāt upāsanāni anaṅga tvena anityāni iti saṃśaya arthaḥ
translated: just as the quality of being made of bilva wood, which is based on the sacrificial post, which is a limb of the animal, is non-eternal due to being for the result of food, similarly, the meditations are non-eternal due to not being limbs, because they have results like the prosperity of the rite. This is the meaning of the doubt.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣe upāsanānām prayoga nitya tvam
translated: In the prima facie view, the performance of the meditations is eternal.

analyzed: siddhānte tu anitya tvam iti phala bhedaḥ
translated: In the conclusion, however, it is non-eternal. This is the difference in results.

analyzed: anitya bhojana āśraya prāṇa agnihotrasya anitya tva vat nitya karma aṅga upāstīnām nitya tvam iti pratyudāharaṇa dṛṣṭāntena pūrvapakṣam āha kim tāvat iti
translated: As the Agnihotra, which is based on the use of perishable materials, is not permanent, so the meditations on the permanent parts of the ritual are not permanent. With this counter-example, he presents the prima facie view: What then?

analyzed: upāsanāni karmāṅgāni
translated: The meditations are parts of the ritual.

analyzed: aphalatve sati karmāṅga āśrita tvāt parṇamayī tva ādi vat
translated: Because they are based on the ritual, and are not ends in themselves, like the injunction to use leaves made of gold.

original: tathā cāṅgatayā prayogavidhinā nityena prayujyanta iti prāpte siddhāntasūtraṃ vyācaṣṭeyānītyādinā /
analyzed: tathā ca aṅga tayā prayoga vidhinā nityena prayujyante iti prāpte siddhānta sūtram vyācaṣṭe iyāni ityādinā
translated: And thus, being parts, they are employed by the permanent injunctions of the ritual. When this is established, he comments on the sutra that presents the conclusion, beginning with yāni.

original: udgīthādayaḥ karmaṇāṃ guṇāḥ aṅgāni teṣāṃ yāthātmayaṃ rasatamatvādikaṃ tannirdhāraṇānyupāsanāni yāni tāni karmasu nityaparṇamayītvādivanna niyamyerannityarthaḥ
analyzed: udgītha ādayaḥ karmaṇām guṇāḥ aṅgāni teṣām yāthātmayam rasatama tva ādikam tad nirdhāraṇāni upāsanāni yāni tāni karmasu nitya parṇa mayī tva ādi vat na niyamyeran iti arthaḥ
translated: The Udgītha and so on are qualities of the rituals, their parts. The determination of their nature, such as being the sweetest, are the meditations that determine that. Those are not restricted to the rituals like the injunction to use leaves made of gold. This is the meaning.

original: eṣāṃ karmāṅgatve taddhīnasyāviduṣaḥ karma na syādaṅgalopāt /
analyzed: eṣām karma aṅga tve tad hīnasya aviduṣaḥ karma na syāt aṅga lopāt
translated: If they were parts of the ritual, then the ignorant person who lacks them would not perform the ritual due to the omission of a part.

analyzed: tasmāt aviduṣaḥ api karma kartṛ tva śruti liṅgaiḥ aṅgatva anumāna bādhaḥ iti āha tad dṛṣṭeḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the inference that they are parts based on the statements and indications of the performance of rituals by even the ignorant is contradicted. He says tad-dṛṣṭeḥ.

analyzed: tasya aniyamasya darśanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the non-restriction of those is seen.

original: tāṃ cedavidvānprastoṣyasi mūrdhā te vyapatiṣyatīti cākrāyaṇenartvijāmākṣiptatvādanupāsakānāmapi karmaprayogo 'stītyāhaprastāvādīti /
analyzed: tām ced a vidvān prastoṣyasi mūrdhā te vyapatiṣyati iti cākrāyaṇena ṛtvijām ākṣipta tvāt anupāsakānām api karma prayogaḥ u sti iti āha prastāva ādi iti
translated: If, not knowing this, you were to chant it, your head would fall off. Since it has been rejected by the priest Akrayaṇa, it is said that even non-devotees have the application of ritual.

analyzed: upāstīnām karma phalāt pṛthak phala śruteḥ na karma aṅga tvam iti āha api ca iti
translated: It is said that the results of meditation are different from the results of ritual, so they are not parts of the ritual. It is said that even though there is a difference between knowledge and ignorance,

original: tenomityakṣareṇa yaścaitadakṣaramevaṃ rasatamatvādirūpeṇa vedopāste yaśca na veda tāvubhau karma kuruta eva yadyapi tu vidyāvidyayornānātvaṃ 🔽bhinnaphalatvam /
analyzed: tena ūm iti akṣareṇa yaḥ ca etat akṣaram evam rasatama tva ādi rūpeṇa veda upāste yaḥ ca na veda tau ubhau karma kurute eva yadi api tu vidyā avidyayoḥ nānātvam  bhinna phala tvam
translated: the two who know and do not know this syllable Om in this way as the highest essence and so on, they both perform the ritual. Although there is a difference between knowledge and ignorance,

original: dṛṣṭaṃ hi maṇivikraye jñānājñānābhyāṃ vaṇikśabarayoḥ phalavaiṣamyaṃ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭam hi maṇi vikraye jñāna ajñānābhyām vaṇij śabarayoḥ phala vaiṣamyam
translated: the difference in results is seen in the case of a merchant and a hunter in the sale of a gem due to knowledge and ignorance.

original: tasmādyadeva karma vidyayodgīthādyupāstyā śraddhayāstikyabuddhyopaniṣadā rahasyadevatādhyānena karoti tadeva karma phalātiśayavadityarthaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt yat eva karma vidyayā udgītha ādi upāstyā śraddhayā āstikya buddhyā upaniṣadā rahasya devatā dhyānena karoti tat eva karma phala atiśayavat iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that the ritual performed with faith, the belief in God, and with the Upanishad, the meditation on the secret deity, along with the knowledge of the Udgitha and other meditations, that ritual alone has superior results.

original: karmaṇo vīryavattvaṃ nāma phalavattvaṃ vidyāhīnasyāpi gamyamānaṃ vidyāyā anaṅgatve liṅgamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: karmaṇaḥ vīryavat tvam nāma phalavat tvam vidyā hīnasya api gamyamānam vidyāyāḥ anaṅga tve liṅgam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the efficacy of the ritual, which is its fruitfulness, is understood even for one lacking knowledge, and that is an indication that knowledge is not a necessary factor.

analyzed: sāmni loka ādi dṛṣṭi upāsaneṣu karma samṛdi atirikta loka ādi phala śruteḥ ca na aṅga tvam iti āha tathā iti
translated: In the case of meditations on the world and so on in the Saman, the result is the attainment of the world and so on, which is different from the prosperity of ritual. Therefore, it is not a subsidiary, he says thus.

original: asmai viduṣe kalpante bhogāya samarthā bhavanti bhūmerūrdhvā lokā āvṛttā adhastanāścetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: asmai viduṣe kalpante bhogāya samarthāḥ bhavanti bhūmeḥ ūrdhvāḥ lokāḥ āvṛttāḥ adhastanāḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: For this knower, the worlds above and below the earth become fit, capable, for enjoyment. This means they turn around.

analyzed: tathā hi guṇa vādaḥ iti
translated: Thus, it is indeed a praise.

analyzed: phala śruteḥ arthavāda mātra tve stuti lakṣaṇā syāt
translated: If the statement of result is merely a praise, there would be an indication of praise.

analyzed: sā na yuktā
translated: That is not proper.

analyzed: mukhya vṛttyā phala paratva saṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is possible to have the primary meaning of being about the result.

analyzed: prayāja anuyāja karmaṇām tu prakaraṇāt darśa ādi aṅga tva lābhāt bhātṛvya abhibhūti phala śruteḥ agatyā stuti lakṣaka tvam
translated: But in the case of the prayāja and anuyāja rites, since they obtain the status of being subsidiaries of the new and full moon sacrifices through context, the statement of the result of conquering one's enemies is to be taken as an indication of praise, because it is unavoidable.

original: yadyapi parṇamayītvādīnāmaṅgatvabodhakaṃ prakaraṇaṃ nāsti tathāpi teṣu phalaśruteḥ stutitvaṃ /
analyzed: yadi api parṇamayī tva ādīnām aṅgatva bodhakam prakaraṇam nā asti tathā api teṣu phala śruteḥ stuti tvam
translated: Even though there is no context that indicates the subsidiary nature of being made of parna leaves and so on, in those cases the statement of result is praise.

analyzed: teṣām akriyā tvena kriyā saṃbandham vinā phala hetu tva anupapatteḥ atas teṣām phala artham
translated: Because, since they are not actions, it is not possible for them to be the cause of a result without being related to an action. Therefore, for the sake of the result,

analyzed: kriyā apekṣi tvāt kratoḥ ca juhū prakṛti dravya ākāṅkṣi tvāt parṇa mayī juhūḥ ityādi vākyena eva
translated: since they require an action, and since the sacrifice requires the original material for the juhū ladle, by the sentence The juhū is made of parna leaves and so on,

analyzed: prakṛti dravya arpakeṇa juhū dvārā saṃnihita kratu aṅga tva siddheḥ yuktam phala śruteḥ arthavāda tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that when the Juhū is offered as a substance of the original material, it is proper for the statement of result to be a commendatory statement, because the Juhū is established as a part of the sacrifice that is present through the Juhū.

analyzed: akriyā ātmaka godohana ādeḥ api phala śrutiḥ arthavādaḥ syāt atas āha godohana ādīnām hi iti
translated: Even for the milking of the cow, which is not an action, the statement of result would be a commendatory statement. To this he says: For the milking of the cow and so on, however, etc.

original: yadapaḥ praṇayettat paśukāmasya sato godohanena brahmavarcasakāmasya kaṃsnyeti phalārthavidhireva nārthavādaḥ godohanādeḥ kratvanākāṅkṣitatvenāṅgatvābhāvāt /
analyzed: yat apaḥ praṇayet tat paśu kāmasya sataḥ godohanena brahmavarcasa kāmasya kaṃsnyā iti phala artha vidhiḥ eva na artha vādaḥ godohana ādeḥ kratu an ākāṅkṣita tvena aṅga tva abhāvāt
translated: When one pours water, that is for one who desires cattle through the milking of the cow, for one who desires brahmic splendor through the Kamsya, etc. The injunction for the sake of the result is itself, not a commendatory statement, because the milking of the cow and so on are not desired as parts of the sacrifice.
Because it is possible for the Chamasa to accomplish its own result through its connection with the action that is not desired.

original: tathā khādiratvena nirākāṅkṣakratvaṅgayūpamāśritya bailvamannādyakāmasya khādiraṃ vīryakāmasyeti phalārthavidhirevārthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā khādira tvena nirākāṅkṣa kratu aṅga yūpam āśritya bailvam annādya kāmasya khādiram vīrya kāmasya iti phala artha vidhiḥ eva arthaḥ
translated: Similarly, relying on the sacrificial post that is not desired as a part of the sacrifice through the Khadira wood, the injunction for the sake of the result is itself the meaning: The Khadira for one who desires food through the Bilva, for one who desires strength.

original: parṇamayītvādiṣu phalavidhiḥ kiṃ na syādata āhana tviti /
analyzed: parṇamayī tva ādiṣu phala vidhiḥ kim na syāt atas āha na tu iti
translated: Why should there not be an injunction of result in the case of the leaf-made and so on? To this he says: Not so, etc.

analyzed: evaṃvidhaḥ yūpa ādi vat nirākāṅkṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this kind of thing is not desired, like the sacrificial post and so on.

analyzed: juhuḥ eva āśrayaḥ iti atas āha vākyena iti
translated: The Juhū itself is the basis. To this he says: By the sentence, etc.

translated: Even after that, in the immediately following Brahmana text, 'This very world is indeed the fire, the mind,' the purpose of the word is seen to be the injunction of mere knowledge, not the injunction of a mere subsidiary of action.

original: bhūyāṃsastvagnyavayavāḥ saṃpādayitavyā vidyāyāmityetasmātkāraṇādagninānubadhyate vidyā na karmāṅgatvāt /

original: cite 'gnau lokadṛṣṭividhānaṃ svatantramuttaratra gamyate pūrvatra maṇḍalapuruṣopāstistatsāṃnidhyānmadhye 'pi mānasāgnayaḥ svatantrā ityarthaḥ

translated: For the materialist does not recognize any reality apart from the four elements.

analyzed: yat anubhavanam bhūta bhautikānām tat caitanyam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that sentience is the experience of the elements and their evolutes,
