translated: A trained actor will not mount his own shoulder.

original: nahi bhūtabhautikadharmeṇa satā caitanyena bhūtabhautikāni viṣayīkriyeran /
analyzed: nahi bhūta bhautika dharmeṇa satā caitanyena bhūta bhautikāni viṣayīkriyeran
translated: Sentience, being a property of the elements and their evolutes, cannot make the elements and their evolutes its objects.

analyzed: nahi rūpa ādibhiḥ sva rūpam para rūpam vā a viṣayīkriyate
translated: For the self is not made an object by form, etc., whether it be the self's own form or another's form.

analyzed: viṣayīkriyante tu bāhya ādhyātmikāni bhūta bhautikāni caitanyena
translated: But the external and internal elements and elemental evolutes are made objects by consciousness.

analyzed: atas ca yathā eva asyāḥ bhūta bhautika viṣayāyāḥ upalabdheḥ bhāvaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: And therefore, just as the existence of the self is to be accepted as the existence of this apprehension of the elements and elemental evolutes,

original: upalabdhisvarūpa eva ca na ātmetyātmano dehavyatiriktatvam /
analyzed: upalabdhi svarūpaḥ eva ca na ātmā iti ātmanaḥ deha vyatirikta tvam
translated: the self is of the nature of apprehension itself. Thus the self is distinct from the body.

analyzed: nitya tvam ca upalabdheḥ aikarūpyāt
translated: And the self is eternal because apprehension is of one and the same nature.

analyzed: aham idam adrākṣam iti ca avasthā antara yoge pi upalabdhṛ tvena pratyabhijñānāt
translated: And because of recognition as the apprehender, even when connected with a different state, as in I saw this before.

analyzed: smṛti ādi upapatteḥ ca
translated: And because memory, etc., are possible.

original: yattūktaṃ śarīre bhāvāccharīradharma upalabdairiti tadvarṇitena prakāreṇa pratyuktam /🔽apica satsupradīpādiṣūpakaraṇeṣūpalabdhirbhavatyasatsu na bhavati /
analyzed: yat tu uktam śarīre bhāvāt śarīra dharmaḥ upalabdaiḥ iti tat varṇitena prakāreṇa pratyuktam  apica satsu pradīpa ādiṣu upakaraṇeṣu upalabdhiḥ bhavati asatsu na bhavati
translated: As for what was said - that the self is the property of the body because it exists when the body exists - that is refuted by the method described.🔽Moreover, apprehension occurs when the means of knowledge such as the lamp, etc. exist, and does not occur when they do not exist.

analyzed: na ca etāvatā pradīpa ādi dharmaḥ eva upalabdhiḥ bhavati
translated: But this does not make apprehension the property of the lamp, etc.

original: evaṃ sati deha upalabdhirbhavatyasati ca na bhavatīti na dehadharmau bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: evam sati dehe upalabdhiḥ bhavati asati ca na bhavati iti na deha dharmau bhavitum arhati
translated: Similarly, apprehension occurs when the body exists and does not occur when it does not exist. Therefore, it cannot be the property of the body.

analyzed: upakaraṇa tva mātreṇa api pradīpa ādi vat deha upayoga upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible for the body to be useful to the self even by mere instrumentality, like a lamp, etc.

original: nacātyantaṃ dehasyopalabdhāvupayogo 'pi dṛśyate niśceṣṭe 'pyasmindehe svapne nānāvidhopalabdhidarśanāt /
analyzed: na ca atyantam dehasya upalabdhau upayogaḥ dṛśyate niśceṣṭe pi asmin dehe svapne nānāvidha upalabdhi darśanāt
translated: And the body is not seen to be absolutely useful for perception, because various perceptions are seen in this body even when it is motionless, in a dream.

original: tasmādanavadyaṃ dehavyatiriktasyātmano 'stitvam // //🔽manuṣyo 'haṃ jānāmiti dehasya jñātṛtāyāḥ pratyakṣatvādātmadharmatvena prasiddhānāṃ
analyzed: tasmāt anavadyam deha vyatiriktasya ātmanaḥ stitvam  manuṣyaḥ ham jānām iti dehasya jñātṛ tāyāḥ pratyakṣa tvāt ātma dharma tvena prasiddhānām
translated: Therefore, the existence of the self separate from the body is faultless.

analyzed: dharmāṇām deha anvya vyatireka anubhavāt tad anya ātmani pratyakṣa abhāvāt apratyakṣasya aprāmāṇika tvāt deha
translated: Because the body is directly perceived as the knower, as in I am a human, I know, and because the properties that are well-known as belonging to the self are experienced as being absent in what is other than the body, and because what is not directly perceived is not valid, it is concluded that the self is the body itself.

original: evātmeti prāpte sūtrasthanatvitipadena siddhāntaṃ pratijānītenatvetaditi /🔽anumānasya tāvatprāmāṇyamanicchitāpyāstheyamanyathā vyavahārāsiddheḥ /
analyzed: eva ātmā iti prāpte sūtra stha na tu iti padena siddhāntam pratijānīte na tu etat iti  anumānasya tāvat prāmāṇyam anicchita api āstheyam anyathā vyavahāra asiddheḥ
translated: The word not in the sutra states the conclusion: This is not so.🔽Even though one may not wish for the validity of inference, it must be accepted, otherwise practical life would be impossible.

analyzed: na hi anāgata pāka ādau iṣṭa sādhanatā anumitam vinā pravṛttiḥ saṃbhavati
translated: For without the inference of the means of accomplishing future results, engagement is not possible.

original: tathāca jñānādayo dehavyatiriktāśrayā dehasattve 'pyasattvādvyatirekeṇa deharūpādivadityāhavyatireka evāsyeti /
analyzed: tathā ca jñāna ādayaḥ deha vyatirikta āśrayāḥ deha sattve pi asattvāt vyatirekeṇa deha rūpa ādi vat iti āha vyatirekaḥ eva asya iti
translated: And thus knowledge and other qualities are not dependent on the body, because they do not exist even when the body exists, like the form of the body and so on, which are different from it. He says: The difference from the body is itself the reason.

analyzed: na ca ādau śyāma dehasya paścāt rūpa antare vyabhicāraḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction in the case of a dark-bodied person later having a different form.

original: guṇatvasākṣādvyāpyajātyavacchedena asattvasya vivakṣitatvāt dehe 'vasthite sadā rūpatvāvacchinnamastyeva /
analyzed: guṇa tva sākṣāt vyāpya jāti avacchedena asattvasya vivakṣita tvāt dehe sadā rūpa tva avacchinnam asti eva
translated: Because non-existence is intended in terms of the class that is directly pervaded by the quality of being a quality, when the body exists, what is qualified by the quality of being form always exists.

original: jñānatvāvacchinnaṃ tu nāstīti na jñānaṃ dehadharmaḥ /
analyzed: jñāna tva avacchinnam tu na asti iti na jñānam deha dharmaḥ
translated: But what is qualified by the quality of being knowledge does not exist, so knowledge is not a property of the body.

analyzed: kiñca ete na deha guṇāḥ paraiḥ adṛśya tvāt iti āha deha dharmāḥ ca iti
translated: Moreover, these are not qualities of the body, because they are not seen by others. He says: And the properties of the body...

original: kiñca dehavyatirike teṣāmabhāvasya saṃdigdhatvānna dehadharmatvaniścaya ityāhaapiceti /
analyzed: kiñca deha vyatirike teṣām abhāvasya saṃdigdha tvāt na deha dharma tva niścayaḥ iti āha api ca iti
translated: Moreover, because the non-existence of these apart from the body is doubtful, there is no certainty that they are properties of the body. He says: Moreover...

analyzed: na ca anupalambhāt teṣām abhāva niścayaḥ tava anupalabdheḥ amāna tvāt
translated: And the non-existence of these is not ascertained from non-apprehension, because non-apprehension is not a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tad dharmya ātmanaḥ deha antara prāptyā api anupalambha upapatteḥ ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And because non-apprehension is possible even by the attainment of another body by the self that has those as its properties. This is the idea.

analyzed: upalabdhi vat iti sūtra stham padam vyākhyātum upakramate kimātmakam iti
translated: He begins the explanation of the word like apprehension in the sutra with What is the nature of...

analyzed: tat kim bhūta atiriktam tattvam uta rūpa ādi vat bhūta dharmaḥ
translated: Is that reality different from the elements, or is it a property of the elements like color etc.?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ apasiddhāntāt iti uktvā dvitīyam āśaṅkya niṣedhati yat anubhavanam ityādinā
translated: The first is not so, as it would contradict one's own doctrine. Having said this, he raises the second doubt and refutes it with What is experienced... etc.

original: dehātmakabhūtānāṃ caitanyaṃ prati viṣayatvātkartṛkarmavirodhena viṣayasya kartṛtvā yogānna bhūtakartṛkatvaṃ caitanyasyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: deha ātmaka bhūtānām caitanyam prati viṣaya tvāt kartṛ karma virodhena viṣayasya kartṛ tvā yogāt na bhūta kartṛka tvam caitanyasya iti arthaḥ
translated: And because the body-formed elements are objects in relation to consciousness, and because the object cannot be the agent due to the contradiction between agent and object, consciousness does not have the elements as its agent - this is the meaning.

analyzed: kiñca jñānasya bhūta dharma tve rūpa ādi vat jāḍya āpatteḥ na tad dharma tvam iti āha nahi iti
translated: Moreover, if consciousness were a property of the elements, it would follow that it is inert like color etc., and therefore it cannot be a property of that. He says nor is it... to this.

analyzed: phalitam sūtra padārtham āha atas ca iti
translated: He states the meaning of the sutra's words in the conclusion with And for this reason...

original: yā dehātiriktā sadrūpopalabdhiḥ sa evātmā cedanityaḥ syādupalabdheranityatvādityata āhanityatvaṃ ceti /
analyzed: yā deha atiriktā sat rūpa upalabdhiḥ saḥ eva ātmā ced anityaḥ syāt upalabdheḥ anitya tvāt iti atas āha nitya tvam ca iti
translated: If the perception of existent things that are different from the body were the self, it would be impermanent, because perception is impermanent. To this he says If it is argued that it is impermanent... etc.

original: ghaṭaḥ sphurati paṭaḥ sphuratīti sarvatra sphūrterabhedānnityatvaṃ viṣayoparāganāśe tu nāśabhrama ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ghaṭaḥ sphurati paṭaḥ sphurati iti sarvatra sphūrteḥ abhedāt nitya tvam viṣaya uparāga nāśe tu nāśa bhramaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the manifestation of the pot, the manifestation of the cloth - everywhere the manifestation is non-different, so it is permanent. But when the object ceases to appear, there is the illusion of destruction.

analyzed: evam ātmā dehāt bhinnaḥ upalabdhi rūpa tvāt upalabdhi vat iti uktam
translated: Thus it has been said that the self is different from the body, because it is in the form of perception, like perception.

original: kiñca jāgratsvapnayordehabhede 'pyātmaikatvapratyabhijñānādātmabhede cānyānubhūte 'nyasya smṛtīcchānupapatteḥ svapnasmṛtyādimānātmā dehādbhinna
analyzed: kiñca jāgrat svapnayoḥ deha bhede pi ātma eka tva pratyabhijñānāt ātma bhede ca anya anubhūte nyasya smṛti icchā anupapatteḥ svapna smṛti ādimān ātmā dehāt bhinna
translated: Moreover, in the waking and dreaming states, even with the difference in bodies, there is recognition of the self as one, and in the difference of selves, the memory and desire of one for what is experienced by another is not possible. Therefore, the self, the experiencer, is different from the body.

analyzed: iti āha aham iti
translated: Thus he says I.

analyzed: nirastam api adhika abhidhitsayā anuvadati yat tu uktam iti  upalabdheḥ deha anvaya vyatirekau na deha dharma tva sādhakau tad nimitta tvena anyathāsiddheḥ iti adhikam āha api ca iti
translated: Though refuted, he repeats it with the desire to say more, saying What was said.🔽The concomitance and non-concomitance of experience with the body do not prove it to be a property of the body, because it is established otherwise as its cause. He says more: Moreover.

analyzed: upalabdhi mātre dehasya nimitta tvam api asiddham iti āhana ca atyantam iti
translated: The mere experience of the body as the cause is also not established. He says And not absolutely.

analyzed: svapna upalabdhiḥ na deha janyā
translated: The experience in a dream is not produced by the body.

analyzed: deha vyāpāram vinā api bhāvāt vṛkṣa vat
translated: Like a tree, it exists even without the operation of the body.

original: ata eva tanvabhāve 'pi svapnavadyogināṃ bhogaṃ sūtrakṛdvakṣyati /
analyzed: atas eva tanu abhāve svapna vat yoginām bhogam sūtrakṛt vakṣyati
translated: For this very reason, the author of the aphorisms will say that even in the absence of the body, yogis enjoy like in a dream.

analyzed: jāgrat upalabdheḥ deha ja tvam asti iti atyantam iti uktam
translated: The experience in the waking state is produced by the body. Therefore, absolutely is said.

original: tasmāduktānumānugṛhītānmama śarīramiti bhedānubhāvādahaṃ manuṣya ityabhedajñānaṃ bhrama ityupasaṃharatitasmāditi ////
analyzed: tasmāt ukta anumā anugṛhītāt mama śarīram iti bheda anubhāvāt aham manuṣyaḥ iti abheda jñānam bhramaḥ iti upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: Therefore, from the inference stated, and from the experience of difference as my body, the knowledge of non-difference as I am a human is a delusion. He concludes thus: Therefore.🔽end

translated: But since the Udgītha, &c., are the same in all the Śākhās, the meditations are everywhere. Thus, since the object of knowledge is the same everywhere, how can there be doubt? To this he says: And in each Śākhā, &c.

translated: the meditations on the Udgītha, &c., enjoined in one Veda are not possible in the Udgītha, &c., occurring in another Veda.

translated: Jaimini raises the objection that there is no renunciation.

original: ūrdhvaretaḥ śabditaṃ pārivrājyamanuṣṭheyaṃ na veti mānabhrāntimūlatvābhyāṃ saṃdehe bhrāntimūlatvānnānuṣṭheyamityāhatraya iti /
analyzed: ūrdhvaretaḥ śabditam pārivrājyam anuṣṭheyam na vā iti māna bhrānti mūla tvābhyām saṃdehe bhrānti mūla tvāt na anuṣṭheyam iti āha trayaḥ iti
translated: The wandering life, called the stage of celibacy, should be practiced or not? In doubt due to being based on valid knowledge and error, he says three that it should not be practiced because it is based on error.

analyzed: āśramāṇām avāntarabheda apekṣayā bahuvacanam
translated: The plural is used with reference to the subdivisions of the stages of life.

analyzed: tathā ca kāṇvāyana smṛtiḥ arthataḥ
translated: And thus the Kāṇvâyanasmṛti is quoted in meaning.

analyzed: gāyatraḥ brāhmaḥ prājāpatyaḥ bṛhan iti brahmacārī caturvidhaḥ
translated: The celibate is of four kinds: Gāyatrī, Brāhma, Prājāpatya, and Bṛhat.

analyzed: tatra upanayanāt ūrdhvam yaḥ tri rātram a kṣāra a lavaṇa āśī gāyatrīm adhīte sa gāyatraḥ
translated: Among them, one who studies the Gāyatrī for three nights, eating food without salt or alkaline substances, after the initiation, is Gāyatrī.

original: yastu vedasya grahaṇāntaṃ brahmacaryaṃ carati sa brāhmaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu vedasya grahaṇa antam brahmacaryam carati sa brāhmaḥ
translated: One who observes celibacy until the recitation of the Veda is Brāhma.

analyzed: ṛtu kāle sva dāra gāmī nityam para strī vimukhaḥ prājāpatyaḥ
translated: One who goes to his own wife during her season, always averse to another's wife, is Prājāpatya.

analyzed: saṃvatsaram veda vrata kṛt vaṭuḥ vā prājāpatyaḥ
translated: Or a young man who has observed the vow of the Vedas for a year is a Prajapati.

analyzed: āmaraṇam guru kula vāsī naiṣṭhikaḥ bṛhan iti ucyate
translated: One who lives in the teacher's house until death is a Naisthika, also called a Brihat.

original: gṛhastho 'pi caturvidhaḥ vārtāko yāyāvaraḥ śālīno ghorasaṃnyasikaśceti /
analyzed: gṛhasthaḥ u pi caturvidhaḥ vārtākaḥ yāyāvaraḥ śālīnaḥ ghorasaṃnyasikaḥ ca iti
translated: And the householder is also of four kinds: a Varttaka, a Yayavara, a Shalina, and a Ghora-Sannyasika.

analyzed: tatra kṛṣi gorakṣa ādikayā vaiśya ādi vṛttyā jīvan ityādi kriyā paraḥ vārtāka vṛttiḥ
translated: Among them, one who lives by the occupation of Vaishyas and others, such as agriculture and cattle rearing, and is devoted to such activities as plowing, etc., is of Varttaka livelihood.

analyzed: yāyāvaraḥ tu a yācita vṛttiḥ yājana adhyāpana pratigraha vimukhaḥ
translated: But a Yayavara is of unasked-for livelihood, averse to officiating at sacrifices, teaching, and accepting gifts.

analyzed: śālīnaḥ tu ṣaṭkarma nirataḥ yājana ādi vṛttiḥ saṃcayī
translated: However, a Shalina, devoted to the six actions, is of the livelihood of officiating at sacrifices, etc., and is an accumulator.

original: uddhṛtaparipūtābhiradbhiḥ kāryaṃ kurvanpratyahaṃ kṛtoñchavṛttirgrāmavāsī ghorasaṃnyasika ityucyate /
analyzed: uddhṛta paripūtābhiḥ adbhiḥ kāryam kurvan pratyaham kṛta uñcha vṛttiḥ grāma vāsī ghorasaṃnyasikaḥ iti ucyate
translated: One who performs his daily duties with water drawn and purified, and who lives in a village with the livelihood of gleaning, is called a Ghora-Sannyasika.

analyzed: hiṃsā vimukha tvāt
translated: Because he is averse to violence.

original: vānaprastho 'pi caturvidhaḥ vaikhānasa audumbaro vālakhilyaḥ phenapaśceti /
analyzed: vānaprasthaḥ u pi caturvidhaḥ vaikhānasaḥ audumbaraḥ vālakhilyaḥ phenapaḥ ca iti
translated: And the forest-dweller is also of four kinds: Vaikhanasa, Audumbara, Valakhilya, and Phenapa.

analyzed: tatra akṛṣṭapacya oṣadhībhiḥ grāma bahiṣkṛtābhiḥ agnihotra ādi kurvan vaikhānasaḥ ucyate
translated: Among them, one who performs the Agnihotra and other rites with unploughed and wild herbs outside the village is called a Vaikhanasa.

original: yastu prātaruthāya yāṃ diśaṃ paśyati tatratyaudumbarabadarīnīvāraśyāmākaiḥ karmaparaḥ sa audumbaraḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu prātar uthāya yām diśam paśyati tatratya audumbara badarī nīvāra śyāmākaiḥ karma paraḥ saḥ audumbaraḥ
translated: The one who, upon rising in the morning, sees the direction where there are udumbara trees, jujube trees, nīvāra rice, and śyāmaka grains, and is devoted to ritual, is the udumbara.

original: yastu jaṭāvalkaladhārī aṣṭau prātasānvṛttyupārjanaṃ kṛtvā cāturmāsye saṃgṛhītāśī kārtikyāṃ saṃgṛhītapuṣpaphalatyāgī sa vālakhilyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu jaṭā valkala dhārī aṣṭau prātasa anvṛtti upārjanam kṛtvā cāturmāsye saṃgṛhīta āśī kārtikyām saṃgṛhīta puṣpa phala tyāgī sa vālakhilyaḥ
translated: The one who wears matted hair and bark garments, who having earned his livelihood by eight morning meals, eats what is collected during the four months, and gives up collected flowers and fruits on the full moon of Kārtika, is the vālakhilya.

original: phenapāstu śīrṇaparṇaphalavṛttayo yatra kvacidvasantaḥ karmaparā iti /
analyzed: phenapāḥ tu śīrṇa parṇa phala vṛttayaḥ yatra kvacid vasantaḥ karma parāḥ iti
translated: The foam-dwellers, who live on fallen leaves and fruits wherever they are, are devoted to ritual.

original: tathā parivrājākāścaturvidhāḥ kuṭīcakā bahūdakā haṃsāḥ paramahaṃsāśceti /
analyzed: tathā parivrājākāḥ caturvidhāḥ kuṭīcakāḥ bahūdakāḥ haṃsāḥ paramahaṃsāḥ ca iti
translated: Similarly, the wandering ascetics are of four kinds: kuṭīcakas, bahūdakas, haṃsas, and paramahaṃsas.

analyzed: tatra sva putra gṛhe bhikṣām carantaḥ tridaṇḍinaḥ kuṭīcakāḥ
translated: Among them, the triple-staff-bearers who beg for alms in the house of their own son are the kuṭīcakas.

original: bahūdakāstu tridaṇḍinaḥ śikyajalapavitrapādukāsanaśikhāyajñopavītakaupīnakāṣāyaveṣadhārāstīrthānyaṭanto bhaikṣaṃ caranta ātmānaṃ prārthayante
analyzed: bahūdakāḥ tu tridaṇḍinaḥ śikya jala pavitra pādukā āsana śikhā yajñopavīta kaupīna kāṣāya veṣa dhārāḥ tīrthāni aṭantaḥ bhaikṣam carantaḥ ātmānam prārthayante
translated: The bahūdakas, who are triple-staff-bearers, wear a sling, a water-purifying pot, sandals, a seat, a tuft of hair, a sacred thread, a loincloth, and a saffron robe, wander to holy places, beg for alms, and pray to the self.

original: haṃsāstu ekadaṇḍinaḥ śikhāvarjaṃ yajñopavītadharāḥ śikyakamaṇḍalupāṇayaḥ grāmaikarātravāsinaḥ kṛcchracāndrāyaṇaparāḥ /
analyzed: haṃsāḥ tu eka daṇḍinaḥ śikhā varjam yajñopavīta dharāḥ śikya kamaṇḍalu pāṇayaḥ grāma eka rātra vāsinaḥ kṛcchra cāndrāyaṇa parāḥ
translated: The haṃsas, who are single-staff-bearers, wear a sacred thread without a tuft, carry a sling and a water pot in their hands, live in a village for one night, and are devoted to kṛcchra and cāndrāyaṇa penances.

original: paramahaṃsāstvekadaṇḍadharā muṇḍā ayajñopavītinaḥ tyaktasarvakarmāṇa ātmaniṣṭhā iti /
analyzed: paramahaṃsāḥ tu eka daṇḍa dharāḥ muṇḍāḥ a yajña upavītinaḥ tyakta sarva karmāṇaḥ ātma niṣṭhāḥ iti
translated: The paramahaṃsas, however, carry one staff, are shaven, do not wear the sacred thread, have renounced all actions, and are devoted to the Self.

original: atra pūrvapakṣe saṃnyāsābhāvāñjñānasya svatantraphalatvāsiddhiḥ siddhānte tadbhāvāttatsiddhiriti phalabhedaḥ /
analyzed: atra pūrvapakṣe saṃnyāsa abhāvāt jñānasya svatantra phalatva asiddhiḥ siddhānte tad bhāvāt tad siddhiḥ iti phala bhedaḥ
translated: Here, in the prima facie view, due to the absence of renunciation, the independence of knowledge as a fruit is not established. In the conclusion, due to its existence, its establishment is the difference in fruits.

original: skandhā āśramāḥ ātmānaṃ śarīramācāryasya kule gṛhe karśayannaiṣṭhika ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: skandhāḥ āśramāḥ ātmānam śarīram ācāryasya kule gṛhe karśayan naiṣṭhikaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The stages are the heaps. The meaning is that one who emaciates his body, his self, in the house of the teacher's family is a life-long student.

original: skandhaśrutāvāśramā na vidhīyante kintu brahmasaṃsthatāsturthamanūdyanta ityukte śaṅkatenanu parāmarśe 'pīti /
analyzed: skandha śrutau āśramāḥ na vidhīyante kintu brahma saṃstha tāḥ turtham anūdyante iti ukte śaṅkate nanu parāmarśe pi iti
translated: In the hearing of the heaps, the stages are not enjoined, but the fourth, the state of being established in Brahman, is reiterated. When this is said, he doubts: But even in the case of reference...

analyzed: anuvāda apekṣita purovādāt pratītim aṅgīkaroti satyam iti
translated: He accepts the understanding from the prior statement required by the reiteration: True...

original: pratyakṣā skandhaśrutireva purovādo 'stu nānuvāda ityata āhasmṛtīti /
analyzed: pratyakṣā skandha śrutiḥ eva purovādaḥ astu na anuvādaḥ iti atas āha smṛti iti
translated: Let the hearing of the heaps itself be the prior statement, not a reiteration. To this he says: The Smṛtis...

analyzed: tayoḥ api iyam eva śrutiḥ mūlam astu
translated: Let this very Vedic text be the root even for those two.

analyzed: kḷpta śrutau vidhi mātra kalpanā lāghavāt
translated: Because in the established Vedic text, the assumption of the injunction alone is simpler.

original: asyā anuvādatve tu mūlatvena sāgnikānagnikāśramaśrutistatra vidhiśceti dvayakalpanāgauravādityata āhaataśceti /
analyzed: asyāḥ anuvāda tve tu mūla tvena sa agnika anagnika āśrama śrutiḥ tatra vidhiḥ ca iti dvaya kalpanā gauravāt iti atas āha atas ca iti
translated: But if this is a reiteration, then the assumption of two things is cumbersome: the Vedic text about the stages with and without the sacred fires as the root, and the injunction there. To this he says: And for this reason...

analyzed: smārta tvāt āśramāḥ pratyakṣa yāvajjīva karma vidhi śruti aviruddhāḥ grāhyāḥ
translated: The stages of life are to be accepted as prescribed by Smṛti, because they are not contradicted by the directly perceived injunctions of duties to last for life.

analyzed: viruddhāḥ tu anagnika āśramāḥ upekṣyāḥ karma anadhikṛtaiḥ andha ādibhiḥ vā anuṣṭheyāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But those stages of life that are contradictory, such as the stage of anagni, are to be disregarded, or are to be followed by those not entitled to perform sacrifices, or by the blind etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yāvat jīva śruti virodhāt lāghavam tyājyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The lightness (of the duties) is to be abandoned because of the contradiction with the injunctions to last for life. This is the idea.

analyzed: skandha śrutau anuvādya tva aviśeṣāt gārhasthya vat itareṣām anuṣṭheya tvam āśaṅkya tasya śrauta tvāt anuṣṭhānam
translated: In the Sāṇḍilya text, because of the absence of any distinction in being the object of injunction, like the stage of householder, the other stages are also to be performed. Suspecting this, because of its being directly stated, the performance is

translated: Then, the injunction of the stage of life is they go forth. Therefore, it is said Thus, this...

translated: Now, having refuted the prima facie view that there is no such Vedic text, it is being considered thus. He says But... etc.🔽end

translated: Similarly, the text, ‘Those who, desiring that very world of the wandering ascetics, wander forth’ (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.1.2),

analyzed: iti hi dharma skandha tri tvam pratijñātam
translated: And the number three is promised for the divisions of dharma.

translated: And the many dharmas such as sacrifice, which are different in origin, cannot be included in three divisions other than the connection with the life-stages.

translated: There, one division of dharma characterized by sacrifice, etc., has been indicated as the life-stage of the householder, and the clear indication of the life-stage as ‘the celibate’ (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.1.1), and also the austerity (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.4.1), which other than the life-stage primarily consisting of austerity, could be accepted as a division of dharma?

analyzed: ye ca ime raṇye chā
translated: 'And those who are in the forest' (Ch. U. 8.1.1).

analyzed: iti ca araṇya liṅgāt śraddhā tapobhyām āśrama gṛhītiḥ
translated: Thus, the acceptance of the stages of life is by faith and austerity, indicated by the forest-mark.

analyzed: tasmāt parāmarśe pi anuṣṭheyam āśrama antaram
translated: Therefore, even in the case of reference, the other stages of life are to be performed.

analyzed: skandha śrutau itara āśramāḥ śruti antara vihitāḥ anūdyante etad vākya anuvādya tvāt gārhasthya vat iti siddhāntayati anuṣṭheyam iti
translated: In the hearing of the aggregates, the other stages of life enjoined by other scriptures are referred to, because they are to be referred to by this statement, like the householder stage. This is the conclusion. He concludes that it is to be performed.

analyzed: anuvādasya kvacid vidhi pūrvaka tve dṛṣṭāntam āha yathā ca iti

original: nivītaṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ prācīnāvītaṃ pitṛṇāmupavītaṃ devānāmiti vākye daive karmaṇyupavītaṃ vidhīyate /
analyzed: nivītam manuṣyāṇām prācīnāvītam pitṛṇām upavītam devānām iti vākye daive karmaṇi upavītam vidhīyate
translated: The sacrificial thread is enjoined in the Vedic ritual in the statement 'the nivita for humans, the pracinavita for the ancestors, and the upvita for the gods'.

analyzed: tad stutaye dvayam anūdyate
translated: For the praise of that, the two are referred to.

original: mānuṣakriyāsu dehārdhavastrabandhanākhyanivītasya saukaryārtatayā prāptatvāt pitrye karmaṇi prācīnāvītasyāpi vidhyantaraprāptatvādityarthaḥ
analyzed: mānuṣa kriyāsu deha ardha vastra bandhana ākhya nivītasya saukarya ārta tayā prāpta tvāt pitrye karmaṇi prācīnāvītasya api vidhi antara prāpta tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The nivita, which is called the tying of half the body and the cloth, is obtained by its ease in human actions, and the pracinavita is also obtained by another injunction in the ritual for the ancestors. This is the meaning.

analyzed: vākya antare ca sākṣāt eva pārivrājya vidhiḥ vidheyaiḥ sāhityāt iti āha tathā etam eva iti
translated: And in another statement, the injunction of wandering is directly to be performed by association. He says thus, 'this very'.

analyzed: asya iti pārivrājya uktiḥ
translated: 'This' refers to the wandering.

analyzed: vidheya veda anuvacana ādi sāhityāt pārivrājyasya vidheya tā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the stage of wandering mendicancy is to be enjoined because of its association with what is to be enjoined, such as the recitation of the Vedas.

analyzed: vākya antare sāmya śrutim āha ya ca iti
translated: He says that even in another sentence, there is a statement of similarity: If this is so.

analyzed: asya iti vānaprastha uktiḥ
translated: This refers to the mention of the stage of forest hermit.

translated: And because it is not possible that he should not be included, since there is no difference in being referred to, he who is in any one of the four stages of life will be one who rests in Brahman.🔽If, on the other hand, he is not referred to, then the only one left is the wandering mendicant, and it will be settled that he alone rests in Brahman.

analyzed: tapaḥ śabdasya tatra rūḍheḥ

translated: But the number three is mentioned in the text, and the fourth stage is not mentioned. So this discussion is pointless. But why should one not be a brahma-farer without being in any of the stages of life? To this he says If he is not in any of the stages of life...

analyzed: anāśramī na tiṣṭheta iti niṣedhāt iti bhāvaḥ

analyzed: dvitīye siddhān prāptim āha atha iti

analyzed: evam parāmarśa tad abhāvābhyām saṃśayam uktvā pūrvapakṣayati tatra iti

translated: Even in a prayer like 'May the god do what I desire', when the words 'upāsīta' (should meditate) etc. are used along with liṅga (gender) etc., how can it be certain that they are expressing an injunction? To this he says 'tathaica' (thus).

analyzed: etat liṅga ādikam vedeṣu utsargataḥ niyamena iṣṭa sādhana tva ākhya vidheḥ lakṣaṇam jñāpakam syāt
translated: This liṅga (gender) etc. would be the indicator, the means of knowing, of the injunction called the means of accomplishing the desired object, which is naturally and invariably present in the Vedas.

analyzed: upapada ādi bādhake tu anya artha param iti arthaḥ
translated: But when there is contradiction by upasargas (prepositions) etc., they have a different meaning. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tat idam āha liṅ ādi iti
translated: This is what is said by 'liṅ and so on'.

original: naca śloke pañcamamityukteḥ pañcapadānāmeva vidhilakṣaṇatvaṃ nopāsītetyādīnāmiti bhramitavyam /
analyzed: na ca śloke pañcamam iti ukteḥ pañca padānām eva vidhi lakṣaṇa tvam na upāsīta ityādīnām iti bhramitavyam
translated: And when it is said in the verse that the fifth is so, one should not be mistaken that only the five words beginning with 'liṅ' have the nature of injunction, not the words beginning with 'upāsīta' (should worship).

original: kriyāsāmānyavācināṃ kṛbhvastīnāmudāharaṇena sarvadhātūparaktaliṅādīnāṃ vidhilakṣaṇatvasya vivakṣitatvātpañcamapadaṃ tūktāpekṣayā ślokapūraṇārthaṃ
analyzed: kriyā sāmānya vācinām kṛ bhvastīnām udāharaṇena sarva dhātu uparakta liṅ ādīnām vidhi lakṣaṇa tvasya vivakṣita tvāt pañcama padam tu ukta apekṣayā śloka pūraṇa artham
translated: Because by the example of the general words for action, such as 'kri', 'bhu', 'as', 'ti', it is intended that the words beginning with 'liṅ' connected with all verbal roots have the nature of injunction. The word 'fifth' is for the sake of filling out the verse, in relation to what has been said,

analyzed: mṛtyuḥ dhāvati pañcamaḥ itivat
translated: like 'Death runs as the fifth'.

original: yadyapi ḍukṛñ karaṇa iti dhātereva karaṇaśabditabhāvanākhyakriyāsāmānyavācitvaṃ netarayordhātvorbhū
analyzed: yadi api karaṇe iti dhāteḥ eva karaṇa śabdita bhāvanā ākhya kriyā sāmānya vāci tvam na itarayoḥ dhātvoḥ bhū
translated: Although only the verbal root 'to do' (dhā) has the nature of expressing the general action called bhāvanā denoted by the word 'doing' (karaṇa), and not the other two verbal roots 'to be' (bhū)

analyzed: bhuvi iti artha antara ukteḥ tathā api janma ākhya bhavanasya tad phalasya astitvasya
translated: and 'to exist' (as), because of the different meaning expressed by 'bhū' (to be) in the sense of existence (sattā) and 'as' (to exist) in the sense of 'bhū' (to be), nevertheless, the action of becoming called birth and the existence which is its result,

analyzed: ca prayojya niṣṭhasya prayojaka vyāpāra ātmaka bhāvanā vyāpta tvāt tayoḥ kriyā sāmānya vāci tva vyavahāraḥ
translated: are conventionally said to have the nature of expressing the general action, because they are pervaded by the bhāvanā which is the activity of the instigator.

original: tatra kuryāditi prakṛtyarthabhāvanākhyātenānūdyate yathā dvāviti prayoge prakṛtyartho dvitvaṃ pratyayenānūdyate /
analyzed: tatra kuryāt iti prakṛti artha bhāvanā ākhyātena anūdyate yathā dvau iti prayoge prakṛti arthaḥ dvi tvam pratyayena anūdyate
translated: There, the bhāvanā called the meaning of the verbal root 'to do' is referred to by the verbal suffix 'ya', just as in the usage 'dva' (two), the meaning of the verbal root 'dva' (to go) is referred to by the suffix.

analyzed: tadvat liṅā ca tasyāḥ iṣṭa sādhana tva ākhya vidhiḥ bodhyate
translated: In the same way, by the suffix lin, the injunction consisting of the nature of being an instrument for the desired result is understood.

analyzed: kartā tu tayā ākṣipyate iti ākṣipta kartṛkā bhāvanā udāhṛtā
translated: But the agent is implied by that. The bhāvanā with an implied agent is cited.

analyzed: tathā kriyeta iti atra api prakṛti pratyaya arthau vyākhyātau
translated: Similarly, in should be done, the meaning of the verbal root and the suffix is explained.

analyzed: karma atra prādhānyena ākṣipyate iti ākṣipta karmikā bhāvanā udāhṛtā
translated: Here, the object is implied as primary. The bhāvanā with an implied object is cited.

original: ākhyātānāṃ kartrādikārake śaktya bhāvātkartṛkarmaṇorākṣepa eveti mīmāṃsakamatam /

translated: The Mīmāṃsakas' view is that since the optative suffixes do not have the power to denote the agent and other cases, the agent and object are only implied.

analyzed: kartavyam iti kṛtyapratyayena karma kārakam ucyate
translated: By the optative suffix should be done, the object case is expressed.

original: tasyopasarjanatvena prakṛtyā bhāvanokteti bhedaḥ /🔽tathā daṇḍī bhavet bhūyate daṇḍinā bhavitavyamityudāhartavyam /
analyzed: tasya upasarjana tvena prakṛtyā bhāvanā uktā iti bhedaḥ  tathā daṇḍī bhavet bhūyate daṇḍinā bhavitavyam iti udāhartavyam
translated: The difference is that by the verbal root, the bhāvanā is stated as subordinate to that.🔽Similarly, should be with a staff, is seen with a staff, should be with a staff should be cited.

analyzed: tathā syāt bhūyeta bhavitavyam iti asti dhātoḥ api udāharaṇam draṣṭavyam
translated: Similarly, should be, would be, should be should be seen as examples of the verb to be.

analyzed: asteḥ bhūḥ ādeśāt
translated: Because of the substitution of bhū for as.

analyzed: etad dhātu traya uparakta liṅ ādibhiḥ sarva dhātvartha uparakta bhāvanā gata iṣṭa sādhāna tva rūpaḥ vidhiḥ ekaḥ eva ucyate
translated: By the optative suffixes etc. attached to these three verbal roots, only one injunction is stated, which has the nature of being an instrument for the desired result, which is attached to the meaning of all verbal roots.

original: dhātūnāṃ pratyayānāṃ kartrādikārakāṇāṃ ca bhede 'pi vidhibhedo nāstīti jñāpanārthaṃ pratidhātūdāharaṇatrayaṃ darśitamiti sarvamavadātam /
analyzed: dhātūnām pratyayānām kartṛ ādi kārakāṇām ca bhede vidhi bhedaḥ na asti iti jñāpana artham prati dhātu udāharaṇa trayam darśitam iti sarvam avadātam
translated: In order to show that there is no difference in the injunctions, even though there is a difference in the roots, and in the agents and other factors, three examples of roots have been shown. Thus everything is clear.

original: evaṃ sūtre bhāvo vidhiriti vyākhyāya caśabdātphalamiti vyācaṣṭepratiprakaraṇaṃ iti /
analyzed: evam sūtre bhāvaḥ vidhiḥ iti vyākhyāya caśabdāt phalam iti vyācaṣṭe pratiprakaraṇam iti

analyzed: sādhana vīrya viśeṣāt tu atīndriyā kasyacid śaktiḥ āvirbhavati tad pratibaddhā parasya tiṣṭhati
translated: But by the special power of the means, the power of some manifests, and that of others is restrained.

original: nacāviśeṣeṇa vidyāyāmabhisaṃdhirnotpadyata ihāmutra vā me vidyā jāyatāmityabhisaṃdherniraṅ kuśatvāt /
analyzed: na ca aviśeṣeṇa vidyāyām abhisaṃdhiḥ na utpadyate iha amutra vā me vidyā jāyatām iti abhisaṃdheḥ niraṅ kuśa tvāt
translated: And the resolve does not arise without distinction in knowledge, either here or there, May knowledge arise for me, because the resolve is unrestricted.

analyzed: śravaṇa ādi dvāreṇa api vidyā utpadyamānā pratibandha kṣaya apekṣayā evā utpadyate
translated: Even when knowledge arises through the door of hearing and so on, it arises only in dependence on the destruction of obstacles.

original: tathācaśrutirdurbodhatvamātmano darśayati 'śravaṇāyāpi bahubhiryo na labhyaḥ śṛṇvanto 'pi bahavo yaṃ na vidyuḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ durbodha tvam ātmanaḥ darśayati śravaṇāya api bahubhiḥ yaḥ na labhyaḥ śṛṇvantaḥ bahavaḥ yam na vidyuḥ
translated: And thus the scripture shows the difficulty of understanding the self: He who is not attained even by hearing, whom many do not know even while hearing,

original: āścaryo 'sya vaktā kuśalo 'sya labdhāścaryo jñātā kuśalānuśiṣṭaḥ' ka / / iti /
analyzed: āścaryaḥ sya vaktā kuśalaḥ sya labdha āścaryaḥ jñātā kuśala anuśiṣṭaḥ kaḥ iti
translated: He who teaches it is wonderful, he who learns it is wonderful, he who knows it is wonderful, he who is taught by the skilled is wonderful.'

original: garbhasya eva ca vāmadevaḥ pratipede brahmabhāvamiti vadantī janmāntarasaṃcitātsādhanājjanmāntare vidyotpattiṃ darśayati /
analyzed: garbhasya eva ca vāmadevaḥ pratipede brahma bhāvam iti vadantī janmāntara saṃcitāt sādhanāt janmāntare vidyā utpattim darśayati
translated: And they say that Garbhi Vamadeva attained the state of Brahman. This shows that the origination of knowledge in a later life is due to the means accumulated in a previous life.

analyzed: nahi garbhasya eva aihikam kiñcid sādhanam saṃbhāvyate
translated: For it is not possible to conceive of any means in this very life for one who is in the womb.

original: samṛtāvapi 'aprāpya yogasaṃsiddhiṃ kāṃ gatiṃ kṛṣṇa gacchati' gī / /
analyzed: samṛtau api a prāpya yoga saṃsiddhim kām gatim kṛṣṇa gacchati
translated: Even in the Bhagavad Gita, when Arjuna asked, 'O Krishna, what end does one go to who has not attained perfection in yoga?'

original: ityarjunena pṛṣṭo bhagavānvāsudevaḥ 'nahi kalyāṇakṛtkaściddurgatiṃ tāta gacchati' gī / /
analyzed: iti arjunena pṛṣṭaḥ bhagavān vāsudevaḥ na hi kalyāṇa kṛt kaścid durgatim tāta gacchati
translated: The Blessed Lord Vasudeva, having said, 'O son, one who does good never goes to a bad end,'

original: ityuktvā punastasya puṇyalokaprāptiṃ sādhukule saṃbūtiṃ cābhidhāyānantaram 'tatra taṃ buddhisaṃyogaṃ labhate paurvadehikam' gī /
analyzed: iti uktvā punar tasya puṇya loka prāptim sādhu kule saṃbūtim ca abhidhāya anantaram tatra tam buddhi saṃyogam labhate paurvadehikam gīta
translated: and having mentioned his attainment of a meritorious world and rebirth in a good family, then said, 'There he obtains the union with knowledge belonging to his former body,'

analyzed: ityādinā aneka janma saṃsiddhaḥ tatas yāti parām gatim
translated: and so on, up to 'perfected through many births, he then attains the supreme goal.'

analyzed: iti etena etat eva darśayati
translated: This shows the same thing.

analyzed: tasmāt aihikam āmuṣmikam vā vidyā janma pratibandha kṣaya apekṣayā iti sthitam
translated: Therefore it is established that the origination of knowledge in this life or the next depends on the destruction of obstacles.

original: aihikamapi saṃnyāsādibālyāntaṃ sādhanajātamuktvā tatsādhyavidyājanma vicāryata iti saṃgatiṃ vadan sādhanasya dvidhā phalasaṃbhavātsaṃśayamāhasarvetyādinā
analyzed: aihikam api saṃnyāsa ādi bālya antam sādhana jātam uktvā tad sādhya vidyā janma vicāryate iti saṃgatim vadan sādhanasya dvidhā phala saṃbhavāt saṃśayam āha sarva ityādinā
translated: Having mentioned the means beginning with renunciation and ending with childhood in this life, the birth of knowledge which is to be accomplished by them is being considered. Thus, stating the connection, he states the doubt due to the possibility of two kinds of results of the means, with the words all etc.

analyzed: kārīrī iṣṭi vat aihika phala tva niyamaḥ śravaṇa ādīnām iti pūrvapakṣam āha tintāvat iti
translated: The prima facie view is stated with not so etc., that the result of listening etc. is necessarily in this life, like the performance of the Kārīrī sacrifice.

analyzed: nanu āmuṣmika phalaka yajña ādi sādhya vidyāyāḥ katham aihika tva niyamaḥ iti atas āha yajña ādīni api iti
translated: How can the knowledge which is to be accomplished by sacrifices etc. that have results in the next life be necessarily in this life? To this he says sacrifices etc. also.

original: śuddhidvārā yajñādibhiḥ śravaṇādiṣu sākṣādvidyāhetuṣu ghaṭiteṣu vidyāvilambo na yuktaḥ /
analyzed: śuddhi dvārā yajña ādibhiḥ śravaṇa ādiṣu sākṣāt vidyā hetuṣu ghaṭiteṣu vidyā vilambaḥ na yuktaḥ
translated: When listening etc. which are the direct causes of knowledge are accomplished by sacrifices etc. through purification, it is not proper for knowledge to be delayed.

original: dṛśyate ca vilambaḥ ataḥ śravaṇādervidyāhetutvamasiddhamiti pūrvapakṣe phalam /
analyzed: dṛśyate ca vilambaḥ atas śravaṇa ādeḥ vidyā hetu tvam asiddham iti pūrvapakṣe phalam
translated: But delay is seen. Therefore, the fact that listening etc. are the causes of knowledge is not established. This is the result of the prima facie view.

original: pratibandhakavaśādvilambe 'pi hetutvasiddhiriti siddhānte phalaṃ matvā citrādivadaniyataphalaṃ śravaṇādikamiti siddhāntayatievamiti /
analyzed: pratibandhaka vaśāt vilambe pi hetu tva siddhiḥ iti siddhānte phalam matvā citra ādi vat aniyata phalam śravaṇa ādikam iti siddhāntayati evam iti
translated: In the conclusion, the result is that even when there is delay due to the presence of obstacles, the fact that they are causes is established. Considering this, he concludes that listening etc. have results that are not fixed, like painting etc., with the words thus etc.

original: nanu prārabdhakarmaviśeṣeṇa śravaṇādiphalapratibandhaḥ kimiti kriyate śravaṇādinaiva karmavipākapratibandhaḥ kiṃ na syādityata āhaupasthitavipākatvaṃ
analyzed: nanu prārabdha karma viśeṣeṇa śravaṇa ādi phala pratibandhaḥ kim iti kriyate śravaṇa ādinā eva karma vipāka pratibandhaḥ kim na syāt iti atas āha aupasthita vipāka tvam
translated: But why is the obstruction to the fruit of listening etc. caused by a particular karma that has begun? Why should not the obstruction to the ripening of karma be by listening etc. itself? To this he says: The fact of having ripened karma present,

analyzed: ca iti
translated: etc.

analyzed: deśa ādi mahimnā karmāṇi vipacyante iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that karmas ripen by the greatness of place etc.

analyzed: tena śravaṇa ādikam eva kim iti na vipacyante
translated: Then why do listening etc. itself not ripen?

analyzed: tatra āha yāni ca iti
translated: To that he says: And those, etc.
The ability to ripen means being the cause of manifestation.

analyzed: nanu tarhi śravaṇa ādi vipācaka deśa ādikam kīdṛśam iti atas āha śāstram api iti
translated: But then what is the place etc. that ripens listening etc.? To this he says: The scriptures, etc.

analyzed: phala balāt deśa ādi jñānam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the knowledge of place etc. is by the power of the fruit.

original: tathāpi karmaṇaiva śravaṇādipratibandho na vaiparītyamityatra ko hetustamāhasādhaneti /
analyzed: tathā api karmaṇā eva śravaṇa ādi pratibandhaḥ na vaiparītyam iti atra kaḥ hetuḥ tam āha sādhana iti
translated: Even so, what is the reason that the obstruction to listening etc. is only by karma, not the reverse? He says that: The means, etc.

analyzed: pratibandhaka tva śaktiḥ api phala balāt jñātavyā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the power of obstruction should also be known by the power of the fruit.

analyzed: pratibandhaka sadbhāve śrautam smārtam ca liṅgam āha tathā ca ityādinā
translated: When there is an obstruction, he states the indication from the scriptures and the Smritis, beginning with Thus indeed, etc.

analyzed: śṛṇvantaḥ pi na vidyuḥ iti ukteḥ pratibandha siddhiḥ
translated: The establishment of the obstruction is from the statement: Even though they listen, they do not know.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ yathāvat vaktā api āścaryaḥ adbhuta vat kaścid eva bhavati
translated: Even one who speaks about himself as he is becomes wonderful, like a marvel.

analyzed: tiṣṭhatu labdhā sākṣātkāravān  parokṣataḥ jñātā api āścaryaḥ
translated: Let alone one who has attained direct realization.🔽Even one who knows it indirectly is wonderful.

analyzed: kuśalena ācāryeṇa anuśiṣṭaḥ api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even one who has been instructed by a skilled teacher.🔽end

analyzed: e ns  start
translated: start

analyzed: mukti phala adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the fruit of liberation. Sutra.

analyzed: evam mukti phala aniyamaḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ
translated: Thus, there is no restriction on the fruit of liberation, because it is determined by that state.

original: yathā mumukṣorvidyāsādhanāvalambinaḥ sādhanavīryaviśeṣādvidyalakṣaṇe phala aihikāmuṣmikaphalatvakṛto viśeṣapratiniyamo dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yathā mumukṣoḥ vidyā sādhana avalambinaḥ sādhana vīrya viśeṣāt vidyā lakṣaṇe phale aihika āmuṣmika phala tva kṛtaḥ viśeṣa pratiniyamaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Just as for one who desires liberation and relies on the means of knowledge, a restriction is seen in the fruit characterized by knowledge, created by the difference between the fruits of this world and the next, due to the superiority of the means,

original: evaṃ muktilakṣaṇe 'pyutkarṣīpakarṣakṛtaḥ kaścidviśeṣapratiniyamaḥ /🔽syādityāśaṅkyāha evaṃ muktiphalāniyama iti /
analyzed: evam mukti lakṣaṇe pi utkarṣa upakarṣa kṛtaḥ kaścid viśeṣa pratiniyamaḥ  syāt iti āśaṅkya āha evam mukti phala aniyamaḥ iti
translated: in the same way, there may be some restriction on the superiority and inferiority created in the fruit characterized by liberation.🔽Suspecting this, he says: Thus, there is no restriction on the fruit of liberation.

original: na khalu muktiphale kaścidevaṃbhūto viśeṣapratiniyama āśaṅkitavyaḥ /
analyzed: na khalu mukti phale kaścid evaṃbhūtaḥ viśeṣa pratiniyamaḥ āśaṅkitavyaḥ
translated: Indeed, in the fruit of liberation, no such restriction should be suspected.

analyzed: kutas tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ
translated: Why? Because it is determined by that state.

analyzed: mukti avasthā hi sarva vedānteṣu eka rūpā eva avadhāryate
translated: For the state of liberation is determined to be of one form in all the Vedanta texts.

analyzed: brahma eva hi mukti avasthā na ca brahmaṇaḥ sti
translated: For Brahman itself is the state of liberation, and Brahman is not connected with many forms.

analyzed: eka liṅga tva avadhāraṇāt as tūlam an aṇu bṛ
translated: Because it is determined that Brahman has only one characteristic. 🔽'It is neither coarse nor fine' (Br. 3.8.8).

analyzed: saḥ eṣa na iti na iti ātmā bṛ
translated: 'That Self is to be described by No, no! (Br. 3.9.26).

analyzed: yatra na anyat paśyati chā
translated: 'Where one sees nothing else' (Ch. 7.24.1).

analyzed: brahma eva idam amṛtam purastāt muṇḍa
translated: 'This all is Brahman, the immortal, in the beginning' (Mu. 1.1.6).

analyzed: idam sarvam yat ayam ātmā bṛ
translated: 'This all is that Self' (Br. 2.5.19).

original: 'sa vā eṣa mahānaja ātmājaro 'maro 'mṛto 'bhayo brahma' bṛ / / /
analyzed: sa vai eṣa mahān ajaḥ ātmā ajaraḥ maraḥ mṛtaḥ bhayaḥ brahma bṛ
translated: 'That is this great unborn Self, undecaying, undying, immortal, fearless, verily Brahman' (Br. 4.4.22).

analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet bṛ
translated: 'Where all this becomes just the Self, by what and whom could one see' (Br. 4.5.15)?

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Thus it is understood from such Vedic texts.

original: apica vidyāsādhanaṃ svavīryaviśeṣāsvaphala eva vidyāyāṃ kañcidatiśayamāsañjayenna vidyāphale muktau /
analyzed: apica vidyā sādhanam sva vīrya viśeṣa asva phale eva vidyāyām kañcid atiśayam āsañjayet na vidyā phale muktau
translated: Moreover, the means of knowledge, by the excellence of its own power, may produce some superiority in the knowledge itself, but not in the result of knowledge, in liberation.

analyzed: tat hi asādhyam nitya siddha svabhāvam eva vidyāya adhigamyate iti asakṛt avādiṣma
translated: For that is to be accomplished, and its nature is eternally accomplished, and is known only through knowledge. We have said this many times.

original: naca tasyāmapyutkarṣanikarṣātmako 'tiśaya upapadyate nikṛṣṭāyā vidyātvābhāvādutkṛṣṭaiva hi vidyā bhavati /
analyzed: na ca tasyām api utkarṣa nikarṣa ātmakaḥ utiśayaḥ upapadyate nikṛṣṭāyāḥ vidyā tva abhāvāt utkṛṣṭā eva hi vidyā bhavati
translated: And even in that, no superiority in the form of excellence or inferiority is possible, because what is inferior is not knowledge. Knowledge is only what is excellent.

analyzed: tasmāt tasyām cira acira utpatti rūpaḥ tiśayaḥ bhavan bhavet
translated: Therefore, any difference in the form of earlier or later origination of the fruit would be possible in that case.

analyzed: na tu muktau kaścid atiśaya saṃbhavaḥ sti  vidyā bheda abhāvāt api tad phala bheda niyama abhāvaḥ karma phala vat
translated: But in the case of liberation, no difference is possible at all.🔽And there can be no restriction of the difference of the fruit of knowledge, because there is no difference of knowledge, just as in the case of the fruit of action.

analyzed: nahi mukti sādhana bhūtāyāḥ vidyāyāḥ karmaṇām iva bhedaḥ sti iti
translated: For there is no difference of knowledge which is the means of attaining liberation, just as there is of actions.

analyzed: saguṇāsu tu vidyāsu manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ chā
translated: But in the case of knowledge with attributes, such as 'consisting of mind, having the vital air for its body' (Tai. 2.1),

original: ityādyāsu guṇāvāpodvāpavaśādbhedopapattau satyāmupapadyate yathāsvaṃ phalabhedaniyamaḥ karmaphalavat /
analyzed: ityādyāsu guṇa āvāpa udvāpa vaśāt bheda upapattau satyām upapadyate yathāsvam phala bheda niyamaḥ karma phala vat
translated: when there is a possibility of difference due to the addition and subtraction of attributes, the restriction of the difference of the fruit is proper according to each, just as in the case of the fruit of action.

original: tathāca liṅgadarśanam 'taṃ yathā yathopāsate tadeva bhavati' iti /
analyzed: tathā ca liṅga darśanam tam yathā yathā upāsate tat eva bhavati iti
translated: And there is the indication of this in the text, 'As one worships him, so he becomes' (Ch. 3.12.7).

analyzed: na evam nirguṇāyām vidyāyām guṇa abhāvāt
translated: But it is not so in the case of knowledge without attributes, because there are no attributes.

original: tathāca smṛtiḥ 'nahi gatiradhikāsti kasyacitsati hi guṇe pravadantyatulyatām' iti /
analyzed: tathā ca smṛtiḥ na hi gatiḥ adhikā asti kasyacid sati hi guṇe pravadanti atulya tām iti
translated: And there is the Smṛti text, 'There is no higher state for any one; when there is an attribute, they declare inequality' (Mbh. 12.235.22).

analyzed: tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ tad avasthā dhṛteḥ iti pada abhyasaḥ dhyāya parisamāptim dyotayati
translated: The repetition of the words 'tasyāvasthā' and 'tadavasthā' indicates the completion of the chapter.

original: asati prārabdhakarmapratibandhe śravaṇādinehaiva vidyodayaḥ yajñādibhiḥ saṃcitapāpapratibandhasya nirastatvāt /🔽sati tu bhogena tannirāsādamutreti vidyāyā aihikāmuṣmikatvaviśeṣaniyama uktastadvatphale
analyzed: asati prārabdha karma pratibandhe śravaṇa ādinā iha eva vidyā udayaḥ yajña ādibhiḥ saṃcita pāpa pratibandhasya nirasta tvāt  sati tu bhogena tad nirāsāt amutrā iti vidyāyāḥ aihika āmuṣmika tva viśeṣa niyamaḥ uktaḥ tadvat phale
translated: When there is no obstruction of the prārabdha karma, the manifestation of knowledge occurs in this very life through hearing etc., because the obstruction caused by the sins accumulated through sacrifices etc. has been removed.

analyzed: pi mokṣe kaścid utkarṣa ādi viśeṣaḥ syāt iti atas āha evam mukti phala aniyamaḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ tad avasthā avadhṛteḥ
translated: But when there is [such an obstruction], it occurs in the next life through the removal of that by experience. Thus, it is said that there is a specific rule that the knowledge is either in this life or the next life, and similarly, there may be some special excellence etc. in the fruit of knowledge, which is liberation. To this, he says: Thus, there is no restriction on the fruit of liberation, because it is determined by that state, because it is determined by that state.

analyzed: muktiḥ atra viṣayaḥ
translated: Liberation is the topic here.

original: tasyāṃ vidyāvadviśeṣaniyamo 'sti na veti phalasyobhayathāsaṃbhavātsaṃśaye pūrvapakṣamāhayatheti /
analyzed: tasyām vidyā vat viśeṣa niyamaḥ sti na vā iti phalasya ubhayathā asaṃbhavāt saṃśaye pūrvapakṣam āha yathā iti
translated: Is there a specific rule regarding it, as in the case of knowledge, or not? Since the fruit is possible in both ways, there is doubt. The prima facie view is stated thus: Just as....

analyzed: muktiḥ sa viśeṣā  phala tvāt vidyā vadataḥ karma sādhyā muktiḥ iti phalam
translated: Liberation is with special qualities.🔽The conclusion is that liberation is to be accomplished by action, because it is a fruit, like knowledge.

analyzed: siddhānte tu nirviśeṣa tva avadhāraṇa śruti bādhitam anumānam atas jñāna eka vyaṅgyā muktiḥ iti phalam
translated: But in the established conclusion, inference is contradicted by the Vedic text determining the absence of special qualities. Therefore, the conclusion is that liberation is manifested solely by knowledge.

original: kiñca śravaṇāditāratamyādvidyāyāṃ kañcidatiśayamaṅgīkṛtya vidyālabhyamuktau nātiśaya ityāhaapica vidyāsādhanamiti /
analyzed: kiñca śravaṇa ādi tāratamyāt vidyāyām kañcid atiśayam aṅgīkṛtya vidyā labhya muktau na atiśayaḥ iti āha api ca vidyā sādhanam iti
translated: Moreover, accepting some superiority in knowledge due to the gradation of hearing etc., he says that there is no superiority in the liberation attainable through knowledge.

analyzed: nanu brahmaṇaḥ nitya siddha tvāt avidyā nivṛtteḥ ca anyatve dvaita āpatteḥ
translated: But since Brahman is eternally existent, and since the cessation of ignorance is different from it, duality would result.

analyzed: ananyatve ca asādhya tva ādikam vidyā phalam iti atas āha tat hi iti
translated: And if it is not different, then the fruit of knowledge is not being accomplished etc. To this he says: That is...

original: vidyayābhivyaktatvena brahmānanda eva mukhyaphalamabhivyaktiravidyānivṛttirānandasvarūpasphūrtipratibandhakābhāvatayā vidyayā sādhyate sā cānirvācyeti
analyzed: vidyayā abhivyakta tvena brahma ānandaḥ eva mukhya phalam abhivyaktiḥ avidyā nivṛttiḥ ānanda svarūpa sphūrti pratibandhaka abhāvatayā vidyayā sādhyate sā ca anirvācyā iti
translated: Brahman's bliss itself is the primary fruit, manifested by knowledge. Manifestation, the cessation of ignorance, is accomplished by knowledge as the absence of the obstruction to the manifestation of the nature of bliss. And that is inexpressible.

analyzed: na dvaita āpattiḥ
translated: So there is no falling into duality.

analyzed: anye tu sā brahma ananyā iti āhuḥ
translated: But others say that it is not different from Brahman.

original: naca sādhyatvānupapattestatra vidyāvaiyarthyamiti vācyam /🔽yadabhāve yadabhāvastattatsādhyamiti jñānātsarvo lokaḥ pravartate /
analyzed: naca sādhya tva anupapatteḥ tatra vidyā vaiyarthyam iti vācyam  yad abhāve yad abhāvaḥ tat tat sādhyam iti jñānāt sarvaḥ lokaḥ pravartate
translated: And it should not be said that knowledge is useless there because it cannot be accomplished.🔽For all people act on the knowledge that the absence of something is to be accomplished by that.

analyzed: yathā ca vidyāyāḥ abhāve brahma svarūpa mukteḥ abhāvaḥ nartha rūpā avidyā eva asti
translated: And just as the absence of Brahman's nature, liberation, exists as ignorance, which is of the nature of non-existence, in the absence of knowledge,

analyzed: asyāḥ avidyāyāḥ eva muktiḥ na asti iti vyavahāra viṣaya tvena mukti abhāva tvāt
translated: Because this ignorance is the subject of the notion that there is no liberation for it, due to the absence of liberation.

analyzed: tathā ca vidyām vinā muktiḥ nā asti iti niścayāt vidyām upādatte
translated: And thus, being certain that there is no liberation without knowledge, he undertakes knowledge.

analyzed: vidyā udaye ca svatas siddha nitya nivṛtta anartha sva prakāśa brahma ānanda ātman avatiṣṭhate iti anavadyam
translated: And when knowledge arises, he abides in the self, which is Brahman, whose bliss is self-luminous, whose evil is eternally and naturally removed. Thus there is no fault.

analyzed: saṃprati vidyāyām atiśaya aṅgīkāra tyajati na ca iti
translated: Now he abandons the acceptance of superiority in knowledge, saying not so.

analyzed: eka rūpe viṣaye pramāyām tāratamya anupapatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in an object of one form, the gradation of valid knowledge is not possible.

original: kathaṃ tarhi pūrvādhikaraṇe vidyāyā viśeṣa uktaḥ /
analyzed: katham tarhi pūrva adhikaraṇe vidyāyāḥ viśeṣaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Then how is the distinction of knowledge stated in the previous section?

analyzed: tatra āha tasmāt iti
translated: There he says therefore.

original: satyāmapi sāmagryāṃ jñāne vilamba ukto na tāratamyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: satyām api sāmagryām jñāne vilambaḥ uktaḥ na tāratamyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even when the means are present, delay in knowledge is stated, not gradation.

original: tarhi satyapi jñāne muktau vilambaḥ kiṃ na syādityata āhanatviti /
analyzed: tarhi sati api jñāne muktau vilambaḥ kim na syāt iti atas āha natu iti
translated: Then, even when there is knowledge, why should there not be delay in liberation? To this he says not so.

original: vāyvādipratibandhāddipotpattivilambe 'pyutpanne tamonivṛttivilambādarśanātsati jñāne nājñānanivṛttau vilamba iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vāyu ādi pratibandhāt dipa utpatti vilambe pi utpanne tamaḥ nivṛtti vilamba adarśanāt sati jñāne na ajñāna nivṛttau vilambaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even when there is delay in the arising of a lamp due to obstruction by air etc., since the removal of darkness is not seen to be delayed when it has arisen, there is no delay in the removal of ignorance when there is knowledge. This is the idea.

original: kiñca karmaṇāmupāsanānāṃ ca guṇabhedena tāratamyātphalatāratamyaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: kiñca karmaṇām upāsanānām ca guṇa bhedena tāratamyāt phala tāratamyam yuktam
translated: Moreover, since there is a gradation of actions and meditations due to the difference in their qualities, it is proper that there should be a gradation in their fruits.

analyzed: nirguṇa vidyāyāḥ tu eka rūpa tvāt tad phala aikarūpyam iti āha vidyā bheda ityādinā
translated: But in the knowledge of the attributeless Brahman, there is no such gradation, because it is of one uniform character. Hence its fruit is of one uniform character. This is what is said by the text beginning with the words, 'vidyābhedāt tu' (Sū. 3.4.1).

analyzed: smṛtau kasyacid nirguṇa vidaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In the Smṛti, the word 'kasya cit' means 'of some one who knows Brahman as attributeless'.

analyzed: tasmāt vidyā sama kālā eva muktiḥ iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that liberation is simultaneous with knowledge.

analyzed: e ns  iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrīmat śaṅkara bhagavat pāda kṛtau śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye tṛtīya adhyāyasya caturthaḥ pādaḥ  /
translated: End.🔽Thus ends the fourth pāda of the third chapter in the Śārīraka-mīmāṃsā-bhāṣya composed by the revered Śrī Śaṅkara-bhagavat-pāda.

original: iti śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīgovindānandabhagavatkṛtau śārīrakavyākhyāyā bhāṣyaratnaprabhāṭīkāyāṃ tṛtīyasyādhyāyasya caturthaḥ pādaḥ
analyzed: iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrī govindānanda bhagavat kṛtau śārīraka vyākhyāyāḥ bhāṣya ratna prabhā ṭīkāyām tṛtīyasya adhyāyasya caturthaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the commentary called Bhāṣyaratnaprabhā, written by the revered Śrī Govindānanda, a disciple of Śrī Śrīnivāsa, on the third chapter of the Śārīraka-vṛtti composed by the revered Śrī Śaṅkarācārya.

analyzed: iti tṛtīya adhyāyasya nirguṇa vidyāyāḥ antaraṅga bahiraṅga sādhana vicāra ākhyaḥ caturthaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fourth pāda of the third chapter, named the examination of the internal and external means of the knowledge of the attributeless Brahman.

analyzed: iti śrīmat brahmasūtra śāṅkara bhāṣye sādhana ākhyaḥ tṛtīyaḥ adhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter named the means of knowledge in the Śrīmadbrahmasūtraśāṅkarabhāṣya.
